CHAPTER I - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Requirements as to enacting ordinances, see Charter §§ 48 and 54. 
State Law reference- For requirements relevant to revision and codification of ordinances, see F.S.A. (1969, amended 1990) § 125.68. 

1-1 - DESIGNATED AND CITED. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances City of North Miami Beach, Florida, 2008" and may be so cited. 
(1957 Code § 1-1) 
1-2 - RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    City shall mean "the City" or "this City," and shall be construed as if the words "of North Miami Beach" followed it and shall extend to and include its several officers, agents and employees. 
    City Council shall mean the City Council of the City of North Miami Beach. 
    City Clerk shall mean the City Clerk of the City of North Miami Beach. 
    City Manager shall mean the City Manager of the City of North Miami Beach. 
    Computation of Time shall mean, whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not be counted. 
    County, the County or this County shall mean the County of Miami-Dade. 
    Florida Statutes or F/S or FSA or Fla. Sta. shall mean the current edition of Florida Statutes, as amended and supplemented. 
    Gender shall mean a word importing the masculine gender, but shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Mayor shall mean the Mayor of the City of North Miami Beach. 
    Number shall mean a word importing the singular number, but may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person or thing. 
    Officer or Official and the title of an officer or official shall be construed as if the words "of the City of North Miami Beach" followed it. 
    Oath shall mean and be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner, as applied to a building or land, shall mean and include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person shall mean and include and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property shall mean and include every species of property except real property. 
    State and the State shall be construed to mean the State of Florida. 
    Time . Words used in the present or past tense include the future as well as the present and past. 
(1957 Code § 1-2) 
1-3 - CATCHLINES OF SECTIONS. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be the titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
(1957 Code § 1-3) 
1-4 - EFFECT OF REPEAL OF ORDINANCES. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the repealed ordinance took effect. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(1957 Code § 1-4) 
1-5 - SEVERABILITY OF PARTS OF CODE. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of the court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(1957 Code § 1-5) 
1-6 - AMENDMENTS OF CODE; EFFECT OF NEW ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS; AMENDATORY LANGUAGE.[2] 
    All ordinances and resolutions passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances or resolutions repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from said Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances or resolutions as numbered and printed, or as omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances and resolutions until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances or resolutions numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the City Council. 
    Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That Section _____ of the Code of Ordinances of North Miami Beach, Florida, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
    In the event that a new section not heretofore existing in the Code, is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of North Miami Beach, Florida is hereby amended by adding a section to be numbered _____, which said Section reads as follows:...." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
    All sections, articles, chapters or provisions to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(1957 Code § 1-6) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- At the direction of the City, this section was changed so as to include amendatory resolutions, to reflect the policy of enactments by resolution, as expressed in § 2-1.3. 

1-7 - METHOD OF ADOPTION OF ORDINANCES. 
    An ordinance, prior to becoming effective, shall be submitted for consideration by the Council in such manner as the rules of the Council shall provide, and shall be read by title only. Further consideration, except as otherwise provided by this Code or by the Charter of the City of North Miami Beach for emergency passage of any ordinance, shall be deferred to a subsequent meeting of the City Council. Prior to consideration on second reading, other than emergency passage, the ordinance shall be posted on the bulletin board of the City Hall, and copies shall be made available for examination in the office of the City Clerk. The second reading of any ordinance may be read by title only. The ordinance may be amended before or after such second reading, and, upon final passage by roll call vote shall be recorded in the minutes of the Council. Before becoming a law it shall be posted for twenty-four (24) hours on the bulletin board of the City Hall. 
(Ord. No. 91-1 § 2, 1-15-91) 
1-8 - GENERAL PENALTY; CONTINUING VIOLATIONS.[3] 
1-8.1   Maximum Penalty.
    Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the City any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful where no specific penalty is provided therefor: the violation of any provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred ($500.00) dollars or imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the appropriate tribunal. 
(1957 Code § 1-8) 
1-8.2   Separate Offenses.
    Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(1957 Code § 1-8) 
1-8.3   Nuisances Declared.
    In addition to the penalties provided above, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated by the City as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(1957 Code § 1-8; F.S.A. (1966) § 167.05) 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- The penalty as hereinabove set out in section 1-8 is applicable to all sections of this Code based upon ordinances enacted prior to March 8, 1958, wherein no specific penalty is provided, said date being the effective date of the new charter set out in Part I of this volume. All sections of this Code based on ordinances enacted on or after March 8, 1958, which provide no specific penalty for violation thereof, shall be punished as provided in Section 52 of the Charter by a fine not exceeding one hundred ($100.00) dollars or by imprisonment in the City jail not exceeding thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Where sections of this Code are based on ordinances enacted on or after March 8, 1958, and contain a penalty, the penalty shall not exceed a fine of five hundred ($500.00) dollars or sixty (60) days' imprisonment in the City jail, or both, as provided in Section 21 subsection (12) of said Charter. 
Charter reference- As to penalty effective where none is provided in an ordinance, see Charter § 52. Authority to enact penalty provisions, Charter § 21(12). 
State Law reference- For State law as to maximum penalty for violation of ordinance, see Fla. Stats. 1994, § 162.22 for general power of City to abate nuisances, see Fla. Stats. 1973 § 166.011 et seq., Municipal Home Rule Powers Act. 

1-9 - RESOLUTIONS UNDER PRIOR CHARTER TO CONTINUE IN EFFECT UNLESS CHANGED OR CONFLICTING. 
    All resolutions which have been heretofore adopted or which are hereafter adopted by the City Council under the provisions of the existing City Municipal Charter and which are in effect when the new municipal Charter is effective, shall remain in force and effect, except to the extent that they conflict with the provisions of the new municipal Charter, until changed by the City Council in the manner therein provided. 
(1957 Code § 2-22; Ord. No. 819, 3-4-58) 
1-10 - ALTERING CODE. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation in the City to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of North Miami Beach to be misrepresented. 
(1957 Code § 1-7) 
CHAPTER II - STRUCTURE OF CITY GOVERNMENT 
Article I. - The City Commission[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, changed the title of Art. I from "The City Council" to read as herein set out. 

2-1 - CITY COMMISSION.[2] 
2-1.1   Meetings of the City Commission.
a.  Quorum Required/Ethical Duty to Remain at City Commission Meetings. Before the City Commission can transact any legal business, there must be not less than five (5) duly qualified Commissioners present. Furthermore, in order to promote the integrity of Commission meetings and to ensure the performance of public duties by the City's elected officials, Commissioners shall (subject to restroom or other temporary personal breaks, and subject to a Commissioner's duty to leave Commission chambers during that portion of a Commission meeting in which the Commissioner has a voting conflict) remain at City Commission meetings throughout the entirety of such meeting, barring an emergency or other matter beyond a Commissioner's control which compels his/her presence elsewhere, in which event he/she shall state into the record the basis of such emergency/other matter prior to leaving the meeting. Failure of a Commissioner to truthfully state the basis of emergency/other matter prior to leaving the meeting shall constitute a violation of this Code subsection. The Miami-Dade County Commission on Ethics and Public Trust shall enforce the provisions of this subsection and may impose any penalty authorized by County Code pertaining to violations of municipal ethics laws. The validity of any action or determination of the City Commission shall not be affected by the failure of any Commissioner to comply with the provisions herein. 
b.  Rescheduled Meetings; Notice to Commissioners and the Public. Whenever the Mayor is informed in writing or at a public meeting by a sufficient number of Commissioners that the Commissioners will not be present at a scheduled Commission meeting so that their absence will result in less than an official quorum being present, the Mayor may reschedule the regular meeting by giving notice to all Commissioners at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the rescheduled meeting that the scheduled meeting has been reset to a particular date and time. In addition, notice shall be given to the public of the rescheduled meeting at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the rescheduled meeting. Any agenda prepared for the regularly scheduled meeting shall automatically become the agenda for the rescheduled meeting. 
c.  Voting Order. All votes taken by the Mayor and City Commissioners shall be conducted on an alphabetical basis and the voting order shall be rotated at each subsequent vote. The Mayor shall always cast his/her vote last on any vote taken at a meeting. 
(1957 Code § 2-24; Ord. No. 80-8 § 2, 3-4-80; Ord. No. 2012-30, § 2, 11-7-12 ; Ord. No. 2016-9 , § 2, 10-4-16; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-1.2   Agenda.
a.  Required; Preparation by City Clerk. The business to be transacted coming before the City Commissioners shall be governed and regulated by an agenda prepared by the City Clerk and concluded five (5) business days preceding the City Commission meeting and posted and delivered by 5:00 p.m. 
b.  City Clerk to Take Requests for Placing Business on Agenda. All persons having business to be transacted with the City Commission may request the City Clerk to place the business on the agenda. 
c.  Time of Placement of Business Agenda. The time for placing business on the agenda shall be the day following an adjourned commission meeting and until six (6) days preceding the next Commission meeting. 
d.  Special Meetings, New Business Not to be Placed. No business is to be placed upon the agenda of a special Commission meeting called for a special purpose. However, new business may be placed on the agenda for all recessed or general meetings. 
e.  Placing New Business Thereon. The Mayor or any Commissioner may, upon the majority consent of the Commission, place any new business on the agenda. 
(Ord. No. 333 §§ 1-5, 9-1-53; 1957 Code §§ 2-27-2-31; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-1.3   Written Enactments of Commission to be by Resolution or Ordinance; Exceptions.
    There is hereby created and it is hereby declared to be the policy of the City Commission that all business of the City requiring written enactment at Commission meetings shall be, effectuated by resolution or by Ordinance, as determined by law and in accordance with Article II, Section 2.6 Powers of the City Commission, of the Charter of the City. 
(1957 Code § 2-31.1; Res. No. R61-6 § 1, 2-7-61; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, changed the title of § 2-1.3 from "Written Enactments of Council to be by Resolution; Exceptions" to read as herein set out. 
2-1.4   Rules of Order of Commission Meetings.
a.  Parliamentary Rules of Order Adopted. The City Commission hereby adopts the Robert's Rules of Order to effect a more orderly procedure as to the Commission meetings whether regularly or specially called. 
b.  Conflict with Charter or Ordinances. Where the Robert's Rules of Order are in conflict with the City Charter or any of the ordinances of the City, then, in that event, the Charter or the ordinances of the City shall supersede the Robert's Rules of Order. 
(1957 Code §§ 2-13; 2-14; Ord. No. 60-16 §§ 1, 2, 2-2-60; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, changed the title of § 2-1.4 from "Rules of Order of Council Meetings" to read as herein set out. 
2-1.5   Parliamentary Rules Established for Meetings of Committee-of-the-Whole.
    Whenever the City Commission sits as a committee-of-the-whole or sits in conference, the Mayor of the City Commission shall automatically be deemed to be the presiding officer over the committee-of-the-whole or conference; and that in his/her absence those members present shall elect from among themselves a member to so preside; and, further, that in all such instances Robert's Rules of Order shall prevail in like manner as if Commission were in session; or unless waived by a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of members then present. 
(1957 Code § 2-16; Ord. No. 60-96 § 1, 9-20-60; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, changed the title of § 2-1 from "City Council" to read as herein set out. 
Charter reference- Power and duties of City Council generally, Charter §§ 22-30 
Cross reference- Financial Disclosure of Elected Officials, see § 2-75. 

2-2 - VICE-MAYOR.[3] 
2-2.1   Commencement, Term of Office.
    The Vice-Mayor shall be elected by a majority of the Commission to serve for a term of four (4) months, which election shall be had at the time that the new Commission takes office, or as soon thereafter as possible, and a successor Vice-Mayor shall be elected by a majority of the Commission triannually thereafter. 
(1957 Code § 2-31.11; Ord. No. 64-21 § 1, 6-2-64; Ord. No. 66-8 § 1, 7-5-66; Ord. No. 67-9 § 1, 8-15-67; Res. No. R75-20 § 1, 5-6-75; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-2.2   Nomination and Election.
    Nominations for the office of Vice-Mayor shall be made in open meeting and no nomination shall require a second. The election of a Vice-Mayor shall be by voice vote. No member of the Commission shall abstain if such failure to vote shall result in a tie vote for the office of Vice-Mayor. If no member nominated for the office of Vice-Mayor shall receive a majority of all the votes cast another roll call shall be taken on the election of a Vice-Mayor by a choice between two (2) nominees having the highest number of votes cast. If more than two (2) are tied for the highest number of votes cast for the office of Vice-Mayor, the two (2) nominees shall be determined by lot by the drawing of names to determine who shall be the nominees to be voted upon. If one (1) member has the highest number of votes cast but less than a majority and there is a tie vote among the remaining nominees, the nominee to be voted upon with the member having the highest number of votes shall be determined by lot by the drawing of names to determine who shall be nominee to be voted upon. 
(1957 Code § 2-31.12; Ord. No. 64-21 § 1, 6-2-64; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-2.3   General Duties.
    The Vice-Mayor shall, at the request of the Mayor, or upon determination by the Commission in the absence or disability of the Mayor, act in such absence or disability and shall exercise the powers of the Mayor when so acting. In addition the Vice-Mayor shall, at the request of the Mayor, represent the Mayor and the City in connection with any affair or function at which the City is to be represented. He shall perform such other duties as the Commission may by motion, resolution or ordinance prescribe. 
(1957 Code § 2-31.13; Ord. No. 64-21 § 2, 6-2-64; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-2.4   Effect of Vacancy in Office of Mayor.
    In the event of a vacancy in the office of Mayor the Vice-Mayor shall not become Mayor but shall act as Mayor and perform the functions of the office until the election and qualification of a person to fill the vacancy. 
(1957 Code § 2-31.14; Ord. No. 64-21 § 3, 6-2-64) 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Selection, function of Vice-Mayor, Charter § 23. 

Article II. - City Attorney 

2-3 - OFFICE OF THE CITY ATTORNEY. 
2-3.1   Created.
    There is hereby created and established a Legal Department in and for the City. 
(1957 Code § 2-48; Ord. No. 867 § 1, 6-4-58) 
2-3.2   City Attorney; Requirements.
    The Legal Department of the City shall be under the supervision of a full time attorney appointed by the City Commission to serve at the pleasure of the Commission. The City Attorney shall be a member of the Florida Bar with at least five (5) years' experience in the practice of law in Florida, and shall not during his/her tenure of office engage in any private practice of law. 
(1957 Code § 2-48; Ord. No. 867 § 2, 6-4-58; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-3.3   Compensation.
    The compensation of the City Attorney and all other personnel of the Legal Department shall be fixed by the Commission in the annual budget. It shall be paid by the City in the same manner as salaries of other City employees are paid. 
(1957 Code § 2-48; Ord. No. 867 § 3, 6-4-58; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-3.4   Staff.
    The City Attorney shall have such clerical, stenographic and legal assistance as shall be approved by the Commission. Employees of the Legal Department, other than the City Attorney, may be placed under civil service at the option of the City Commission. 
(1957 Code § 2-48; Ord. No. 867 § 4, 6-4-58; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-3.5   Duties of the City Attorney; Appointment of Assistant.
    It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to act as legal advisor to the City Commission, the City Manager, and Department Heads in the City. He/she shall prepare all ordinances, resolutions or regulations submitted for consideration by the Commission. He/she shall examine and approve as to legal sufficiency all contracts, franchises, deeds or other undertakings of the City. He/she shall represent the City in bond validations, condemnations under eminent domain, and other legal proceedings in which the City is a party. Provided, however, the City Commission may, in his/her discretion, associate other counsel in any matter in which the City has an interest, and pay the compensation of such associate counsel. The City Attorney or duly appointed assistant appointed by the City Commission, for such purposes only, shall prosecute and defend cases in all appropriate tribunals. 
(1957 Code § 2-48; Ord. No. 867 § 5, 6-4-58; Ord. No. 90-25 § 2, 11-6-90; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-3.6   Additional Duties.
    The City Attorney shall attend meetings of the City Commission and shall perform such other duties as the Commission may by resolution or ordinance provide. 
(1957 Code § 2-48; Ord. No. 867 § 6, 6-4-58; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-3.7   Limitation.
    No part of the present section shall be construed so as to violate, repeal, contradict or infringe upon the rights, duties, and privileges of classified personnel under Civil Service rules and regulations presently obtaining or hereafter to be enacted or amended. 
(1957 Code § 2-48 (g); Ord. No. 867 § 7, 6-4-58) 
Charter reference- Legal Department, Charter § 42 et seq. 
Article III. - Office of the City Clerk 

2-4 - CITY CLERK. 
2-4.1   Duties and Responsibilities; Exclusions.
a.  The City Clerk of the City of North Miami Beach or the Clerk's authorized designee shall attend all regular and special meetings of the City Commission and any other meetings as requested by the City Commission. The City Clerk shall be the custodian of all City records including all electronically recorded tapes of any and all proceedings or meetings of the City Commission and all Boards, Commissions and Committees of the City. The City Clerk shall also be responsible for transcribing the minutes or proceedings of Commission meetings and for maintaining copies of same. The City Clerk shall be responsible for gathering and storing original ordinances, resolutions, deeds, agreements, contracts, and any other City documents as well as copies of the minutes of all Board, Commission and Committee meetings. The City Clerk shall be the Supervisor of City Elections, ensure that all new ordinances are properly codified in the Code of Ordinances and provide for the updating of the Code of Ordinances. The City Clerk, as Custodian of the City Records, shall oversee the maintenance of any records necessary to the City in its ordinary course of business and provide and maintain proper storage for the preservation of all such records. The Clerk shall be responsible for posting notices of City Commission meetings and placing all necessary advertisements of same in newspapers as required. The City Clerk shall administer the required oath of office to those individuals requiring same. The City Clerk shall perform any and all other duties as may be further assigned by the City Commission from time to time. 
b.  The City Clerk shall not be responsible for maintaining documents maintained by various departments including the following: All documents of the Department of Community Development, other than tapes relating to the Planning and Zoning Board, including building permits and plans which shall be kept and maintained by the Department of Community Development; records of the Public Utilities Commission, excluding tapes which shall be kept and maintained in the Public Services Director's office; minutes and records of the Retirement Committee, excluding tapes which shall be kept and maintained by the Human Resources Department, which Department shall also maintain all personnel records. Police Department records shall be kept and maintained by the Police Department under the supervision of the Chief of Police. Civil Service records shall be kept and maintained in the Human Resources Office. 
c.  The Secretary of each Board and Commission of the City shall file with the City Clerk as soon as possible after each meeting all electronically recorded tapes and a copy of the minutes of each meeting. 
(1957 Code § 2-31.21; Ord. No. 80-30 § 2, 6-10-80; Ord. No. 2010-29 § 2, 1-18-11; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Article IV. - Office of the City Manager 

2-5 - CITY MANAGER.[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- For provision regulating the appointment, qualifications, tenure, compensation, duties and powers of the City Manager, see Charter, Article VI. 

2-6 - RESERVED. 
Article V. - Departments of the City Government 

2-7 - DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT. 
2-7.1   Created.
    There is hereby created a Department of Community Development to be headed by a Director appointed by the City Manager. The Director of Community Development shall operate and function directly under the City Manager's office and shall have the same standing as other Department Heads. 
(1957 Code § 2-54.1; Ord. No. 79-19 § 1, 8-7-79) 
2-7.2   Duties of the Director.
    The Director of the Department of Community Development shall administer the Code of Ordinances of the City of North Miami Beach as it applies to planning, zoning, building inspection and Code enforcement functions. He/she shall have the authority to execute all discretionary acts allowed under the Zoning Code, promote and administer the master plan, issue building permits, provide for the proper inspection of buildings and administer any and all Codes and ordinances that are not enforced by the Police Department. In addition, the functions of the Director of Community Development shall include but are not limited to the following: The coordination, implementation and enforcement of the policies and objectives of the City Commission in the areas of planning, zoning, building inspection and Code enforcement, administration functions, investigation of citizens' inquiries regarding building and zoning, participation on the preparation of new ordinances and the revision of existing ordinances relating to planning, zoning, building inspection and Code enforcement. 
(1957 Code § 2-54.1; Ord. No. 79-19 §§ 1, 2, 8-7-79; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-8 - DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE. 
2-8.1   Creation.
    There is hereby created a Department of Finance of the City. 
(1957 Code § 2-49; Ord. No. 906 § 1, 8-20-58; Ord. No. 60-18 § 1, 2-16-60; Ord. No. 64-9 § 1, 4-7-64; Ord. No. 80-52, 9-16-80) 
2-8.2   Director of Finance.
    The City Manager shall appoint a qualified Director of Finance who shall also be the city tax assessor and the city tax collector. The Director of Finance shall be the head of the Finance Department of the City of North Miami Beach. He/she shall perform such other duties and make such reports as the City Commission may require. He/she shall post such bond payable to the City of North Miami Beach conditioned upon the faithful performance of his/her duties, as the City Commission, upon recommendation of the City Manager, shall require. The premium on such bond shall be deemed an expense of the City of North Miami Beach. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, repealed § 2-8.2 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. The former § 2-8.2 pertained to Director of Finance; appointment; duties, and derived from the 1957 Code § 2-49; Ord. No. 906 § 2, adopted Aug. 20, 1958; Ord. No. 60-18 § 2, adopted Feb. 16, 1960; Ord. No. 64-9 § 1, adopted April 7, 1964; and Ord. No. 80-52 § 2, adopted Sept. 16, 1980. 
2-8.3   Reports.
    In addition to the duties as may be prescribed herein, the Director of Finance shall submit monthly to the City Manager a full and complete statement of all receipts and disbursements of the City. He/she shall maintain the accounts and financial records of the City. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, repealed § 2-8.3 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. The former § 2-8.3 pertained to statement of receipts and disbursements, and derived from the 1957 Code § 2-49; Ord. No. 906 § 3, adopted Aug. 20, 1958; Ord. No. 60-18 § 2, adopted Feb. 16, 1960; Ord. No. 64-9 § 1, adopted April 7, 1964; and Ord. No. 80-52 § 2, adopted Sept. 16, 1980. 
2-8.4   Safekeeping of funds.
    The Director of Finance shall collect all funds payable to the City of North Miami Beach and issue his/her receipt therefor. Moneys received by the Finance Director shall be deposited in such depository as shall have been selected by the City Commission. The deposit shall be made no later than the next banking day after the receipt of such funds by the Finance Director. The City Commission may insure funds received by the Finance Director against loss by fire, theft or other cause not covered in the bond of the director, in such reasonable amount as shall take into consideration the sums of money maintained in the office prior to deposit being made as herein required. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, repealed § 2-8.4 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. The former § 2-8.4 pertained to responsibility for City funds, and derived from the 1957 Code § 2-49; Ord. No. 906 § 4, adopted Aug. 20, 1958; Ord. No. 60-18 § 2, adopted Feb. 16, 1960; Ord. No. 64-9 § 1, adopted April 7, 1964; and Ord. No. 80-52 § 2, adopted Sept. 16, 1980. 
2-8.5   Depositories.
    The City Commission shall designate one (1) or more banks or trust companies doing business in Miami-Dade County as the depository or depositories of the funds of the City of North Miami Beach. Each depository shall give bond, or other security to be approved by the City Commission, securing the safekeeping of the funds of the City and the prompt payment of same upon demand. At the time of each deposit, the director of finance shall prepare an abstract showing the amount to be credited to each of the City funds herein authorized, and the depository shall prepare deposit receipts in triplicate, two (2) of which shall be delivered to the Director of Finance. One (1) receipt shall, by the Director of Finance, be preserved for the use of the auditor appointed by the City Commission. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, repealed § 2-8.5 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. The former § 2-8.5 pertained to depository for City funds, and derived from the 1957 Code § 2-49; Ord. No. 906 § 5, adopted Aug. 20, 1958; Ord. No. 60-18 § 2, adopted Feb. 16, 1960; Ord. No. 64-9 § 1, adopted April 7, 1964; and Ord. No. 80-52 § 2, adopted Sept. 16, 1980. 
2-8.6   Real Property Tax Appraisal Information; Fees.
    The Department of Finance will provide computer print-outs of real property tax appraisal information for a fee of one ($1.00) dollar per copy to the general public so long as the City leases the computer terminal supplying the information from the Miami-Dade County Property Appraiser's Office. 
(1957 Code § 2-49; Ord. No. 906 § 6, 8-20-58; Ord. No. 60-18 § 2, 2-16-60; Ord. No. 64-9 § 1, 4-7-64; Ord. No. 80-52 § 2, 9-16-80) 
2-8.7   Collection of Taxes and Assessments.
    The Director of the Department of Finance shall collect such taxes, levies, excises, imposts, special assessments and exactions as may be provided by ordinance, and shall issue his/her receipt therefor. The collection of such items shall be enforced in the manner provided by ordinance. 
(1957 Code § 2-49; Ord. No. 906 § 7, 8-20-58; Ord. No. 60-18 § 2, 2-16-60; Ord. No. 64-9 § 1, 4-7-64; Ord. No. 80-52 § 2, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Charter reference- Finance Department, Charter § 68 et seq. 
Cross reference- Taxation, Ch. VIII. 
2-8.7.1   Warrants.
    The Director of Finance shall issue all warrants for the payment of the just obligations of the City, signed by him/her and countersigned by the City Manager, pursuant to vouchers certified as the City Commission may require. No warrant shall be issued unless an appropriation has been made therefor and there is money in the city treasury from which to make the payment. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-9 - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY. 
2-9.1   Established.
    There is hereby established and provided a Police Department in and for the City, which Department to be headed by a Chief of Police. 
(1957 Code § 2-45a; Ord. No. 865 § 1, 6-4-58) 
2-9.2   Members of the Department.
    There shall be as many officers, patrolmen, and other personnel as the City Commission shall approve. 
(1957 Code § 2-45b; Ord. No. 865 § 2, 6-4-58; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-9.3   Duties of the Chief.
    The Chief of Police shall be responsible for the proper performance of his/her duties and for the administration of the affairs and duties of the Police Department as more fully set forth in Article VIII Police Department, of the Charter as set out in Part I of this Code. It shall be the duty of the Department to enforce the ordinances of the City and to maintain and preserve order therein. 
(1957 Code § 2-45c; Ord. No. 865 § 3, 6-4-58; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-9.4   Powers of Police Officers.
    Members of the Police Department shall enjoy and possess such powers as may be authorized by the general laws of the State of Florida, the City Charter, and ordinances of the City not inconsistent therewith. 
(1957 Code § 2-45d; Ord. No. 865 § 4, 6-4-58; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17, changed the title of § 2-9.4 from "Powers of Policemen" to read as herein set out. 
2-9.5   Protection of Rights.
    No part of this section shall be construed so as to violate, repeal, contradict or infringe upon the rights, duties, and privileges of classified personnel now (June 4, 1958), in the Police Department or classified personnel to be added to the Police Department under Civil Service rules and regulations presently obtaining or hereafter to be enacted or amended. 
(1957 Code § 2-45e; Ord. No. 865 § 5, 6-4-58) 
2-9.6   Disposal of Abandoned Property.
a.  Authority. The Police Department of the City is hereby granted the authority to dispose of all abandoned personal property in the possession of such Department for a period of more than one hundred twenty (120) days. 
b.  Advertising Sale. Such personal property shall first be advertised for sale by public auction in a newspaper of general circulation in Miami-Dade County. 
c.  Number of Publications of Notice. Such notice of sale shall be published no less than one (1) time per week for two (2) consecutive weeks prior to such sale. 
d.  Date of Sale. The date of sale shall be no less than fifteen (15) days from the date of last publication. 
e.  Posting Notice. Notice of such sale is to be placed in a conspicuous location of the City Hall. 
f.  Disposition of Unsold Property. All such property not purchased at such sale may be sold at private sale or be donated to an organized charity. 
g.  Disposition of Proceeds. All funds received from the sale of such abandoned property shall be placed in the general fund of the City. 
(Ord. No. 726 §§ 1-7, 7-20-57; 1957 Code § 2-45.1) 
Charter reference- For provisions relating to the Police Chief and Police Department, see Charter §§ 86-89, inclusive. 
Cross reference- As to interfering with Police in the discharge of their duties, see subsection 9-2.1. 
2-10 - FIRE DEPARTMENT. 
    The City Commission may provide for the creation, operation, and maintenance of a Fire Department for the City of North Miami Beach. The Fire Chief shall be head of the department. He/she shall be appointed by the City Manager. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-10.1   Powers.
    The Fire Chief and the Fire Department shall have such powers relating to fire prevention, fire detection and the fighting of fires anywhere in the City of North Miami Beach, or in adjacent areas threatening the safety and well being of the citizens of the City of North Miami Beach, as the City Commission may by ordinance provide. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-10.2   Fire Department Budget.
    The City Commission, in the annual budget, shall make adequate provision for the maintenance of the Fire Department, in accordance with recommendations of the City Manager. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-11 - OFF-DUTY POLICE SERVICES; PERMIT REQUIRED FOR SERVICES OF OFF-DUTY POLICE. 
2-11.1   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    Chief shall mean the Police Chief. 
    City Manager shall mean the City Manager of the City of North Miami Beach. 
    Off-regular-duty police services shall mean and include any police services rendered by police officers during a period or periods of time not within their regularly assigned hours of duty. 
    Permit shall mean a permit issued pursuant to this section. 
    Permit Assignment shall mean and include any assignment made by the Police Chief to a Police Officer to provide any off-regular-duty Police services. 
    Permittee shall mean and include any person receiving a permit. 
    Police Officer shall mean a Police Officer of any rank who is an employee of the North Miami Beach Police Department. 
(1957 Code § 2-139; Res. No. R67-40 § 1, 4-4-67; Ord. No. 91-21 § 2, 8-6-91) 
2-11.2   Application for Permit.
    Any person who engages in an activity or function within the North Miami Beach area which may reasonably require special Police services in addition to those Police services provided generally to the public by law, may apply to the City Manager for a permit providing such services. 
(1957 Code § 2-140 Res. No. R67-40 § 2, 4-4-67; Ord. No. 91-21 § 3, 8-6-91) 
2-11.3   Issuance of Permit.
    Upon application on a form provided by the City Manager for that purpose, the City Manager may issue to the applicant a permit which shall authorize and define such off-regular-duty Police services as the City Manager deems appropriate; provided, however, that the City Manager may cancel a permit issued hereunder at any time with or without cause. 
(1957 Code § 2-141; Res. No. R67-40 § 3, 4-4-67; Ord. No. 91-21 § 4, 8-6-91) 
2-11.4   Charges for Permit.
    The charges for each permit issued shall be made in accordance with the following schedule: 
a.  Eighteen ($18.00) dollars per hour shall be charged for each Police Officer authorized by a permit; provided, however, that a minimum total charge of thirty-six ($36.00) dollars shall be made for each Police Officer so authorized. 
b.  If the permit assignment requires the presence of a supervising officer for its proper performance, an additional charge of one ($1.00) dollar shall be made for each hour of service rendered by such supervising officer. 
c.  Fifteen ($0.15) cents per mile shall be charged for each mile traveled by an authorized vehicle in the course of a permit assignment. 
d.  Time and mileage shall be computed in accordance with the portal to portal principle of computation. 
e.  The geographical points at which a permit assignment shall commence and terminate shall be established by the City Manager. 
f.  In the case of permittees who require the services provided for by this section on a frequent and regular basis, the City Manager may establish a uniform schedule of charges below the schedule of charges provided for herein. 
g.  If a permittee is a charitable or religious organization, and a Police Officer chooses to make a contribution to such permittee by fulfilling a permit assignment without compensation, no charge shall be made on account of services rendered by such Police Officer except a charge of one ($1.00) dollar times each hour served during the course of such assignment. 
(1957 Code § 2-142; Res. No. R67-40 § 4, 4-4-67; Res. No. R69-122 § 1, 8-7-69, Res. No. R71-28 § 1, 3-16-71; Res. No. R73-18 §§ 1, 2, 3-6-73; Res. No. R74-85 § 1, 12-10-74; Ord. No. 82-19 § 1, 6-1-82; Ord. No. 84-11 § 3, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 91-21 § 5, 8-6-91) 
2-11.5   Relinquishment of permit.
    A permittee may relinquish his/her permit at any time; provided, however, that in the event of such relinquishment, the permittee shall be required to pay to the City a reasonable compensation for all expenses incurred and preparations made to provide the services authorized by the permit. The amount of the reasonable compensation may be agreed upon by the City Manager and the permittee at the time the permit is issued. 
(1957 Code § 2-143; Res. No. R67-40 § 5, 4-4-67; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-11.6   Compensation of Police Officers.
    For each permit assignment fulfilled by him, a Police Officer shall be compensated by the City of North Miami Beach in an amount equal to the amount charged for his/her services under the permit less the sum of four ($4.00) dollars times each hour served during the course of the permit assignment, with a minimum deduction of eight ($8.00) dollars. A Police Officer shall not accept or receive any other compensation whatsoever from any person for fulfilling a permit assignment. No time served by a Police Officer in fulfilling a permit assignment shall be considered by the City in determining the amount of compensatory time off that a Police Officer may be entitled to receive. 
(1957 Code § 2-144; Res. No. R67-40 § 6, 4-4-67; Res. No. R71-28 § 2, 3-16-71; Res. No. R73-18 § 3, 3-6-73; Ord. No. 82-19 § 2, 6-1-82; Ord. No. 84-11 § 2, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-11.7   Certain Compensation Prohibited.
    No Police Officer shall accept or receive any compensation whatsoever from any person except the City of North Miami Beach for performing any off-regular-duty Police services. 
(1957 Code § 2-145; Res. No. R67-40 § 7, 4-4-67; Ord. No. 91-21 § 6, 8-6-91) 
2-11.8   Status of Police Officers Fulfilling Permit Assignment.
    Police Officers shall be deemed to be acting within the course and scope of their official duties while fulfilling permit assignments. 
(1957 Code § 2-146; Res. No. R67-40 § 8, 4-4-67; Ord. No. 91-21 § 7, 8-6-91) 
2-11.9   Disposition of Proceeds.
    All proceeds collected by the City Manager, under the terms of this section shall be forthwith transmitted by him to the Director of Finance of the City of North Miami Beach, who shall deposit the proceeds in the general fund of the City of North Miami Beach. 
(1957 Code § 2-147; Res. No. R67-40 § 9, 4-4-67) 
2-11.10   Rules and Regulations.
a.  The City Manager shall make and prescribe such rules and regulations reasonably necessary and appropriate for the proper administration and enforcement of the provisions of this section. 
b.  The Chief shall furnish from time to time such information as is requested by the City Manager pertaining to the specific character and volume of off-regular-duty services provided under the provisions hereof and the City Manager shall report to the City Commission every six (6) months the frequency, character and cost of compensation claims paid, together with any recommendations he/she may have to reduce the frequency of accidents. 
(1957 Code § 2-148; Res. No. R67-40 § 10, 4-4-67; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-12-2-13 - RESERVED. 
2-14 - DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN RESOURCES. 
2-14.1   Created.
    There is hereby created a Department of Human Resources to be headed by a Director appointed by the City Manager. The Director of Human Resources shall operate and function under the City Manager's Office and shall have the same standing as other Department Heads. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17; Ord. No. 2018-2 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, repealed § 2-14.1 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. The former § 2-14.1 pertained to created; Director, and derived from the 1957 Code § 2-50; and Ord. No. 907 § 1, adopted Sept. 4, 1958.  
 Subsequently, Ord. No. 2018-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 20, 2018, changed the title of § 2-14.1 from "Director" to read as herein set out. 
2-14.2   Duties.
    The Department of Human Resources shall maintain records relating to the employees of the City of North Miami Beach, including qualifications, employment classification, salary, leave and attendance and such other information as the City Manager or the City Commission may require. It shall provide for the giving of examinations or other determination of qualifications as herein provided, and shall make periodic reports as may be required by the City Manager, the City Commission or the Civil Service Board. The Department shall administer the provisions of the civil service system of the City of North Miami Beach. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17; Ord. No. 2018-2 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, repealed § 2-14.2 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. The former § 2-14.2 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the 1957 Code § 2-50; and Ord. No. 907 § 2, adopted Sept. 4, 1958. 
2-14.3   Reserved.
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 20, 2018, repealed former § 2-14.3, which pertained to purpose, and derived from the 1957 Code, § 2-50; and Ord. No. 907, § 9, adopted Sept. 4, 1958. 
2-15-2-18 - RESERVED. 
2-19 - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS. 
2-19.1   Department Created.
    There is created a Department of Public Works of the City of North Miami Beach, to be headed by a director selected by the City Manager in the same manner as other department heads, and possessing the same rights and privileges granted department heads in this Code. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, repealed § 2-19.1 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. The former § 2-19.1 pertained to creation, and derived from the 1957 Code § 2-50; and Ord. No. 870, § 1, adopted June 4, 1959. 
2-19.2   Powers and Duties of the Director.
    There shall be appointed a Director of Public Works, who shall have supervisory charge of the improvement, repair, maintenance and operation of streets, sidewalks, alleys, lanes, viaducts, and other public highways; of sewers, drains, ditches, culverts, canals, streams and watercourses, of all public boulevards, squares and other public places and ground belonging to the City or dedicated to public use, including parks and playgrounds; the maintenance, improving and repairing of public lands, public wharves, docks, anchorage basins, harbors, channels and watercourses; the cleaning, sprinkling, and lighting of streets and public places; the collection of disposal of waste, garbage and offal; the preservation of records, tools and appliances belonging to the City and pertaining to the Department. 
(1957 Code § 2-47; Ord. No. 870 § 2, 6-4-59) 
2-19.2.1   Functions.
    The Department of Public Works shall be responsible, subject to the powers of the City Manager, for trash and garbage collection, street maintenance and repair, maintenance of public alleys and bridges, and such other functions as the City Commission may authorize by resolution, ordinance, or in the annual budget. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-19.2.2   Commission to provide funds.
    The City Commission shall make adequate provision in the annual budget for the operation of the Department of Public Works. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-19.3   Divisions Authorized.
    The Department of Public Works shall contain as many divisions as recommended by the Director of Public Works and approved by the Commission embracing the various functions and as from time to time shall become necessary. 
(1957 Code § 2-47; Ord. No. 870 § 3, 6-4-59; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-19.4   Assistant Directors; Duties.
    All divisions of the Department of Public Works recommended by the Director, and approved by the City Commission, shall remain and be under the direct control and supervision of the Director of Public Works, who shall have an Assistant Director of Public Works in charge of each division so created. Each such Assistant Director of Public Works shall be responsible for the function recited in the title of his/her division and in all instances, directly responsible to the Director of Public Works. 
(1957 Code § 2-47; Ord. No. 870 § 4, 6-4-59; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-19.5   Limitation.
    No part of the present section shall be construed so as to violate, repeal, contradict or infringe upon the rights, duties, and privileges of classified personnel now in the Department of Public Works or classified personnel to be added to the Department of Public Works under Civil Service rules and regulations presently obtaining or hereafter to be enacted or amended. 
(1957 Code § 2-47; Ord. No. 870 § 5, 6-4-59) 
Charter reference- For enumerated powers of City, see Charter § 21. 
Cross reference- For provisions relating to health and sanitation, see Chapter XXI; re streets and sidewalks, see Chapter XVII; re water, see Chapter XIX; re civil service see Chapter V, § 5-3 et seq. 
2-20 - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SERVICES.[5] 
2-20.1   Creation of Department of Public Services; Appointment of Director of Public Services.
a.  There is hereby created and established as an Agency of, and as a separate Department of, the City of North Miami Beach, a Department to be named and known as the Public Services Department of North Miami Beach, to manage, control, operate, and maintain on a self-sustaining basis the presently owned waterworks plant and system and the sewer works plant and system, subject to the powers of the City Manager, as recited in Section 3.1.1 of the City Charter, and under the supervision and control of the City Manager. 
b.  The Public Services Department, which shall operate and function under the supervisory control of the City Manager, shall be headed by a chief executive officer, to be known as the Director of Public Services, appointed by and subject to the direct control and supervision of the City Manager in the same manner as other Department Heads, and possessing the same limitations, restrictions, responsibilities, rights and privileges granted Department Heads by the City Charter. 
c.  The Director of Public Services shall have a minimum of five (5) years experience in the public utilities field, a person of good moral character, a citizen of the United States, and have an excellent reputation for integrity, responsibility, and business ability, but no member of the Public Services Commission or City Commission shall be eligible for appointment as Director of Public Services. The Director shall receive such salary as shall be recommended by the Public Utilities Commission, subject to approval of the City Commission, and as fixed in the annual budget referred to in subsection 2-20.9. 
(1957 Code § 2-106; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-20.2   Responsibility for Maintenance, Control of Water and Sewer Works, Other Utilities.
a.  The responsibility for the maintenance, operation and control of the waterworks, plant and system, and the sewer works, plant and system shall remain with the Public Services Department, subject to this Code, including, but not limited to, Chapter 3 Purchasing. The Director of Public Services, or his/her duly appointed representative, shall be present at all solicitation openings affecting his/her Department. 
b.  The Public Services Director shall be responsible subject to the powers of the City Manager, to manage, control, operate and maintain the water and sewer works and system and all other Public Services owned and operated by the City. 
(1957 Code § 2-107; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-20.3   Powers and Duties of Director of Public Services.
a.  The Public Services Director shall at all times manage, control, operate and maintain the waterworks and sewer systems subject to the direct control and supervision of the City Manager, and consistent and in accordance with the covenants and undertakings of the City, as expressed in the ordinances adopted by the City Commission, from time to time, specifying the powers and duties of the Public Services Director, and as set forth in the following paragraph b. 
b.  The Public Services Director shall devote his/her entire time and attention to the duties of his/her office and shall not engage actively in any other business or profession. Subject to such recommendations of the Public Utilities Commission as have received the City Manager's approval, the Director shall have general supervision over and be responsible for the operation and maintenance of the waterworks and sanitary sewer systems of the City of North Miami Beach, and shall exercise the powers vested in and perform the functions and duties imposed upon the Director of Public Services by the City's ordinances. The Director shall attend all meetings of the Public Utilities Commission, shall furnish to the Public Utilities Commission, the City Manager, and the City Commission, a monthly report with respect to the operation, maintenance and financial condition of each of these systems, and shall from time to time have prepared, and shall furnish, such reports, audits, and other information relative to these systems as may be required by the City Manager or City Commission, or other governmental agencies. In the event the Director shall for any reason be temporarily incapable of exercising the powers, and of performing the duties and functions of his office, the City Manager may appoint an Acting Director, to exercise such powers and to perform such functions and duties until such incapacity of the Director shall be terminated. 
(1957 Code § 2-108; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-20.4   Appointment of Nonclassified Employees by City Manager.
    The City Manager shall appoint, for a term equal to the term of the Director of Public Services, the respective Administrative Heads of the waterworks and system and of the sewer works and system. They shall have the direct administration, supervision, and control of all personnel of their respective divisions, subject to the recommendations of the Director of Public Services, and the power and supervision of the City Manager. 
(1957 Code § 2-109; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-20.5   Status of Existing Employees of Water and Sewer Works.
    All persons presently employed by the Water Division and Sewer Division of the City, as heretofore constituted, exclusive of contract employees or employees appointed for a specific term, shall be classified within the Civil Service rules and regulations of the City and shall receive and be entitled to all of the rights and privileges heretofore accorded all other employees of the City. 
(1957 Code § 2-110; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74) 
2-20.6   City Attorney as General Counsel to the Public Services Department.
a.  The City Attorney, in addition to the duties and powers prescribed in City Charter Section 3.3.1, shall act as, and shall be deemed legal adviser and counsel to the Department of Public Services and its Director and attend all meetings. The City Attorney shall act as general counsel for the Public Services Department, Public Utilities Commission, and its members, in all matters of law which may arise, and shall prosecute or defend all suits brought by or against the Department of the City which relate to the waterworks and sewer works, plants, and systems of the City. He/she may designate one of his/her assistants, with suitable experience, to exercise the functions and duties of legal counsel to the Department under the direct supervision of the City Attorney. He/she may, as occasion arises, recommend to the City Commission the employment of special counsel as to particular suits. 
b.  The annual budgets of the Water Division and the Sewer Division of the Public Services Department shall make provision, as an operating expense, for a reasonable sum, payable to the City Attorney's office, for the legal services set forth in paragraph a. hereof. This sum shall be payable to the City Attorney in monthly installments. The City Attorney shall apportion this sum, subject to the approval of the City Manager, to supplement the salaries of the City Attorney, assigned assistant, secretarial, and other expenses of his/her office. This sum shall be in addition to the salaries and expenses allocated to the City Attorney's office by the City's annual budget. 
(1957 Code § 2-111; Ord. No. 74-13 § 2, 10-1-74; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-20.7   Fidelity Bond.
    The City Manager shall require all of the officials and employees of the Public Services Department who may be in a position of authority, or in possession of money derived from the operation of the Water and Sewer Systems, to obtain, or be covered by, a blanket fidelity or faithful performance bond or independent fidelity bonds, written by a responsible company, in amounts fully adequate to protect the City from loss. The amounts of such bonds shall be fixed by the City Commission upon recommendation of the City Manager. The premium of such bonds shall be deemed an operational expense of the division of the Public Services Department. 
(1957 Code § 2-112; Ord. No. 74-13 § 2, 10-1-74; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-20.8   Water and Sewer Works to be Managed by Department; Commission to Act as Advisory Body.
    The Department of Public Services is hereby delegated the management, control and operation of the waterworks, plant and system, and the sewer works, plant and system, of the City. The Public Utilities Commission shall act only as an advisory body to the Public Services Department, its Director, the City Manager and the City Commission with regard to the management, control and operation of the systems, except that the Public Utilities Commission is hereby delegated certain other powers and duties, as specifically hereinafter designated and limited solely thereto. 
(1957 Code § 2-91; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-20.9   Budget for the Department of Public Services.
a.  The Public Utilities Commission shall prepare a proposed annual budget as directed by the existing bond ordinances, to be submitted to the City Manager for his/her approval, modification or rejection. In the event any modifications are made by the City Manager, the modified budget shall be submitted to the Public Utilities Commission for their information and advice. Thereafter, the City Manager shall submit the annual budget to the City Commission for its approval, modification or rejection. The budget shall be prepared not later than sixty (60) days prior to the commencement of each fiscal year. The budget shall contain a proposed budget of current receipts and expenses, and a budget of capital expenditures for the ensuing fiscal year, and shall be in the form prescribed from time to time by the consulting engineer. The budget shall be submitted to the City Manager for his/her study and suggestions and thereafter by him/her transmitted to the City Commission for study and adoption and the making of any changes deemed necessary within the terms and provisions of the existing Bond Ordinances and in the best interest of the City and its Departments. 
b.  The Public Utilities Commission shall also make recommendations to the City Manager with respect to the operation, management, control, and maintenance of the waterworks, plant and system, and the sewer works, plant and system, of the City. The City Manager may give due consideration to said recommendations and may adopt any of such recommendations and may be acceptable to him, or modify or reject said recommendations as he may see fit. 
c.  The Public Utilities Commission is hereby delegated the duty and authority of making studies as to the orderly development and extension of public utilities of every type into the residential and industrial areas of the City and service areas granted to the utility by governmental agencies, and to make recommendations to the City Commission pertaining thereto for its consideration, together with such other duties and authority as the City Commission may, from time to time, provide by ordinance. 
(1957 Code § 2-92; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74; Ord. No. 86-4 § 2, 4-1-86; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-20.10   Contracts; Bylaws.
a.  The Public Services Director shall recommend to the City Manager that the City Manager, acting on behalf of the City, enter into contracts with all persons or firms deemed necessary for the efficient operation of the water and sewer systems. 
b.  The Public Utilities Commission shall have the power to establish bylaws, rules, and regulations for its own government and procedures, and may, subject to the provisions of this section, recommend to the City Manager that he/she make and enter into contracts and agreements deemed necessary or incidental for the efficient operation of the water and sewer systems, provided however, that all such contracts and agreements shall be for a term of no more than one year, and, further, that all such contracts or obligations shall be payable solely from the funds realized through the issuance of revenue bonds, or through the collecting of the revenues of the water and sewer systems. 
c.  Any recommendations made by the Public Utilities Commission to the City Manager, the City Commission, and to the Public Services Director shall not be deemed or construed as mandatory, but only suggestive in nature. 
(1957 Code § 2-93; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74; Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-20.11   Revenues.
    All revenues and other income of the water and sewer systems shall be collected, disposed of, and accounted for by the Public Services Department in the manner prescribed by the existing bond ordinances. All disbursements of the revenue of the water and sewer systems shall be made by the City Manager, upon the request of the Director of Public Services, pursuant to the annual budget of the sewer and water divisions. All disbursements of revenues not pursuant to the annual budget may be made by the City Manager upon the request of the Director of Public Services, and only upon the written approval of the consulting engineer, as stipulated in the existing bond ordinances. 
(1957 Code § 2-94; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74) 
Footnotes:

2-21 - RESERVED. 
2-22 - DEPARTMENT OF RECREATION. 
2-22.1   Recreation Director; Position Created; Duties. [6] 
    There is hereby created the position of Recreation Director. 
    The duties of the Recreation Director are herewith declared to be: 
a.  Design special events, coordinate the efforts of special workers, plan socials for neighborhood groups and direct activities as planned; 
b.  Supervise, create, direct, play, promulgate and coordinate football, basketball, and swimming activities, both junior and adult; 
c.  Organize junior and adult play leagues, when it is propitious; 
d.  Promote and develop citizenship in the young by every appropriate means through supervised leisure time activities; 
e.  Create play school programs; 
f.  Create, develop and have jurisdiction over pre-school (kindergarten) programs; 
g.  To prepare the annual departmental budget pursuant to the provisions of the Charter of the City; 
h.  To plan, organize and supervise recreation and parks; 
i.  And generally to promulgate and facilitate the various programs and duties which come within the purview of a recreation director. 
(1957 Code § 17-1; Ord. No. 60-113 § 3, 10-4-60) 
2-22.1.1   Recreation Director.
    The City Commission shall create a recreation department for the City of North Miami Beach. The City Manager, subject to the provisions relating to personnel, shall appoint a director of the Department of Recreation. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-22.1.2   Duties and Functions.
    The Recreation Department shall be responsible for the administration of the public parks, beaches, playgrounds, nursery schools, day schools and other recreational facilities provided for the health, comfort, and convenience of the citizens of the City of North Miami Beach, in accordance with such regulations or ordinances as the City Commission in its discretion may adopt. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-22.1.3   Budget.
    Upon its creation, adequate provision shall be made by the City Commission in the annual budget for the maintenance of the department of recreation. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17) 
2-22.1.4   Personnel.
    The Director and other employees of the Department of Recreation shall have such qualifications as shall be established by the Civil Service Board of the City of North Miami Beach. 
( Ord. No. 2017-2 , § 2, 2-21-17)
