2-23-2-28 - RESERVED. 
Article VI. - Emergency Management, Civil Defense Organization, and Mutual Aid Plan[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, adoped Feb. 20, 2018, changed the title of Art. VI, from "Civil Defense Organization and County Mutual Aid Plan" to read as herein set out. 

2-29 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT. 
2-29.1   Definitions.
    As used in this article: 
    City Manager shall mean the City Manager of the City of North Miami Beach or designee. 
    Emergency shall mean a condition which threatens or adversely affects the public health, safety, general welfare or security and which is or threatens to be beyond the control of those public and private agencies normally responsible for the management of such a condition, resulting from an act or imminent threatened act of war, riot, terrorism, mob or other acts of violence; from conflagration, explosion, hazardous materials incident or release; from a weather event such as a flood, hurricane or tornado; from a disruption in the City's utility, or other utility system; or from any other cause, reason, condition or circumstance. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.2   Applicability of Provisions.
    All officers, employees, contractors, subcontractors, vendors, boards and other agencies of the City are subject to the provisions of this article. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.3   Emergency Management Structure.
a.  The City Manager shall perform the functions of Director of Emergency Management and shall implement, manage and report on all actions authorized and taken under the provisions of this article. 
b.  The City Manager shall plan for the coordination of those actions necessary for the creation and maintenance of an effective emergency response capability to prepare for and manage emergency conditions. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.4   Powers, Duties and Responsibilities.
    The City Manager, when acting as the Director of Emergency Management, shall have the following powers, duties and responsibilities: 
a.  To declare a state of emergency pursuant to Section 2-29.5 and to inform the Mayor and City Commission of the reasons for and status of events requiring the declaration. 
b.  To direct the creation, revision and the exercise of emergency response plans consistent with State and County emergency plans for the mitigation of, preparation for, response to, and recovery from emergencies, and to exercise all powers permitted by Chapter 252 of the Florida Statutes. 
c.  To recommend funding to the City Commission for the creation and maintenance of an emergency response capability as provided in this article. 
d.  To issue emergency regulations necessary for the protection of life and property, establishment of public order, and control of adverse conditions affecting public welfare resulting from an emergency. 
e.  To plan for and develop an emergency operations control center to include equipment, manning, and operational procedures necessary to the management and control of emergency conditions. 
f.  To develop and manage the City's emergency awareness public information program. 
g.  To apply for public assistance or other disaster relief funding. 
h.  To take any reasonable action necessary to carry out the duties of the Director of Emergency Management that are in the public's best interest, as permitted by law. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.5   Declaration of a State of Emergency.
a.  The City Manager shall have the sole authority to declare a state of emergency. 
b.  Any declaration of a state of emergency and all emergency regulations activated under the provisions of this article shall be confirmed by the City Commission by resolution no later than at the next regular meeting, unless the nature of the emergency renders a meeting of the City Commission impossible. Confirmation of the emergency declaration shall disclose the reasons for actions proposed and taken to manage the emergency, and other pertinent data relating to the emergency requiring the declaration. 
c.  Emergency resolutions or orders authorized by this article may include, but are not limited to, the following subjects and as may be permitted pursuant to Section 870.045 of the Florida Statutes, as amended: 
1.  Evacuation; 
2.  Curfews; declaration of areas off limits; 
3.  Suspension or regulation of the sale of, or offer to sell, with or without consideration: explosives or combustibles; 
4.  Water use restrictions; 
5.  Suspension of local building regulations; 
6.  Emergency procurement procedures. 
d.  A declaration of a state of emergency shall activate the emergency plans applicable to the City. A declaration of a state of emergency shall automatically invoke the emergency measures listed in Section 870.044 of the Florida Statutes, if the emergency relates to overt acts of violence or the imminent threat of such violence. 
e.  A state of emergency, when declared, shall continue in effect from day to day until declared to be terminated by the City Manager or City Commission, in accordance with Section 2-29.6. 
f.  Upon the declaration of a state of emergency, the City Manager shall post a written notice of such declaration upon the main bulletin board in City Hall, and shall, as promptly as practicable, file in the office of the City Clerk a notice of a declared state of emergency, or emergency measure declared or ordered and promulgated by virtue of Florida Statutes. The City Manager shall notify the local media and residents as soon as possible and in the manner most practicable and expeditious. 
g.  The City Manager may issue orders pursuant to this article and may elect to adopt orders issued by County or State emergency management agencies. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.6   Termination of a State of Emergency.
    A state of emergency shall be terminated by a vote of the City Commission if practicable or upon the certification of the City Manager that the conditions leading to or causing the emergency no longer exist and the City's agencies and departments are able to manage the situation without extraordinary assistance; provided, that a state of emergency established under Sections 870.041-870.046 of the Florida Statutes shall terminate at the end of a period of seventy-two (72) consecutive hours after the declaration of the emergency, unless, prior to the end of the seventy-two (72) hour period, the City Manager or the City Commission has terminated such state of emergency. Any extension of the seventy-two (72) hour time by the City Manager must be confirmed by the City Commission by resolution at the next regular meeting, unless the nature of the emergency renders a meeting of the City Commission impossible. Notice of termination of the emergency declaration shall be made to the public by the City Manager by the same means as the notice of the declaration of the state of emergency. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.7   Police Emergencies.
a.  An emergency may be declared because of civil unrest or imminent threat to public peace or order when the Chief of Police, or if unavailable, the next highest ranking officer in the Police Department chain of command certifies to the City Manager that an emergency condition arising from hostile actions of others, armed or unarmed or other imminent threat to public peace or order, requires extraordinary measures for control, including, but not limited to curfew; blockade; explosives and combustibles; evacuation; and other similar actions. The City Manager may issue a declaration of a state of emergency in accordance with Section 2-29.5. 
b.  The declaration of a state of emergency because of civil unrest or imminent threat to public peace or order, shall authorize the issuance of emergency resolutions or orders and other appropriate resolutions or orders, as may be required and may, if applicable, require automatic emergency measures pursuant to Section 870.044 of the Florida Statutes. In addition, additional discretionary emergency measures pursuant to Section 870.045 of the Florida Statutes may be issued. 
c.  A state of emergency may be declared because of fire and hazardous materials emergencies, utility emergencies, and weather emergencies when the Chief of Police, or if unavailable, the next highest ranking officer in the Police Department chain of command certifies to the City Manager that an emergency condition exists. The City Manager may issue a declaration of a state of emergency in accordance with Section 2-29.5. 
d.  The declaration of a state of emergency pursuant to Section 2-29.5 because of fire or hazardous materials emergencies, utility emergencies, and weather emergencies shall authorize, respectively, the issuance of emergency resolutions or orders. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.8   Fire and Hazardous Materials Emergencies.
a.  An emergency may be declared because of fire or a hazardous materials incident emergency when the Miami-Dade County Fire Chief or Police Chief, or the designee of the Miami-Dade County Fire Chief or Police Chief certifies to the City Manager that an actual or potential condition arising from fire, explosion, chemical spill or release, building or bridge collapse, or plane, train or other vehicle accident, requires extraordinary measures for control, including, but not limited to calling out of off-duty and reserve personnel; assistance by outside agencies; evacuation; and other similar actions. The City Manager may issue a declaration of a state of emergency in accordance with Section 2-29.5. 
b.  The declaration of state of emergency because of fire and hazardous material emergency shall authorize the issuance of emergency resolutions or orders and other appropriate resolutions or orders, as may be required. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.9   Utility Emergencies.
a.  An emergency may be declared because of utility conditions when the Director of NMB Water or designee of the relevant franchise utility certifies to the City Manager that: 
1.  A condition exists or is imminent that endangers the safety, potability, quantity, availability, collection, conveyance, transmission, distribution, treatment, or storage of water or waste water through or within the water or waste water utility system serving the City; or 
2.  A condition exists or is imminent that endangers the safety, quality, quantity, availability, transmission, distribution, or storage of gas or electricity through or within the franchised electrical or gas utility system(s); and 
3.  Extraordinary actions to control and correct the situation are required, including, but not limited to emergency purchase; call-in of off-duty personnel; assistance by other communities and agencies; and other similar actions. 
    The City Manager may issue a declaration of a state of emergency in accordance with Section 2-29.5. 
b.  The declaration of a state of emergency because of utility conditions shall authorize the issuance of emergency resolutions or orders, and other appropriate resolutions or orders, as may be required. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.10   Weather Emergencies.
a.  An emergency may be declared because of weather conditions when the National Weather Service or a State, County or local emergency management agency informs the City or the public that emergency conditions resulting from meteorological conditions are present or imminent. Meteorological conditions covered by this section shall include, but are not limited to hurricane, floods, tornados, or other severe weather conditions and the results therefrom. The City Manager may issue a declaration of a state of emergency in accordance with Section 2-29.5. 
b.  The declaration of a state of emergency because of weather conditions shall authorize the issuance of emergency resolutions or orders and other appropriate resolutions or orders, as may be required. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.11   Suspension of Local Building Regulations.
    The City Manager may authorize a suspension of local building regulations during and following a declared state of emergency when the Chief Building Official certifies through the Director of Community Development to the City Manager that such action is necessary for the expeditious restoration of property damaged by the emergency event, unless terminated by the City Commission. Such suspension of building regulations may be applied on a case-by-case basis as required to remedy specific conditions and to facilitate the provision of emergency housing to disaster victims. The Chief Building Official shall specify the provisions of the building code to be suspended and the reasons therefore, when certifying the necessity of such suspension to the City Manager. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.12   Certification of Emergency Conditions.
    A certification of emergency conditions to the City Manager may be verbal, but each verbal certification shall be confirmed in writing within twenty-four (24) hours following an emergency declaration. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-29.13   Penalty.
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this article, for which another penalty is not specifically provided herein or required by law shall, upon conviction, be subject to such fine or imprisonment or both as provided by Section 1-8 of the City Code. Each day that a violation shall continue to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
( Ord. No. 2018-1 , § 2, 2-20-18) 
2-30 - CIVIL DEFENSE ORGANIZATION. 
2-30.1   Established.
    There is hereby established within the framework of the City government a North Miami Beach Civil Defense Organization, to discharge civil defense responsibilities and functions as defined in and provided for by Chapter 252, Florida Statutes. 
(1957 Code § 2-20.1; Ord. No. 73-17 § 1, 9-20-73) 
2-30.2   Director.
    The Director of the North Miami Beach Civil Defense Organization shall be the City Manager. He shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, and operation of the North Miami Beach Civil Defense Organization, subject only to the direction and control of the City Council. 
(1957 Code § 2-20.2; Ord. No. 73-17 § 2, 9-20-7) 
2-30.3   Performance of Functions Within and Without City.
    The North Miami Beach Civil Defense Organization shall perform civil defense functions within the territorial limits of the City of North Miami Beach, and, in addition, shall conduct such functions outside of the territorial limits of the City as may be required pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 252, Florida Statutes, and in accordance with the State and County civil defense plans. 
(1957 Code § 2-20.3; Ord. No. 73-17 § 3, 9-20-73) 
2-30.4   Basic Plan.
    The Civil Defense Survival Plan of the City of North Miami Beach, Florida, and the North Miami Beach Natural Disaster Plan, on file, are incorporated herein by reference and adopted as the basic plan for emergency action by the government of the City of North Miami Beach; except that in the event of a conflict between provisions of the civil defense survival plan or the natural disaster plan, and this section, such other sections shall control. 
(1957 Code § 2-20.4; Ord. No. 73-17 § 4, 9-20-73) 
2-30.5   Departmental Plans.
    The City Manager is authorized and directed to direct all City Departments to develop individual Departmental plans outlining necessary arrangements that such Departments will be prepared to implement to cope with emergencies arising in the City of North Miami Beach, which Departmental plans shall comply with the plans described in subsection 2-30.4. When approved by the Director of the North Miami Beach Civil Defense Organization, such plans shall be integrated within and become part of the City plans described in subsection 2-30.4 hereof as supplements and appendices thereto, and thereafter the City Manager shall direct the implementation thereof by such individual City Departments as may be required to accomplish the intents and purposes of this section and of the plans adopted pursuant to subsection 2-30.4. 
(1957 Code § 2-20.5; Ord. No. 73-17 § 5, 9-20-73) 
2-31 - COUNTY-WIDE MUTUAL AID PLAN. 
2-31.1   Mayor Authorized to Enter Into Agreements.
    The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to enter into agreements (copies of which, together with operational plans therefor are on file in the office of the City Clerk), with the County-wide mutual aid plan for Miami-Dade County, Florida, at the earliest possible moment in order to be prepared to meet the needs of the citizens of North Miami Beach, Florida, and Miami-Dade County, Florida, in the event of some physical disaster or catastrophe and because of wars in which the United States of America may be engaged and in all matters of civil defense, and to meet extraordinary conditions and problems which may arise in the City and County, resulting from potential disaster, disasters, sabotage, war, or other acts of violence affecting national welfare, such as floods, fires, earthquake, pestilence, epidemic, tornadoes, and other acts of God which threaten to cause loss or destruction of property or life. 
(1957 Code § 2-19; Ord. No. 381 § 1, 10-5-54; Ord. No. 651, 2-19-57) 
2-31.2   Duties of Department Heads With Respect to Mutual Aid Plan.
    The Department Heads of the Communications, Fire, Law Enforcement, Transportation, Public Works, Rescue, Utilities, Medical and Health Departments, and other affected Departments are hereby directed to familiarize themselves with the conditions of the County-wide mutual aid plan and stand ready to cooperate and lend aid and assistance when called upon by the Director of the Miami-Dade County Civil Defense Council, or by any other member of the County-wide mutual aid plan. 
(Ord. No. 381 § 2, 10-5-54; Ord. No. 651, 2-19-57; 1957 Code § 2-20) 
Article VII. - Boards, Committees and Commissions 

2-32 - GENERALLY. 
2-32.1   Residency requirement.
    Members of all Boards, Commissions and Committees shall be residents of the City of North Miami Beach, except as otherwise specifically provided. Should any Board, Commission or Committee member move outside the City limits during the term of his appointment, he shall automatically immediately be removed from the position he holds. 
(1957 Code 2-55; Ord. No. 79-20 § 4, 9-4-79) 
2-32.2   Any Person Can Serve on More Than One City Advisory Board, Commission or Committee Simultaneously, etc; Exception.
    Any person can serve on more than one (1) City Advisory Board, Commission or Committee simultaneously and the Mayor and members of the City Council, shall serve or be appointed to serve on more than one (1) Board, Committee or Commission of the City of North Miami Beach at the same time. However, no person can serve on the Code Enforcement Board, the Planning and Zoning Board, the Civil Service Board, or the Public Utilities Commission at the same time. 
(1957 Code § 2-23.3; Res. No. 75-28 §§ 1-3, 5-20-75; Ord. No. 2008-5 § 2, 3-18-08; Ord. No. 2010-1 § 2, 1-19-10) 
2-32.3   Optional Appointment of Ex Officio Members; Exception.
    The Mayor and City Council may appoint up to two (2) ex officio members to each Board, Commission or Committee other than the Public Utilities Commission, the Planning and Zoning Board and the Civil Service Board. An ex officio member shall have no vote on any issue or matter before the Board, Commission or Committee on which he or she sits and members need not be residents of the City. However, ex officio members of North Miami Beach General Employees' Pension Board of Trustees and the Police Officers' and Firefighters' Pension Board of Trustees are exempted from this section and the membership rights and responsibilities of such ex officio members are not limited by this section. 
(1957 Code § 2-56; Ord. No. 79-20 § 5, 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2010-12 § 2, 7-6-10) 
2-32.4   Removal, Replacement of Members.
a.  Should any member of any Board, Commission or Committee fail to attend two (2) of the three (3) consecutive meetings without due cause and without prior approval of the Chairperson, the Chairperson of that Board, Commission or Committee shall declare the member's seat vacant and certify same to the City Council. A replacement shall promptly be named by the City Council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
b.  Any member of any Board, Commission or Committee may be removed with or without cause by the City Council. 
(1957 Code § 2-57; Ord. No. 79-20 §§ 6, 10, 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2001-4 § 2, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 2009-11 § 2, 6-2-09) 
2-32.5   Authority to Incur Expenses Restricted.
    No Board, Commission or Committee, or any member thereof, shall be authorized to incur any obligation or expense on behalf of the City except in regard to those items specifically budgeted, or where otherwise provided in the Code or by ordinance. 
(1957 Code § 2-58; Ord. No. 79-20 § 7, 9-4-79) 
2-32.6   Minutes; Officers.
a.  All Boards, Commissions and Committees shall submit copies of the minutes of their respective meetings to the City Council within fifteen (15) days of the date of each meeting. 
b.  Each Board, Commission and Committee shall elect its own chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary. Each person so elected shall serve for a one (1) year term. 
(1957 Code § 2-58.1; Ord. No. 79-20 §§ 8, 9, 9-4-79) 
2-33 - INDEPENDENT CITY AUDITOR. 
    The duties, method of selection, and method of compensation of the Independent City Auditor are as follows: 
a.  Duties. 
1.  Render a professional opinion on the fair representation of the City's General Purpose Financial Statements (GPFS) and prepare same in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principals (GAAP) for the applicable fiscal year. 
2.  Conduct an annual audit which shall be conducted in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Standards (GAAS) and Generally Accepted Government Auditing Standards (GAGAS) applicable in financial statement and compliance audits. 
3.  The audit shall be performed in accordance with Section 11.45, Florida Statutes, as may be amended, and shall comply with the State of Florida Audit General Rule 10.550. 
4.  The audit shall also include: 
(a)  An auditor's report on the fair presentation of the General Purpose Financial Statements included in the Comprehensive Annual Financial Report. 
(b)  The necessary separately issued Federal and State single audit reports in accordance with OMB Circular A-133 and the Rules of the Auditors General of the State of Florida. 
(c)  Management letters to the City Council and the City Manager in order to comply with the Rules of the Auditor General. 
(d)  A report on irregularities and illegal acts, if warranted. 
5.  Fulfill all requirements as set forth by the Government Finance Officers Association (GFOA) in the Certificate of Achievement for Excellence in Financial Reporting Program in preparing the Comprehensive Annual Financial Report (CAFR). 
6.  Assist the City in planning and preparation for, and implementation of new Government Auditing Standard Board (GASB) pronouncements. 
7.  Use the audit process to evaluate strengths and weaknesses in internal auditing controls and assess areas to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of accounting and related processes. These matters shall be communicated at least annually through management letters to the City Council and the City Manager. 
8.  Maintain a year-round dialogue with the City Council and management of the City. 
9.  Be available for related work not covered under an agreement, such as verification of data used in official statements, verification of bond escrow assistance with special projects, and consent to use the auditor's report in official statements. A fee schedule for such related work shall be provided. 
b.  Method of Selection of Independent City Auditor. 
1.  The Independent City Auditor shall be selected pursuant to a Request for Proposals procedure and in accordance with the provisions of Section 218.391 of the Florida Statutes. The proposals shall be publicly opened in the Procurement Division Office at the time and date specified. Late proposals shall not be accepted or considered and shall be returned to the bidder unopened. The City of North Miami Beach reserves the right to accept any proposal deemed to be in the interest of the City or to waive any informality in any proposal. The City may reject any or all proposals and readvertise. 
2.  The City shall establish an Audit Committee of at least three (3) individuals appointed by the City Manager and/or his/her designee to review, rank and recommend a list of auditors to the City Council. The appointees of the Audit Committee shall have the necessary technical knowledge to adequately evaluate the submitted proposals. 
3.  The City Council shall appoint the Independent City Auditor by resolution. The City Council shall have the authority to remove the Independent City Auditor with or without cause. 
c.  Compensation. 
1.  The Independent City Auditor shall be paid either on an hourly rate or based on the services to be rendered. The Federal and State single audit reports shall be priced separately. 
2.  If the payment is to be based on an hourly rate, the proposed fee schedule for such services shall set forth the title and classification of each person anticipated to render services, the maximum hours to be worked by each person, and the hourly rate of each person. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3 § 2, 3-2-10) 
2-34 - EDUCATION COMMITTEE. 
2-34.1   Established.
    There is hereby established the Education Committee for North Miami Beach. 
( Ord. No. 2014-11 , § 2, 12-2-14) 
2-34.2   Purpose.
    The purpose of the Education Committee is to assist in the City Council's efforts to insure that high quality education and state of the art facilities are provided to children who reside in North Miami Beach and attend Miami-Dade County Public Schools. 
( Ord. No. 2014-11 , § 2, 12-2-14) 
2-34.3   Powers and Duties.
    The Education Committee shall be an advisory committee authorized to conduct public hearings, prepare reports and make written recommendations, on a quarterly basis, to the City Council in matters related to the Miami-Dade County Public Schools attended by children who reside in North Miami Beach. 
( Ord. No. 2014-11 , § 2, 12-2-14) 
2-34.4   Composition.
    The Education Committee shall consist of nine (9) voting members comprised of the following: 
 One (1) member, to be appointed by the City Council at large, shall be a Parent Teacher Association President or designee from a Miami-Dade County Public School serving children who reside in North Miami Beach; and 
 One (1) member, to be appointed by the City Council at large, shall be a Principal or designee of a Miami-Dade County Public School serving children who reside in North Miami Beach; and 
 Seven (7) members, to be appointed by each of the City Council members, shall be a resident of the City of North Miami Beach with experience and expertise with regard to education and whose term shall be consistent with the duration of the term of the appointing City Council member; and 
 One (1) non-voting ex-officio member, to be a City staff member, designated by the City Manager; and 
 One (1) non-voting ex-officio member, to be appointed by the City Council at large, shall be a City Council member. 
( Ord. No. 2014-11 , § 2, 12-2-14) 
2-35 - RESERVED. 
2-36 - ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR DISABLED INDIVIDUALS. 
2-36.1   Created.
    There is hereby created and established an advisory committee on the disabled, also to be known as the Advisory Committee for Disabled Individuals, which Committee shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the Mayor and City Council, and a City Council liaison member to be appointed by the Mayor. All appointments shall be for two (2) years except for appointments to fill unexpired terms, which appointments shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(1957 Code § 2-79; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(I), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 92-19 § 2) 
2-36.2   Members.
    Members of the Committee shall serve in a voluntary capacity with no compensation, and shall be persons with a longstanding interest in the disabled, as well as physically challenged individuals who, at a minimum, are representative of people who are blind or who have low vision, people who are deaf or who are hard of hearing, and people who use wheelchairs or who have difficulty walking. 
(1957 Code § 2-79; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(I), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 92-19 § 2) 
2-36.3   Duties.
    The Committee shall meet once each month in an effort to provide guidance, insight, experience and expertise in an advisory capacity to the Mayor and City Council and to the Office of the City Manager on such interests of the handicapped as architectural and other avenues of accessibility including access to information for people who are vision or hearing impaired, employment of the able handicapable, recreation and other programs to provide equal opportunity to qualified physically disabled persons, public awareness programs concerning physically challenged persons, and such other matters as may seem pertinent and appropriate. 
    The Committee shall assess the needs of the physically challenged citizens of our community and shall advise the Mayor and City Council as well as the Office of the City Manager regarding programs and aspects of City government, services and facilities aimed at eliminating physical and social barriers to the full enjoyment and productive living of the handicapable citizens of the City of North Miami Beach. 
(1957 Code § 2-79; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(I), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 92-19 § 3) 
2-37-2-39 - RESERVED. 
2-40 - BUDGET REVIEW COMMISSION. 
2-40.1   Creation; Membership; Terms.
    There is hereby created and established a Budget Review Commission, which Commission shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the Mayor and City Council. All terms shall commence on June 1, and all appointments shall be for two (2) years except for appointments to fill unexpired terms, which appointments shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(1957 Code § 2-61; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(A), 9-4-79) 
2-40.2   Qualifications of Members.
    Members of the Commission shall possess demonstrated competency in budget and fiscal affairs. 
(1957 Code § 2-61; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(A), 9-4-79) 
2-40.3   Quorum; Compensation; Meetings.
    Four (4) members of the Commission shall constitute a quorum necessary to hold meetings and take any action. Members shall serve without compensation. The chairperson may call meetings of the Commission or meetings may be called by written notice signed by four (4) members of the Commission. The Commission at any meeting may fix and call a meeting on a future date. 
(1957 Code § 2-61; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(A), 9-4-79) 
2-40.4   Duties and Powers of the Commission.
    The Commission shall have the following duties, functions, powers and responsibilities: 
a.  To serve in an advisory capacity to the City Council with respect to the continuous review of the City's budget. 
b.  To make a continuing study of the fiscal and budget matters of the City. 
c.  To report and make available to the City Council any completed written studies and recommendations affecting the budget and fiscal affairs of the City from time to time. 
d.  To perform such other duties as may from time to time be assigned by the City Council. 
(1957 Code § 3-61; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(A), 9-4-79) 
2-40.5   Limitation of Powers.
    The Commission shall be purely advisory on nature and shall not have any power or authority to subpoena or compel the attendance of witnesses. The Commission shall have no power to appoint City Officers or employees or to make policy decisions. 
(1957 Code § 2-61; Ord. 79-20 § 3(A), 9-4-79)

2-44 - CHARTER REVIEW COMMITTEE.[9] 
2-44.1   Established.
    There is hereby created and established a Charter Review Committee, which Committee shall consist of seven (7) appointed members. Each of the seven (7) Councilpersons shall appoint one (1) member to the Charter Review Committee and the appointment shall be approved by the Mayor and City Council. Each member of the Charter Review Committee shall sit as one particular Councilperson's appointee. All members of the Committee shall be residents of the City of North Miami Beach. All terms shall be determined by a Resolution of the City Council. The members of the Committee shall elect a chairperson and a vice-chairperson from its members. A Charter Review Committee shall be appointed no less than once every ten (10) years. 
(1957 Code § 2-77; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(G), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2012-35, § 2, 1-15-13 ; Ord. No. 2015-9 , § 2, 7-7-15) 
2-44.2   Duties.
    The duties of the Committee shall be prescribed by Resolution. 
(1957 Code § 2-77; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(G), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2012-35, § 2, 1-15-13 ; Ord. No. 2015-9 , § 2, 7-7-15) 
2-44.3   Quorum.
    A quorum in order to hold a meeting and make any recommendations to the City Council shall consist of four (4) members. 
(1957 Code § 2-77; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(G), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2012-35, § 2, 1-15-13 ) 
2-44.4   Compensation; Secretarial Service.
    The Committee shall serve without compensation, but the City Clerk shall make available to it such secretarial services as may be budgeted for that purpose and essential to the performance of its functions. 
(1957 Code § 2-77; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(G), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2012-35, § 2, 1-15-13 ; Ord. No. 2015-9 , § 2, 7-7-15) 
2-44.5   Interpretation.
    Nothing in this section shall be construed as interfering with the right of the people to initiate Charter changes as provided in the Home Rule Charter, and nothing in this section shall be construed as requiring mandatory adoption by the Council of recommendations of the Charter Review Committee. 
(1957 Code § 2-77; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(G), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2012-35, § 2, 1-15-13 ) 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-35, § 2, adopted Jan. 15, 2013, amended the title of Section 2-44 to read as herein set out. Formerly, Section 2-44 was entitled "Charter Review Board." 

2-45 - CITIZENS COMMITTEE ON RECREATION. 
2-45.1   Created.
    There is hereby created and established a Citizens Committee on Recreation, which Committee shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the Mayor and City Council. All terms shall commence on June 1 and all appointments shall be for two (2) years except for appointments to fill unexpired terms, which appointments shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(1957 Code § 2-71; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(E), 9-4-79) 
2-45.2   Duties.
    It shall be the duty of the Recreation Committee to study the needs of the community for recreational facilities and programs in light of existing programs, potential programs and population distribution by age groups and income classifications. The Recreation Committee shall report its findings and recommendations annually to the City Council, which report shall be made to the Council at least thirty (30) days prior to the consideration of the annual budget of the City by the Council. 
(1957 Code § 2-71; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(E), 9-4-79) 
2-45.3   Cooperation of Department of Recreation.
    The Department of Recreation shall cooperate with the Recreation Committee in the performance of its advisory functions by making available to the Committee such information relating to existing programs as the Committee may request; provided, the information requested is currently available in the form requested by the Recreation Committee without the necessity of statistical surveys requiring the time and attention of any of the personnel of the Recreation Department. 
    The Recreation Committee shall meet in the City Hall or at such other place or places as the Committee shall determine. The Recreation Committee shall hold such meetings as it may deem necessary to the performance of its functions. At the request of the chairperson of any other Committee appointed by the City Council to consider the problems of recreation in the City or appointed in connection with any related matters, the Recreation Committee shall schedule joint meetings with such Committee. 
(1957 Code § 2-71; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(E), 9-4-79) 
2-46 - RESERVED. 
2-47 - CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD. 
    (See Chapter XIV, Building and Housing for Code provisions dealing with the Code Enforcement Board.) 
2-48 - MULTI-CULTURAL COMMITTEE. 
2-48.1   Established.
    There is hereby created and established a Multi-Cultural Committee, which Committee shall consist of fifteen (15) members appointed by the Mayor and City Council. All terms shall commence on June 1 and all appointments shall be for two (2) years except for appointments to fill unexpired terms, which appointments shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. Members shall be selected as nearly as practicable on the basis of their interest and involvement in various and different cultural groups, in the arts and letters, in education programs, and in programs that will contribute to the multi-cultural development of our diverse ethnic society. 
(1957 Code § 2-76; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(F), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2009-12 § 4, 7-12-09) 
2-48.2   Purpose.
    It shall be the function of the Committee to propose such programs as in its opinion will contribute to the multi-cultural development of the community and which may develop and exploit the talents of the members of the community to accomplish the greatest good for the greatest number. The Committee shall seek to promote greater awareness and appreciation of the diversity of cultures represented by the City's residents and citizens. 
(1957 Code § 2-76; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(F), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2009-12 § 4, 7-12-09) 
2-49 - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION. 
2-49.1   Created; Membership.
    There is hereby created and established the City of North Miami Beach Economic Development Commission, which Commission shall consist of a minimum of five (5) but up to fifteen (15) members appointed by the City Council. 
(1957 Code § 2-62[a]; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(B), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2009-13 § 2, 7-21-09; Ord. No. 2012-26, § 2, 11-7-12 ) 
2-49.2   Terms.
    Members shall be appointed for terms to commence on June 1 of the year of appointment, and appointments shall be for two (2) years except for appointments to fill unexpired terms which shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. If any member fails to attend two (2) of three (3) successive meetings without cause and without prior approval of the Chairman, the Economic Development Commission shall declare the member's office vacant, and the Mayor and City Council shall promptly fill such vacancy for the remainder of the term. 
(1957 Code § 2-62[b]; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(B), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2009-9 § 2, 4-21-09; Ord. No. 2009-13 § 2, 7-21-09) 
2-49.3   Quorum; Voting.
    A quorum shall consist of a majority of active appointed members, but not less than three (3) of the duly appointed members of the Commission. The necessary vote for the passage of any motion or for the adoption of any reports by the Commission shall be a majority vote of those present and qualified to vote. 
(1957 Code § 2-62[c]; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(B), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2009-13 § 2, 7-21-09; Ord. No. 2012-26, § 3, 11-7-12 ) 
2-49.4   Compensation.
    All members shall serve without compensation, including the chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary. 
(1957 Code § 2-62[d]; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(B), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2009-13 § 2, 7-21-09) 
2-49.5   Meetings.
    Regular meetings shall be scheduled at least once every two (2) months. 
(1957 Code § 2-62[e]; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(B), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2009-13 § 2, 7-21-09; Ord. No. 2012-26, § 4, 11-7-12 ) 
2-49.6   Reserved. [10] 
2-49.7   Guidelines for Appointments.
    In determining who should be appointed as members of the Commission, the Council should include a fair balance and reasonable number of labor, business and other interested persons. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection 2-32.1, members of this Commission need not be residents or maintain residency in the City of North Miami Beach, so long as they own or manage commercial property in the City or have and maintain a business tax receipt entitling them to conduct business in the City. 
(1957 Code § 2-62(g); Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(B), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2004-8 § 2; 6-15-2004; Ord. No. 2009-13 § 2, 7-21-09) 
2-49.8   Duties; Responsibilities.
    The Commission shall have the following duties, functions and responsibilities: 
a.  To encourage and promote the development and growth of new and existing businesses within the City; 
b.  To encourage employment of area residents; 
c.  To determine and report to the City Council on the present condition of the local economy; 
d.  To determine and report ways to stimulate business growth and development the City; 
e.  To improve the relationship and to foster a positive and creative liaison between local government and local business in the City; 
f.  To establish and enhance the downtown area of the City, namely, Hanford Boulevard and other areas, as appropriate; 
g.  To interface with neighboring marketing councils and chambers to encourage business opportunities in the City; 
h.  To serve as a voice to the City Council to promote local businesses; and 
i.  To communicate with City residents and neighboring cities regarding current and future business programs, opportunities, and events. 
j.  To perform such other duties as may be assigned by the City Council from to time. 
(1957 Code § 2-62[h]; Ord. No. 79-20 § 3(B), 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2009-13 § 2, 7-21-09)
