9-2 - COOPERATION WITH POLICE OFFICERS; PROCEDURES OF THE POLICE DEPARTMENT. 
9-2.1   Obstruction of Justice; Interfering With or Giving False Information to Officer.
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to obstruct or oppose any officer of the City or other legally authorized person in the execution of legal process or in the lawful execution of any legal duty, or knowingly to give false or untrue or misleading information upon inquiry by an officer of the City regarding the whereabouts or identity of a person for whom the officer shall have a warrant. 
(Ord. No. 96, § 1, 4-7-42; 1957 Code § 13-25) 
9-2.2   Disobeying Police Officer.
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 3, 11-22-55; 1957 Code § 13-26) 
9-2.3   Property Held by the Police Department.
a.  Property Clerk Designated by Chief of Police. The Chief of Police shall designate one (1) police officer to be Property Clerk in addition to his other duties. The Property Clerk shall be responsible for the safekeeping of all evidence and other property which is held by the Police Department pending trial, or which is to be held by the City after a determination of guilt of the person tried, for the use and benefit of the City or for any other purpose whatsoever. 
b.  Disposition of Stolen Property. All property alleged to have been stolen shall be held by the Property Clerk as evidence and, after trial, the City Judge shall order the Property Clerk to return the same to its rightful owner. 
(Ord. No. 492, §§ 141, 142, 11-22-55; 1957 Code §§ 13-27, 13-28) 
9-2.4   Temporary Questioning of Persons in Public Places; Dangerous Weapon Search.
a.  A police officer may stop any person abroad in a public place whom he has probable cause to believe may be committing, may have committed, or is about to commit a felony, and may demand of him his name, address, and an explanation of his actions. 
b.  When a police officer has stopped a person for questioning pursuant to this subsection, and when such police officer has probable cause to believe he is in danger of life or limb, he may search such person for a dangerous weapon. If the police officer finds such a weapon, the possession of which may constitute a crime, he shall take and keep it until the completion of the questioning, at which time he shall either return it, if lawfully possessed, or arrest such person. 
(1957 Code § 13-29.2; Ord. No. 68-25, § 1, 8-20-68) 
9-2.5   Taking Possession of Weapons and Arms; Disposition; Custody.
a.  Every officer making an arrest under the Code of Ordinances of the City of North Miami Beach or under any State or County law shall take possession of any weapons, electric weapons or devices, or arms found upon the person arrested and deliver them to the Chief of Police of the City of North Miami Beach who shall retain the same until after the trial of the person arrested. 
b.  If the person arrested, as aforesaid, is convicted of a crime involving the use or attempted use of such weapons, electric weapons or devices, or arms, such weapons, electric weapons or devices, or arms shall become forfeited to the City of North Miami Beach without any order of forfeiture being necessary, although the making of such an order shall be deemed proper, and such weapons, electric weapons or devices, or arms shall be forthwith delivered to the Chief of Police and the Chief of Police is hereby made the custodian of such weapons, electric weapons or devices, and arms for the City. 
c.  If the person arrested, as aforesaid, is acquitted of the offenses mentioned in paragraph b, the weapons, electric weapons or devices, or arms taken from him, as aforesaid, shall be returned to him; however, if he fails to call for or receive the same within sixty (60) days from and after his acquittal or the dismissal of the charges against him, the same shall be delivered to the Chief of Police, as aforesaid, to be held by him as hereinafter provided. This subsection shall likewise apply to persons and their weapons, electric weapons or devices, and arms, who have heretofore been acquitted or the charges against them dismissed. 
d.  All such weapons, electric weapons or devices, and arms now in, or hereafter coming into, the hands of the Police Department of the City which have been found abandoned or otherwise discarded, or left in their hands and not reclaimed by the owners shall, within sixty (60) days, become forfeited. 
e.  Weapons, electric weapons or devices, or arms coming into the hands of the Chief of Police pursuant to paragraphs c and d, aforesaid, unless reclaimed by the owner thereof within sixty (60) days from the date the same come into the hands of the Chief, shall become forfeited to the City of North Miami Beach. 
f.  Weapons, electric weapons or devices, and arms coming into the hands of the Chief as aforesaid shall be listed, kept, and held by him as Custodian for the City. Any and all weapons, electric weapons or devices, and arms suitable for use by the Chief may be so used. All weapons, electric weapons or devices, and arms which are not needed or which are useless or unfit for use shall be destroyed or otherwise disposed of by the Chief as provided in Chapter 705 of the Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 492 § 140, 11-22-55; 1957 Code § 13-29; Ord. No. 80-29 § 2, 5-20-80) 
9-3 - LITTERING[3] 
9-3.1   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    Litter shall mean and include, but not be limited to, the following: trash, refuse, rubbish, junk, junk cars, garbage, debris, paper, bottles, cans, landscape trimmings, discarded trees, plants, vines, shrubs, grass, and discarded and/or scrap building materials, abandoned vehicles, as well as other similar and like materials and property. 
(1957 Code § 13-42; Ord. No. 74-1 § 7, 3-19-74) 
9-3.2   Accumulation Prohibited.
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, allow, place, accumulate, dump, maintain, or cause to remain on private or public property, litter to such an extent as to constitute or tend to constitute an eyesore, a nuisance, or a danger to the public health, safety or general welfare. 
(1957 Code § 13-43; Ord. No. 74-1 § 1, 3-19-74) 
9-3.3   Responsibility for Maintenance of Premises.
    It shall be the individual and joint responsibility of the owner, tenant, person in control, and occupant of private property to maintain the premises free of litter; and either or all such persons and/or any person responsible for the placing, dumping or depositing of the litter may be cited and prosecuted for any such existing violation, and also be charged and billed for the cost and expense of the removal of same. 
(1957 Code § 13-44; Ord. No. 74-1 § 2, 3-19-74) 
9-3.4   Approved Litter Receptacles.
    This section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in public or private litter receptacles approved or accepted by the City or in garbage cans or securely tied bundles, when such receptacles, cans, or bundles meet the requirements, rules, practice, or policy of the City or its appropriate department heads, nor shall this prohibit the storage of litter in specific, designated and authorized areas approved in writing by the City or by its appropriate department heads. 
(1957 Code § 13-45; Ord. No. 74-1 § 3, 3-19-74) 
9-3.5   Public Works Department Authorized to Remove Litter at Cost of Person Responsible, After Notice Served.
    In the event the litter is not removed within two (2) weeks, or within twenty-four (24) hours if deemed hazardous by the appropriate department head and so designated by him, after the mailing of, the personal service of, the leaving with an adult at the premises, or the posting on premises, of a notice to remove the litter, then the Public Works Department of the City shall remove the litter at the cost and expense of the owner, tenant, occupant, the person in control of the premises and/or the person responsible for the placing, dumping or depositing of the litter. 
(1957 Code, § 13-46; Ord. No. 74-1 § 4, 3-19-74) 
9-3.6   Computation of Cost.
    The cost and expense of removal of litter by the City shall be computed at the actual cost of the removal, including the following costs and expenses, to wit: Administrative, legal, publication, mailing, recording, filing, standard charges for the use of trucks, payloaders, and any other equipment necessary to effectuate the removal, if any, for each removal, and shall be due and payable to the City within thirty (30) days after posting, delivery, and/or mailing of copy of bill to the person or persons mentioned in subsection 9-3.3. If same is not paid within the allotted period of time, interest at the rate of ten (10%) percent per annum shall be added thereto. 
(1957 Code § 13-47; Ord. No. 74-1 § 5, 3-19-74) 
9-3.7   Cost to Constitute Lien.
    The bill for the cost and expense for the removal of the litter as prepared, posted, delivered and/or mailed by the head of the Department of Public Works, shall be deemed a lawful lien against the property and against the appropriate parties until fully paid to the City, and such a statement of lien may be filed by the City with the Office of the Clerk at any time after, or simultaneously with, the billing for same. 
(1957 Code § 13-48; Ord. No. 74-1 § 6, 3-19-74) 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Garbage, trash and weeds, Ch. XVIII. For provisions governing the regulations and licensing of Distribution of Handbills, see Chapter XII, Section 12-11; see also "Litter Enforcement," Section 4-15. 

9-4 - NOISE CONTROL 
9-4.1   Standards Adopted; Title.
    There is hereby created a set of noise control standards and regulations for the control of excessive and unnecessary noise in the City of North Miami Beach, as set out in this section, which shall be known as the "noise control ordinance." 
(1957 Code, § 13-65; Ord. No. 79-16 § 2, 7-17-79) 
9-4.2   Unnecessary and Excessive Noises Prohibited.
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any loud, excessive, unnecessary or unusual noise. The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, excessive, unnecessary or unusual noises in violation of this section, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive, namely: 
a.  Horns, Signaling Devices, etc. Sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle on any street or public place of the City of North Miami Beach, except as a danger warning, the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound, and the sounding of any such device for any unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. 
b.  Radios, Televisions, Phonographs, etc. Using, operating, or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, television set, musical instrument, phonograph, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner so as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants, or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person or persons who are in the room, vehicle or chamber in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100') feet from the building, structure or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
c.  Animals, Birds, etc. The keeping, owning, possessing or harboring of any animal, bird or fowl which causes frequent or long continued noise so as to disturb the sleep, peace or quietude of any inhabitant of the City or which is plainly audible to a person or ordinary sensibilities at a distance of one hundred (100') feet from the building, structure or premises in which the animal or bird is located, or is audible to a person of ordinary sensibilities located within a residential dwelling unit regardless of the distance that such dwelling unit is located from the building, structure or premises upon which the animal, bird or fowl is located. It shall be an affirmative defense to any charge hereunder that such animal, bird or fowl was emitting such noise in response to an intrusion upon the premises by any person. 
d.  Exhausts. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, or motor vehicle, except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
e.  Defect in Vehicle or Load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle, or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create loud or unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. 
f.  Trucks. The running of trucks and/or the equipment or machinery contained on or in same, and the unloading of same in an excessively loud manner for a period in excess of ten (10) minutes, within one hundred (100') feet of any residence between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(1957 Code § 13-66; Ord. No. 79-16 § 3, 7-17-79; Ord. No. 93-8 § 2, 10-9-93) 
9-4.3   Excessive Noise Prohibited in Vicinity of Churches, Schools, etc.; Notice.
    It shall be unlawful to create any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same are in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institutions, or which disturbs or unduly annoys the patients in the hospital; provided, conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that it is a school, hospital or court street. 
(1957 Code § 13-67; Ord. No. 79-16, § 4, 7-17-79) 
9-4.4   Shouting by Peddlers, etc., Prohibited.
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, hawker, or vendor to shout or tout his wares in such a manner so as to disturb the peace and quiet of a neighborhood. ;hn0; (1957 Code, § 13-68; Ord. No. 79-16, § 5, 7-17-79) 
9-4.5   Loud Noise From Vessels; Restricted Hours in Residential Areas.
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or permit to be operated any boat, motorboat, or vessel propelled or powered by machinery in such a manner as to cause a noise disturbance or create loud or unnecessary noise particularly adjacent to residential areas between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(1957 Code § 13-69; Ord. No. 79-16 § 6, 7-17-79) 
9-4.6   Violations; Penalties.
a.  Any person guilty of violating subsections 9-4.2 b, c, f; subsection 9-4.3 or subsection 9-4.5 shall receive a warning citation for a first offense. 
b.  Should any person violate subsections 9-4.2 a, d, e or subsection 9-4.4 or should any person be accused of violating subsections 9-4.2 b, c, f; subsections 9-4.3 or subsection 9-4.5 for a second time, such person, upon conviction of such violation, shall be subject to a fine of up to five hundred ($500.00) dollars and/or sixty (60) days in jail, in addition to any other penalties which may be provided in this Code. 
c.  Each and every violation, including the repetition of a violation for which a notice of violation has already been issued, shall constitute a separate offense and may be punished separately. 
(1957 Code § 13-70; Ord. No. 79-16 § 7, 7-17-79) 
9-4.7   Noises From Building or Manufacturing; Time Restricted.
a.  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in any building, construction, manufacturing or fabricating business or occupation in the City, either as owner, agent, servant, or employee, to make, cause, suffer or allow, in connection with the operation of such business, or occupation, any loud, intense or annoying noise between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following day, which noise causes annoyance to the public or disturbs the peace, quiet and rest of persons occupying or residing on property near enough thereto to be annoyed or discomforted by such noises. 
b.  Special Equipment. In addition to the restrictions in paragraph a hereof, it shall be unlawful for any persons engaged in any building or construction business to perform any work in the City between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. weekdays and 5:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. on Sundays, except by written permission of the City Building Inspector, and then only in cases of emergency, with the following machinery: Bulldozers, pile drivers, steam shovels, pneumatic hammers, and/or other similar apparatus. 
c.  Weekend restrictions in residential districts. In addition to the restrictions in paragraphs a. and b. hereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any outdoor construction or building activities which generate any offensive noises that affect the peaceable enjoyment of the neighborhood in any residential district in the City between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. on Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. 
(Ord. No. 302 §§ 1, 2, 2-17-53; 1957 Code § 13-21; Ord. No. 2002-1 § 2, 3/19/2002) 
9-4.8   Vending Vehicles, Audible Devices.
    It shall be unlawful for operators of any vending vehicles to utilize devices that are audible within the homes in the City. 
    This prohibition shall be in full force and effect during all hours of the day and night with no exception as to holidays or weekends. 
(Ord. No. 329 §§ 1, 2, 8-4-53; 1957 Code § 13-22) 
9-4.9   Reserved.
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-15 , § 2, adopted Jan. 16, 2018, repealed former § 9-4.9 which pertained to juke boxes or music on premises holding a business tax receipt, and derived from Ord. No. 128, § 1, adopted Nov. 5, 1946; and the 1957 Code, § 13-23. 
9-5 - ABANDONED, WRECKED DERELICT PROPERTY AND MOTOR VEHICLES. 
9-5.1   Lost or Abandoned Property on Public Property.
a.  Abandoned Property Procedure. Florida Statutes Chapter 705 is hereby incorporated by reference and shall be deemed a part of the City of North Miami Beach Code of Ordinances regulating the procedures for the removal of abandoned property. 
b.  Definitions. As used in this subsection with regards to public property: 
1.  Abandoned Property shall mean all tangible personal property which does not have an identifiable owner and which has been disposed on public property in a wrecked, inoperative, or partially dismantled condition or which has no apparent intrinsic value to the rightful owner. Abandoned property shall include wrecked, inoperative or partially dismantled motor vehicles, trailers, boats, machinery, refrigerators, washing machines, plumbing fixtures, furniture, and any other similar article which has no value other than nominal salvage value, if any, and which has been left abandoned and unprotected from the elements. 
2.  Lost Property shall mean all tangible personal property which does not have an identifiable owner and which has been mislaid on public property, upon a public conveyance, on premises used at the time for business purposes, or in parks, places of amusement, public recreation areas, or other places open to the public in a substantially operable, functioning condition or which has an apparent intrinsic value to the rightful owner. 
3.  Code Enforcement Officer shall mean any member of the City Code Enforcement Division who shall have been authorized to enforce the provisions of this section. 
4.  Law Enforcement Officer shall mean any member of the City Police Department who shall have been authorized to enforce the provisions of this section. 
c.  In addition to the criteria contained in Florida Statutes Chapter 705, the following criteria shall be utilized in determining whether a piece of property constitutes abandoned property: 
1.  Visible evidence of having been involved in a collision or any other incident in which physical damage was incurred to the vehicle. Visible evidence of such physical damage shall, however, be more than normal deterioration, rusting or other physical change; or 
2.  Visible evidence of being derelict property with no value other than nominal salvage value. Visible evidence required under this paragraph shall include: Removed or flat tires, partial or complete dismantling or removal of parts of the vehicle visible to the inspector; broken glass; missing vehicle parts such as windshield wipers, lights, doors, trunk covers, hoods or motor parts essential for safe operation of the vehicle, and/or other signs of general deterioration. The inspector shall consider attempts, if any, to repair and/or protect any such vehicle from rain, wind-driven rain, or other natural elements, in determining whether or not any vehicle comes within the provisions of this paragraph; or 
3.  Visible evidence of having been left abandoned and unprotected from the elements. Visible evidence under this paragraph shall include growth of vegetation above the line of the hubs of the axles, direct exposure to sunlight, rain and wind-driven rain, missing or removed body parts, a vehicle sitting in other than an upright (or operable) position, and/or showing signs of direct exposure to vandalism; or 
4.  Visible evidence of being inoperative property. Evidence required under this paragraph shall include: No visible evidence of current business tax receipt or registration; and/or visible evidence of missing body or mechanical parts which makes the operation of any such vehicle impossible. 
(1957 Code § 13-35; Ord. No. 71-19 § 1, 11-16-71; Ord. No. 78-12 §§ 2, 3, 8-1-78; Ord. No. 82-27 §§ 1, 2, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 90-4, 4-3-90) 
9-5.2   Wrecked and/or Derelict Property on Private Property.
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to put, place or to permit to remain on any private property in the City of North Miami Beach any article which constitutes wrecked and/or derelict property as defined in paragraph b of this subsection. 
b.  Definitions. As used in this subsection with regards to private property: 
1.  Wrecked and/or derelict property shall mean all tangible personal property which has been left or kept unprotected from the elements on private property in a wrecked, inoperative or partially dismantled condition or which has no apparent original intrinsic value to the rightful owner and shall include wrecked, inoperative or partially dismantled motor vehicles, trailers, boats, machinery, refrigerators, washing machines, plumbing fixtures, furniture, and any other similar article which has no value other than nominal salvage value, if any. 
2.  Code Enforcement Officer shall mean any member of the City Code Enforcement Division who shall have been authorized to enforce the provisions of this section. 
c.  In addition to the definition of "wrecked and/or derelict property" in paragraph b. the following criteria shall be utilized in determining whether a piece of property constitutes derelict property: 
1.  Visible evidence of having been involved in a collision or any other incident in which physical damage was incurred to the vehicle. Visible evidence of such physical damage shall, however, be more than normal deterioration, rusting or other physical change; or 
2.  Visible evidence of being derelict property with no value other than nominal salvage value. Visible evidence required under this paragraph shall include removed or flat tires, partial or complete dismantling or removal of parts of the vehicle visible to the inspector; broken glass; missing vehicle parts such as windshield wipers, lights, doors, trunk covers, hoods or motor parts essential for safe operation of the vehicle, and/or other signs of general deterioration. The inspector shall consider attempts, if any, to repair and/or protect any such vehicle from rain, wind-driven rain, or other natural elements, in determining whether or not any vehicle comes within the provisions of this paragraph. 
3.  A properly secured commercial grade car cover, on one (1) vehicle per single family residence or single dwelling unit shall be considered an appropriate attempt to protect the vehicle from the elements. This cover shall be properly affixed and maintained at all times. 
 The City Manager and/or his designee shall have the discretion to authorize the covering, with a commercial grade car cover, of a second vehicle per single family residence or single dwelling unit as an appropriate attempt to protect the vehicle from the elements pursuant to this paragraph. If the applicant's request for a second car cover is denied, the applicant has a direct right of appeal to the Mayor and City Council. Under no circumstances shall more than two (2) vehicles per single family residence or single dwelling unit utilize this car cover option. The option of utilizing a car cover shall not be available to further a public nuisance which may endanger the health, safety and welfare of the community; or 
4.  Visible evidence of having been left derelict and unprotected from the elements. Visible evidence under this paragraph shall include growth of vegetation above the line of the hubs of the axles, direct exposure to sunlight, rain and wind-driven rain, missing or removed body parts, a vehicle sitting in other than an upright (or operable) position, and/or showing signs of direct exposure to vandalism; or 
5.  Visible evidence of being inoperative property. Evidence required under this paragraph shall include: Visible evidence of missing body or mechanical parts which makes the operation of any such vehicle impossible. 
 A vehicle in a garage (an enclosure with a roof and with three (3) sides enclosed, usually with a fourth side having a swing door, two (2) swing doors or an overhead door, capable of being closed or latched) shall not be construed to be a wrecked and/or derelict vehicle. 
d.  Whenever a Code Enforcement Board shall find that wrecked and/or derelict property is present on private property, within the limits of the City, it shall cause a notice to be placed upon or immediately adjacent to such property. Such notice shall be substantially in the following form: 
NOTICE TO THE OWNER AND ALL PERSONS 
INTERESTED IN THE ATTACHED PROPERTY 
This property, to wit: (setting forth brief description) located at (setting forth brief description of location) is improperly stored and is unlawfully upon the property described herein and must be removed within (setting forth time period prescribed by the Code Enforcement Board, not less than ten (10) days, and provided that if the property is a boat, not less than thirty (30) days) from date of this notice; otherwise it shall be presumed to be wrecked and/or derelict property and will be removed and destroyed by order of the City of North Miami Beach. If the property is a motor vehicle or boat, the owner will be liable for the costs of removal and destruction. Dated this: (setting forth date of posting of notice) Signed: (setting forth name, title, address, and telephone number of enforcement officer). 
1.  Such notice shall not be less than eight (8") inches by ten (10") inches and shall be sufficiently weatherproof to withstand normal exposure to the elements for a period of ten (10) days. In addition to posting, the Enforcement Officer shall mail a copy of the notice to the owner of the real property upon which the wrecked and/or derelict articles are located, as shown by the real estate tax records used by the local government, and shall make reasonable effort to ascertain the name and address of the owner, if the wrecked and/or derelict property is a motor vehicle or boat, and shall mail a copy of the notice to such owner, on or before the date of posting such notice. 
2.  If at the end of the time period prescribed by the Code Enforcement Board, not less than ten (10) days, provided that if the property is a boat, not less than thirty (30) days, after posting such notice, the owner or any person interested in the wrecked and/or derelict article or articles described in such notice has not removed the article or articles and complied with the ordinance or regulation cited in the notice, the Enforcement Officer may cause the article or articles of wrecked and/or derelict property to be removed and destroyed. The salvage value, if any, of such article or articles shall be retained by the City to be applied against the costs of removal and destruction unless the costs of removal and destruction are paid by the owner as provided in paragraph d.3. in which case the salvage value may be deposited in the City of North Miami Beach general fund. 
3.  The owner of any wrecked and/or derelict motor vehicle or boat who, after notice as provided in this section, does not remove the vehicle or boat within the specified period, shall be liable to the City for all costs of removal and destruction of such property, less any salvage value received by the City. Upon such removal and destruction, the City of North Miami Beach Code Enforcement Officer shall notify the owner of the amount owed and of the penalty provision of this subsection. In the case of a wrecked and/or derelict boat, any person who neglects or refuses to pay such amount shall not be entitled to be issued a certificate of registration for any other boat, until such costs have been paid. The City Code Enforcement Officer shall supply the Department of Natural Resources with a list of persons whose boat registration privileges have been revoked under this subsection, and neither the Department nor the Tax Collector or other person acting as agent thereof shall issue a certificate of registration to a person whose boat registration privilege has been revoked, as provided by this subsection, until such costs have been paid. In the case of a wrecked and/or derelict motor vehicle, any person who neglects or refuses to pay such amount shall be subject to a fine of one hundred ($100.00) dollars. 
4.  Whoever opposes, obstructs, or resists the Code Enforcement Officer or any person authorized by the Officer in the discharge of his duties as provided in this subsection, upon conviction shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of this Code. 
5.  The Code Enforcement Officer, or any person authorized by him, shall be immune from prosecution, civil or criminal, for trespass upon any property while in the discharge or performance of duties imposed by any subsections of this section. 
6.  This section shall be cumulative, supplemental and in addition to any presently existing City of North Miami Beach Code provision or ordinance or any law of any nature whatsoever, which may have similar, like, or overlapping provisions and which may be available for use by the City of North Miami Beach. 
(1957 Code § 13-35; Ord. No. 71-19, § 1, 11-16-71; Ord. No. 78-12, §§ 2, 3, 8-1-78; Ord. No. 82-27, §§ 1, 2, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 90-4, 4-3-90) 
9-6 - ABANDONED ICEBOXES, REFRIGERATORS OR CHESTS. 
9-6.1   Destruction of Locks Required.
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to discard, abandon, or store in any carport, yard, or other place to which children have or may have access within the City, any icebox, refrigerator, chest, or other container large enough to be occupied by any child, which icebox, refrigerator, chest, or other container contains an automatic locking device, unless such locking device shall have been made inoperative or shall have otherwise been destroyed so that the icebox, refrigerator, chest, or other container shall be freely opened from the inside. It shall be the duty of every person before discarding or abandoning any such icebox, refrigerator, chest, or other container to destroy any locking device thereon or otherwise make same inoperative in conformance with the provisions of this section. It shall be the duty of the owner and of the person in possession of any icebox, refrigerator, chest, or other container stored in violation of the provisions of this section to destroy or otherwise make inoperative all locking devices thereon. 
b.  Violations of this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred ($500.00) dollars or by imprisonment in the appropriate facility for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the appropriate tribunal. 
(1957 Code, § 13-32; Ord. No. 6-21, §§ 1, 2, 6-20-61; Ord. No. 64-34, § 1, 9-22-64; Ord. No. 91-14, § 3, 5-21-91) 
9-7 - FALSE ALARMS. 
9-7.1   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    False alarm shall mean the activation of a burglary alarm by other than forced entry or attempted forced entry to the premises and at a time when no burglary or robbery is being committed or attempted on the premises. 
    Telephone alarm device shall mean any device which, when activated, automatically transmits by telephone a recorded alarm message or electronic or mechanical alarm signal to any telephone instrument installed in the Police Department and which is also referred to as an automatic dialing device. 
(Ord. No. 82-37 § 2, 11-2-82; Ord. No. 83-8 § 2, 5-17-83) 
9-7.2   Responsibility for False Alarms; Procedure.
a.  Responsibility for a false alarm shall be borne by the owner of the property in which an alarm system is employed, and the lessee or occupant of the property, including employees, agents and servants, if someone other than the owner occupies same at the time of the occurrence of the false alarm. 
b.  A response to a false alarm shall result when any Police Officer is dispatched to or learns while on patrol of the activation of any alarm system and subsequently responds to same. 
c.  If a Police Officer of the City responds to any false alarm in the City, the City shall charge the following fees to the firm, person or persons set forth in paragraph a, which fees shall be collected by the Finance Department: 
1.  For the first and second response to a false alarm between the period of October 1 through September 30, no fee shall be assessed, but the person responsible for the false alarm shall take whatever corrective action necessary to insure that the second false alarm will be the last. 
2.  For each successive response to a false alarm after the second within any twelve (12) month period, the fee assessed shall be twenty-five ($25.00) dollars for the third response, and fifty ($50.00) dollars for the fourth response, one hundred ($100.00) dollars for the fifth response, and two hundred ($200.00) dollars for the sixth or successive response. All notices of any responses to false alarms shall be sent to the alarm user and a courtesy copy shall be sent to the owner of record. After the sixth alarm, the Police Department may order the disconnection of such alarm system until it is repaired. It shall be a violation of this section not to disconnect the alarm when so directed. If six (6) alarms occur during a period between October 1 through September 30, the alarm user shall be required to attend a false alarm education training program and pay attendant fees for the program as established by the City of North Miami Beach, and to have the alarm checked by an alarm company holding a business tax receipt and forward documentation to the City of North Miami Beach stating that the alarm is functioning properly. 
(1957 Code § 13-36; Ord. No. 82-37 § 2, 11-2-82; Ord. No. 83-8 § 2, 5-17-83; Ord. No. 98-7 § 13-36, 8-18-98) 
9-7.3   Violations; Penalty; Hearing.
a.  Every person who owns, operates or leases an alarm system and who fails to turn off or deactivate the system within one (1) hour after being notified of its activation, whether the alarm is false or not, shall be deemed in violation of this section and shall be assessed a fine of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars per incident. 
b.  Upon request of the person assessed a fine or ordered to disconnect an alarm, a hearing before the North Miami Beach Police Department may be held to review such assessment or order to disconnect if a request is made in writing, within fifteen (15) days of notification of assessment or order to disconnect. 
c.  In the event that any person against whom a fine has been assessed fails to pay the fine within thirty (30) days from receipt of notification of the assessment, a certified copy of the notification of the assessment imposing the fine may be recorded in the Public Records of Dade County, Florida, and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the property on which the alarm system is located, which lien may be enforced in the same manner as a Court judgment. 
d.  It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association to install, maintain, operate or use any telephone alarm device which makes or is programmed to make connection with any telephone installed in any facility of the City. 
e.  Alarm Permit Required for Repeat Offenders Only; Procedure and Penalty for Failure to Obtain an Alarm Permit; Application Fee; Minimum Requirement of the Alarm's Capabilities; Transferability. 
1.  If an alarm user has been identified as a repeat offender, then it shall be illegal to operate or cause to operate an alarm system without a valid alarm permit issued by the City of North Miami Beach. For purposes of this subsection, a repeat offender is any alarm user at an identified location where eight (8) or more false alarms have occurred during a period from October 1 through September 30. Upon the City of North Miami Beach becoming aware of any alarm system being used by a repeat offender, the following procedure shall apply prior to enforcement of these penalties: 
(a)  A certified, return receipt requested letter that includes a blank alarm permit application form shall be sent to the owner of record of the property, tenant or listed business proprietor in question notifying him/her of the requirement to obtain an alarm permit. 
(b)  This letter shall give the owner, tenant or business proprietor thirty (30) calendar days from receipt of the letter to comply by submitting the required alarm permit form to the City of North Miami Beach. 
(c)  For residential properties the failure to obtain an alarm permit from the City will result in liens being filed against the individual home, unit, property or fee simple. 
(d)  For commercial properties, if the user/violator is the property owner, failure to obtain an alarm permit from the City will result in liens being filed against the property. For commercial properties, if the user/violator is a tenant or business owner, failure to obtain an alarm permit from the City will result in the revocation or nonrenewal of a business tax receipt. 
2.  In order to operate a valid alarm system within the City of North Miami Beach, the contractor holding a business tax receipt hired by the user to install the alarm system shall first obtain a separate electrical permit from the City of North Miami Beach. Failure to obtain a separate electrical permit from the City of North Miami Beach shall result in a double permit fee being assessed. 
3.  All repeat offenders, as specified in paragraph e.1. above shall complete an alarm permit application form and submit a nonrefundable permit fee of fifty ($50.00) dollars. The City of North Miami Beach shall issue an alarm permit to those individuals by affixing a decal to the front of the alarm location. The decal shall have an alarm user number. A replacement decal, if required, shall cost five ($5.00) dollars. 
4.  All repeat offenders within sixty (60) days of being notified to obtain an alarm permit and all alarm installations shall, at a minimum, have the following capabilities: 
(a)  Fifteen (15) minute alarm shut off for residential alarms. 
(b)  Twenty (20) minute alarm shut off for commercial alarms. 
(c)  Alarms must meet National Electric Code, South Florida Building/ National Fire Code and be installed by an alarm system installer holding a business tax receipt. 
(d)  Automatic telephone dialing system to the Police Department is prohibited. 
(e)  Alarm system must have a back up power system to prevent false alarms. 
(f)  Alarm system must have a mechanism in place that prevents the alarm from ringing from the time the authorized person enters until the system is shut off. 
(g)  Allowance by the City to disconnect the alarm any way necessary. Cost to be borne by the alarm user. 
(h)  Alarm installer must provide documentation that the alarm user has been educated regarding the use of their alarm system. 
(i)  Any other information deemed necessary by the Chief of Police. 
(j)  Twenty-four (24) hour contact information for the alarm company that services the alarm for the alarm user. 
(k)  A listing of two (2) additional persons on the application who are authorized to respond/enter the residence/ business, if necessary, when the owner (alarm user) cannot be contacted. 
5.  An alarm permit cannot be transferred to another person. An alarm permit holder shall inform the City of North Miami Beach of any change that alters any information listed on the permit application within two (2) business days. No fee will be assessed for such changes. 
f.  Permit Duration and Renewal of Permit. 
1.  Each permit expires on September 30th of every given year, and only repeat offenders as described in paragraph e,1 shall renew their permits for a new year period by submitting an updated application and a permit renewal fee to the City of North Miami Beach. The schedule for the permit renewal fee shall be set by the City Council. All fees/fines assessed during the year must be paid prior to the permit renewal. Failure for the repeat offender to renew the permit within ninety (90) days will result in the same penalties as outlined in paragraph e,1,(c) and (d) above. 
g.  Revocation or Loss of Alarm Permit. 
1.  The City of North Miami Beach may revoke an alarm permit if it is determined that: 
(a)  There is a false statement of a material matter in the application for a permit; 
(b)  The permit holder has failed to make timely payment of a fee; 
(c)  The permit holder has failed to comply with any required mandates. 
2.  A person commits an offense if he operates an alarm system during the period in which his alarm permit is revoked. The same penalties as outlined in paragraph e,1,(c) and (d) above shall apply. 
3.  The City of North Miami Beach shall notify all revoked alarm permit holders by Certified Mail Return Receipt Requested that the alarm permit has been revoked. 
h.  Reinstatement of Permit. 
1.  A person whose alarm permit has been revoked may be issued a new permit if the person: 
(a)  Submits an updated application and pays a fifty ($50.00) dollar permit fee; 
(b)  Pays, or otherwise resolves, all alarm citations which the City issued; 
(c)  Submits certification from a professional alarm company, licensed by the State or County of Dade to install or design alarm systems stating that the alarm system has been inspected and maintained by, or with the direct supervision approval of the alarm company. 
i.  Penalties. 
1.  Failure to file for the alarm permit by the required deadline, operating an alarm system without a permit, failure to pay false alarm fines, failure to attend the false alarm education training program and pay attendance fees or failure to have the alarm checked as required under paragraph c 2 of subsection 9-7.2 shall result in an additional fine which will be added to the outstanding yearly balance and the total shall be filed with the County as an appropriate lien being placed on the property or the revocation or nonrenewal of a business tax receipt. 
j.  Appeal Process. 
1.  The City Manager or his/her designee(s) shall hear all appeals from alarm users. 
2.  Within fifteen (15) days of receipt of notification that a false alarm has occurred, the alarm user must request a hearing in writing which shall be sent to the City Manager. 
3.  All requests for hearings must be accompanied by filing a bond in cash, money order or certified check for each alarm disputed. The bond shall be returned to the user if the alarm user prevails. 
4.  At the appeal hearing the alarm users shall have the right to present evidence and testimony. Within ten (10) working days, the City Manager or his/her designee(s) shall make written findings regarding the appeal and which shall be made available to the alarm user. 
(1957 Code § 13-38; Ord. No. 82-37 § 2, 11-2-82; Ord. No. 83-8 § 2, 5-17-83; Ord. No. 98-7 § 2 [13-35], 8-18-98) 
9-8 - DISORDERLY CONDUCT. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of disorderly conduct as hereinafter defined. Whoever commits such acts as are of a nature to corrupt the public morals, or outrage the sense of public decency or affect the peace and quiet of persons who may witness them, or engages in brawling or fighting or engages in such conduct as to constitute a breach of the peace or disorderly conduct shall be deemed guilty of disorderly conduct. 
(Ord. No. 492 § 131, 11-22-55; 1957 Code § 13-11; Ord. No. 91-26, § 2, 8-20-91) 
9-9 - DISORDERLY INTOXICATION; LOITERING OR PROWLING. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of disorderly intoxication as hereinafter defined. 
     No person in the City of North Miami Beach shall be intoxicated and endanger the safety of another person or property, and no person in the City of North Miami Beach shall be intoxicated or drink any alcoholic beverage in a public place or in or upon any public conveyance and cause a public disturbance. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of loitering or prowling as hereinafter defined. 
     It is unlawful for any person to loiter or prowl in a place, at a time or in a manner not usual for law abiding individuals, under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such alarm or immediate concern is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstance makes it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting him to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. 
(Ord. No. 492 § 130, 11-22-55; 1957 Code § 13-12; Ord. No. 91-26 § 3, 8-20-91) 
9-10 - HOURS OF OPERATION OF CITY FACILITIES; EXCLUSIONS; PENALTY. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to remain on or about any City facility or property including parks, swimming pools, tennis courts, the City Hall complex, parking lots and other property between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., or during hours other than the specifically permitted times posted at the park or facility, unless there is an activity approved by the City Council or the City administration taking place on the premises, or the individual has received written permission from the City Manager, the Chief of Police or their authorized designees to remain on the property. 
b.  The Police Department of the City of North Miami Beach is hereby authorized to stop any and all persons found at City facilities or on property belonging to the City of North Miami Beach between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., or during hours other than the specifically permitted times posted at the park or facility, when there is no approved activity taking place and inquire whether the person has written permission to remain. If the person so stopped does not have such permission, the police officer may order such person to move on. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such order shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
c.  Penalties. Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine not exceeding five hundred ($500.00) dollars, or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty (30) days, or both. 
(1957 Code § 13-37; Ord. No. 80-64, § 2, 11-4-80; Ord. No. 82-28, § 1, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 98-3, § 1, 4-7-98) 
9-11 - TRESPASS, BREAKING AND ENTERING. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to commit a trespass against any property within the City limits; and it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to break and enter into any property not their own within the City limits. 
(Ord. No. 492 § 138, 11-22-55; 1957 Code § 13-30) 
State Law reference- For offense of trespassing, injury to realty or similar offenses, see F.S.A. (1966), Ch. 821. 
9-12 - UNATTENDED BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS, CURFEW; BUSINESS HOURS; OPERATION OF MOTORS, ETC. 
a.  All business establishments within the City, having no attendant or personnel on the premises, shall have a set and fixed closing hour of 11:00 p.m., at which time all business operations shall cease and desist and the transactions for the day shall terminate. 
b.  Such unattended establishments shall open for business in the morning not earlier than 7:00 a.m. The maximum business hours for these unattended business establishments being from 7:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m. 
c.  All motors, pumps, and like equipment, on the premises of the above described establishments, shall be shut off and shall not be allowed to operate during the evening period aforementioned. 
(1957 Code § 13-31; Ord. No. 60-48 §§ 1-3, 5-4-60) 
9-13 - MASKED PERSONS. 
9-13.1   Prohibited on Public or Private Property.
It  shall be unlawful for any person in this City while wearing any mask or device whereby any portion of the face is so hidden or covered as to conceal deliberately the identity of the wearer to enter upon or be or appear upon any public or private property within the City limits. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 1, 7-5-49; 1957 Code § 13-16) 
9-13.2   Demanding Entrance or Trespassing Prohibited.
    It shall be unlawful for any person while wearing a mask or device whereby any portion of the face is so hidden or covered as to conceal deliberately the identity of the wearer to demand entrance or admission or enter or come upon or into the premises, enclosure, or house of any person in this City. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 2, 7-5-49; 1957 Code, § 13-17) 
9-13.3   Exceptions.
    The following are exempted from the provisions of this section: 
a.  Any person or persons wearing traditional costumes of the holiday during a holiday period. 
b.  Any person or persons under the age of seventeen (17) years, it being now determined after study that children sometimes in the spirit of levity indulge in the use of holiday masks, and which acts and conduct do not create the mischief otherwise intended to be prohibited by subsections 9-13.1 and 9-13.2. 
c.  Any person wearing a mask in a circus or play. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 4, 7-5-49; 1957 Code, § 13-18) 
9-14 - AMMUNITION AND EXPLOSIVES. 
9-14.1   Reserved.
    Former subsection 9-14.1, Armor-piercing Bullets Prohibited; Exceptions, previously codified herein and containing portions of 1957 Code § 13-39 and Ordinance Nos. 82-12 and 85-11, was repealed in its entirety by Ordinance No. 2011-11, 9-6-11. 
9-14.2   Bomb; Rumors, Transportation, etc.
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly or maliciously to make, transmit or convey, or to procure, aid, counsel, or induce another to make, transmit or convey, by any means or mode of communication whatsoever, to any other person any threat or any false statement, representation, rumor, or suggestion that a bomb, or other explosive device, has been, or will be, placed in any church, synagogue, or other place of religious worship; any school, public or private; any hospital; any hotel, restaurant, or other place of public accommodation; any building or property used for or in connection with the transportation of the public or in any other building, structure or place, public or private, of whatsoever nature. 
(1957 Code § 13-5.2; Ord. No. 971 § 1, 12-17-58) 
9-15 - OBSCENE MATERIAL OR PERFORMANCES. 
9-15.1   Declaration of Policy.
    The City Council deems it contrary to the public health, safety, welfare and morals to permit or allow the promotion of obscene material in the City. (1957 Code, § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7, § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-15.2   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    Material shall mean anything tangible which is capable of being used or adapted to arouse interest, whether through the medium of reading, observation, sound or any other manner. 
    Obscene: Any material or performance is "obscene" if: 
a.  Considered as a whole, its predominant appeal is to prurient, shameful or morbid interest in nudity, sex, excretion, sadism or masochism; 
b.  It is patently offensive because it affronts contemporary community standards relating to the description or representation of sexual matters; and 
c.  It is utterly without redeeming social value. 
    Predominant appeal shall be judged with reference to ordinary adults unless it appears from the character of the material or the circumstances of its dissemination to be designated for children or other specially susceptible audience. 
    Performance shall mean any play, motion picture, dance or other exhibition performed before an audience. 
    Promote shall mean to manufacture, issue, sell, give, provide, lend, mail, deliver, transfer, transmit, publish, distribute, circulate, disseminate, present, exhibit or advertise or to offer or to agree to do the same. 
(1957 Code § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7 § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-15.3   Promotion, etc. of Obscenity Prohibited.
    It shall be unlawful and a person is guilty of obscenity when, knowing its content and character, he: 
a.  Promotes, possesses with intention to promote, any obscene material; or 
b.  Produces, presents or directs an obscene performance or participates in a portion thereof which is obscene or which contributes to its obscenity. 
(1957 Code § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7 § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-15.4   Presumptions of Obscenity.
a.  A person who promotes obscene material, or possesses the same with intent to promote it in the course of his business is presumed to do so with knowledge of its content and character. 
b.  A person possessing five (5) or more identical or similar obscene articles is presumed to possess them with intent to promote the same. 
(1957 Code, § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7, § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-15.5   Defense.
    In any prosecution for obscenity, it is an affirmative defense that the persons to whom allegedly obscene material was disseminated, or the audience to an allegedly obscene performance, consisted of persons or institutions having scientific, educational, governmental or other similar justification for possessing or viewing the same. 
(1957 Code § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7 § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-15.6   Evidence; Adjudication of Obscenity.
a.  In any prosecution for obscenity, evidence shall be admissible to show: 
1.  The character of the audience for which the material or performance was designed or to which it was directed; 
2.  What the predominant appeal of the material would be for ordinary adults or any special audience to which it was directed, and what effect, if any, it would probably have on conduct of such people; 
3.  Artistic, literary, scientific, educational or other merit of the material; 
4.  The degree of public acceptance of the material; 
5.  Appeal to prurient interest, or absence thereof, in advertising or other promotion of the material; and 
6.  The good repute of the author, creator, publisher or other person from whom the material originated. 
b.  Expert testimony and testimony of the author, creator, publisher or other person from whom the material originated, relating to factors entering into the determination of the issue of obscenity shall be admissible. 
c.  The court shall dismiss a prosecution of obscenity if it is satisfied that the material is not obscene. 
(1957 Code § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7 § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-15.7   Confiscation of Prohibited Material.
    Whenever anyone is convicted of violating this Section, the Court, in awarding sentence, shall make an order confiscating the obscene material and authorizing and directing the Chief of Police to destroy the same. 
(1957 Code § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7 § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-15.8   Minors Under Seventeen Years of Age.
    The provisions of this section of the Code shall be inapplicable and unenforceable to persons under seventeen (17) years of age in order to comply with the 1969 Florida Statutes which have preempted this area by special legislation regarding such persons. 
(1957 Code § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7 § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-15.9   Court Orders Effectuating Above Provisions.
    The appropriate tribunal shall have the power to enter such orders, within constitutional limitations, as it shall deem necessary for the purpose of carrying out and effectuating the provisions of this section, including orders for the production and preservation of evidence. 
(1957 Code § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7 § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-15.10   Provisions Deemed Cumulative.
    This section shall be cumulative, supplemental and in addition to any presently existing City of North Miami Beach Code provision or ordinance or any law of any nature whatsoever, which may have similar, like, or overlapping provisions and which may be available for use by the City of North Miami Beach. 
(1957 Code § 13-34; Ord. No. 71-7 § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-16 - FINGERPRINTS AND PHOTOGRAPH REQUIRED FOR CERTAIN OCCUPATIONS. 
9-16.1   Fingerprinting, Photographing, Registering Certain Persons; Occupations Where Required.
    Every person employed in any nightclub, any place handling liquor, beer or wine in any form, places of amusement, hotels, rooming houses, apartment houses, delivery services originating in the City, drugstores, places where narcotics are used or administered, all night watchmen, itinerant gardeners and tree trimmers, persons employed in the business of exterminating insects and vermin, drivers of buses used for transportation to and from race tracks, solicitors for subscriptions to magazines, house to house salesmen or saleswomen, newspaper delivery boys over the age of seventeen (17) years, employees of a zoo, special police officers, parking lot attendants, domestic servants, employees of trailer sales establishments, taxicab drivers, vending machine operators, gasoline and service stations, and bail bondsmen in the City, and owners, operators and employees of day care and child care centers and nurseries and any person whose principal business is telephone solicitation are hereby required to register in a book of registration to be kept by the Chief of Police of the City and also to be fingerprinted and photographed by the Chief of Police prior to beginning work at any such employment or place of business. All such photographs and fingerprints shall be forwarded to the Federal Bureau of Investigation Division of the United States Department of Justice, Washington, D.C. 20537 for search. 
(Ord. No. 436 § 1, 6-10-55; 1957 Code § 13-13; Ord. No. 69-22 § 1, 10-7-69; Ord. No. 84-17, § 1, 10-16-84; Ord. No. 86-2 § 2, 2-18-86) 
Cross reference- Similar requirement see §§ 12-15.9, private detective. 
9-16.2   Duty of Employers.
    It shall be the duty of all employers of all persons who are required to register as provided in this section to cause such persons to so register before beginning work, and any employer who fails to perform such duty shall be subject to the revocation of his business tax receipt and to the penalties provided in Section 1-8 of this Code, in the discretion of the Municipal Judge. 
(Ord. No. 436 § 2, 6-10-55; 1957 Code § 13-14) 
9-16.3   Identification Cards.
    Identification cards shall be issued to each such person so registering, which identification card shall be renewed by the holder thereof each twelve (12) months thereafter by reregistration as above set forth. For the purpose of defraying expense of enforcement of Section 9-16, the sum of ten ($10.00) dollars for bona fide residents of the City of North Miami Beach and the sum of fifteen ($15.00) dollars for non-residents shall be paid for each such identification card or renewal thereof. All holders of identification cards shall notify the Police Department within five (5) days upon change of address. 
(Ord. No. 436 §§ 3-5, 6-10-55; 1957 Code § 13-15; Ord. No. 66-14 § 1, 10-18-66; Ord. No. 75-17 § 1, 8-19-75; Ord. No. 84-1 § 2, 2-7-84; Ord. No. 89-10 § 2, 10-3-89; Ord. No. 92-11 § 2) 
9-17 - GARAGE SALES. 
9-17.1   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    Garage Sale shall mean the sale of personal property from a residence, duplex, apartment or vacant lot in a residential area. The sale of personal property not in excess of five (5) items in number, provided that such items are specifically named or identified in the advertisement thereof, or the sale of personal property pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction, shall not be construed as a garage sale. 
(1957 Code § 13-41; Ord. No. 82-29 § 1 10-19-82) 
9-17.2   Conditions and Restrictions.
    Garage sales shall be permitted on the premises of residences, duplexes and apartments subject to the following conditions and restrictions: 
a.  No garage sale shall be conducted unless and until a permit shall have been obtained from the City Clerk after payment of a one ($1.00) dollar processing fee. Only the owner or lessee of the property upon which the garage sale is being conducted may obtain such permit. 
b.  Before a permit is issued, the applicant shall file an application with the City Clerk, which application shall contain the following information: 
1.  Street address where the sale is to be conducted; 
2.  Proof of ownership or lease of property; 
3.  Date(s) of sale; and 
4.  Hours of sale. 
c.  Upon verification and compliance with the provisions of this section and the payment of the fee, the City Clerk shall issue a permit which will designate the location of the sale and the days upon which such sale may be conducted. 
d.  Only personal property owned by the seller and usual to a household may be sold or offered for sale. 
e.  Only one (1) sign not exceeding three (3) feet by three (3) feet in size may be displayed on the premises where such sale is being conducted. The sign must be removed at the end of the sale. 
f.  Garage sales may be conducted between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. only. 
g.  Personal property may be exhibited or displayed only within established setbacks. 
h.  No more than two (2) consecutive days are permitted for any one (1) garage sale. 
i.  No more than two (2) garage sales may be held from the same property within any calendar year, with not more than two (2) garage sales within a thirty (30) day period. 
j.  The garage sale permit must be prominently displayed from the front of the building from which such sale is conducted. 
k.  By making application for a garage sale permit, accepting the permit and conducting such sale, the owner or lessee of the property to whom such permit is granted authorizes any Code Enforcement Officer of the City to enter upon the property for the purpose of determining that such sale is being conducted in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(1957 Code § 13-41; Ord. No. 82-29 § 1, 10-19-82) 
9-17.3   Penalty.
    Any person found guilty of violating any of the terms of this section shall be subject to a fine of up to one hundred ($100.00) dollars for each offense and denial of a permit for the one hundred twenty (120) days next following a violation. 
(1957 Code § 13-41; Ord. No. 82-29, § 1, 10-19-82) 
9-18 - SALES, REPAIR OF VEHICLES IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS-REGULATION; RESTRICTIONS, PROHIBITION. 
9-18.1   Sales of Vehicle, Automobile, Boat in Residential Areas-Regulations, Restrictions.
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell more than two (2) automobiles, vehicles, boats, vessels, watercrafts, trailers, or hitches, from a residence, duplex or apartment in a residential area within the City of North Miami Beach during a period of one (1) year. 
b.  Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred ($500.00) dollars or sixty (60) days imprisonment or both. 
(1957 Code § 13-41A; Ord. No. 90-5, 4-3-90) 
9-18.2   Repair of Automobiles, Other Vehicles in Residential Areas, Restriction, Prohibitions.
a.  It shall be unlawful to engage in the repair of any automobile or other vehicle located on public property within the City of North Miami Beach. 
b.  Repair of automobiles or other vehicles in residential areas of the City of North Miami Beach is permitted only under the following conditions: 
1.  No one shall repair or be engaged in the repairing of more than one (1) vehicle at any one (1) time. 
2.  Commercial repairs are prohibited. The residential property owner may only repair vehicles owned by himself and members of his family and must be prepared to show proof of ownership for the automobile or vehicle being repaired. 
3.  Each repair shall be completed within ten (10) days. 
4.  The repair of the vehicle shall not generate excessive noise nor hazardous fumes, gases, odors, oils or solvents. 
5.  The repair activity shall take place only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
6.  While under repair, the automobile or vehicle shall not be parked in the front yard unless the side yard or the rear yard are not accessible. 
(1957 Code § 13-35A; Ord. No. 87-1 § 2, 5-5-87) 
9-19 - BUSINESSES AND OCCUPATIONS PROHIBITED. 
9-19.1   Reserved.
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-15 , § 2, adopted Jan. 16, 2018, repealed former § 9-19.1 which pertained to drive-in or curb service restaurants prohibited, and derived from the 1957 Code, § 13-12.1; and Ord. No. 68-2, § 1, adopted Feb. 6, 1968. 
9-20 - BOAT REGULATIONS. 
9-20.1   Speed Regulated Boats; Speed, Manner of Operation.
a.  It shall be unlawful to operate any boat, vessel or other watercraft upon any waterway or body of water within the corporate limits of the City at a rate of speed which causes waves to damage docks, wharves, seawalls or boats moored or tied to docks or wharves along such waterways or bodies of water. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any boat, vessel or other watercraft under power at a speed other than at "idle speed" upon any waterway or body of water within the corporate limits of the City; except outside and beyond one hundred (100') feet of land on Maule Lake. 
(1957 Code § 13-5.1[a]; Ord. No. 62-2 §§ 1-3, 3-6-62; Ord. No. 75-21, 9-29-75; Ord. No. 89-3 § 2, 11-7-89) 
9-20.2   Careful Operation.
    It shall be illegal to operate any boat or other watercraft in any of the waters described in subsection 9-20.1 above in such a manner as to endanger life or property. 
(1957 Code § 13-5.1 [b]; Ord. No. 62-2 §§ 1-3, 3-6-62; Ord. No. 75-21 § 1, 9-29-75; Ord. No. 89-3 § 2, 11-7-89) 
9-20.3   Penalty.
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this section, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred ($500.00) dollars or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, within the discretion of the appropriate tribunal. 
(1957 Code § 13-5.1[c]; Ord. No. 62-2 §§ 1-3, 3-6-62; Ord. No. 75-21 § 1, 9-29-75; Ord. No. 89-3, § 2, 11-7-89; Ord. No. 91-14 § 2, 5-21-91) 
9-20.4   Boats, Watercrafts, Personal Watercrafts; Speed Restriction on Snake Creek Canal.
a.  No person shall operate a motorboat or personal watercraft as further defined by Florida Statutes or permit a motorboat or personal watercraft to be operated in the Snake Creek Canal Idle Speed No Wake Zone at any speed greater than Idle Speed No Wake. The Snake Creek Canal (C-9) Idle Speed No Wake Zone is hereby established to be all waters of the Snake Creek Canal (C-9) from the salinity control structure located three hundred fifty (350') feet east of U.S. #1 (also known as Biscayne Boulevard) to SR #860 (also known as Miami Gardens Drive). 
b.  The Snake Creek Canal Idle Speed No Wake Zone shall be marked on the canal with uniform waterway regulatory markers in accordance with applicable State and Federal laws and regulations. 
c.  A violation of any provision of this section shall be punished pursuant to Section 327.73, Florida Statutes. 
(1957 Code § 13-5.1A; Ord. No. 89-3 § 3, 11-7-89) 
9-21 - AIRCRAFT REGULATIONS. 
9-21.1   Minimum Altitude of Aircraft.
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an aircraft over the City at a height of less than one thousand (1,000') feet; provided however, this section shall not be applicable to any aircraft immediately taking off or landing in any airport located within or adjacent to the City; and this section shall not be applicable to any aircraft operated by any lawful governmental agency discharging chemicals in connection with a continuing mosquito control program. 
(Ord. No. 172 § 1, 12-7-48; 1957 Code § 13-2.1; Res. No. R76-50 § 1, 5-18-76; Ord. No. 81-24 § 2, 8-4-81) 
9-21.2   Helicopter Permits and Regulations.
    No helicopter shall be permitted to take off or land in the City except those helicopters used for ambulances, safety, law enforcement or other emergency purposes. Permits shall be issued to qualified applicants after investigation by the Chief of Police. A fee of one hundred ($100.00) dollars shall be paid to the City at the time the application is filed. 
(1957 Code § 13-2.2; Ord. No. 81-24 § 3, 8-4-81) 
9-21.3   Reckless Operation of Aircraft.
    It shall be unlawful for any person to recklessly operate an aircraft in any manner over the City. (1957 Code, § 13-3; Ord. No. 172, § 2, 12-7-48) 
9-21.4   Beacons Required on Structures of a Certain Height.
a.  Any temporary structure that is erected, maintained or placed anywhere in the City having a height in excess of fifty (50') feet shall contain on the top thereof a flashing three hundred (300) mm electric code beacon, each equipped with two (2) lamps and aviation-red color filters or an equivalent of twelve (12") inch flashing beacon consisting of two (2) six hundred twenty (620) watt light bulbs of two thousand (2,000) candlepower, each with a maximum of forty (40) flashes per minute, a minimum of twelve (12) flashes per minute; and shall be lit and properly operating between the hours of sunset and sunrise. 
b.  The word "structure" shall mean an object constructed, created or installed by man, such as derricks, cranes and other boom-equipped machinery and other similar equipment. 
c.  The City Manager or his designated agent and/or employee shall make every effort to obtain full compliance as to this section. 
(1957 Code § 13-3.1; Res. No. R76-77 §§ 1-3, 11-16-76) 
9-22 - RESERVED. 
9-23 - ABUSE OF FLAG, COLORS, STANDARDS, ETC. 
9-23.1   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    Flag, Standard, Color, Ensign, or Shield shall mean and include any flag, standard, color, ensign, or shield; or copy, picture, or representation thereof, made of any substance or represented or produced thereon, and of any size, evidently purporting to be such flag, standard, color, ensign or shield of the United States, or a copy, picture, or representation thereof. 
(1957 Code § 13-33; Ord. No. 71-6 § 1, 2-16-71) 
9-23.2   Offenses.
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to mutilate, deface, defile or contemptuously abuse the Flag of the United States of America. 
b.  No person shall publicly mutilate, deface, defile, trample upon, or by act cast contempt upon any such flag, standard, color, ensign or shield. 
c.  No person shall publicly mutilate, deface or trample upon, or burn with intent to insult, any flag, standard, color, or ensign of the United States. 
(1957 Code § 13-33; Ord. No. 71-6 § 2, 2-16-71) 
9-23.3   Use of Flag, etc. for Decorative or Patriotic Purposes.
    Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the use of any flag, standard, color, shield, ensign or other insignia of the United States of America for decorative or patriotic purposes. 
(1957 Code § 13-33; Ord. No. 71-6 § 3, 2-16-71) 
9-23.4   Application of Provisions.
    This section shall not apply to any act permitted by the Statutes of the United States or the State of Florida, or by the United States Army and Navy regulations, nor shall it apply to any printed or written document or production, stationery, ornament, picture or jewelry, whereon shall be depicted said flag, standard, color, ensign or shield with no design or words thereon. (1957 Code, § 13-33; Ord. No. 71-6 § 4, 2-16-71) 
9-24 - CONSUMER GOODS PRICING.[4] 
9-24.1   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    Consumer goods shall mean any article, product or commodity of any kind or class, including fruit, meat, poultry, produce and other perishable items, which is used or bought primarily for personal, family or household purposes. 
    Retail shall mean the sale or offering for sale of individual items of merchandise to the ultimate consumer or to any person for any purpose other than for resale. 
    Self-service Store shall mean any store or structure wherein merchandise is sold at retail, as defined heretofore, by a system or plan whereby said merchandise is displayed or exposed for sale on shelves, stands, platforms, counters or in bins or aisleways in such a manner that purchasers are invited and permitted to make a personal selection of the merchandise sought to be purchased and to take the same into possession, and may be provided with baskets, carts or containers in which the merchandise may be carried or carted to a counter, place or exit point, where employees or agents of those conducting the business calculate the total price of the merchandise and receive payment therefor from the customer. 
(1957 Code, § 13-71; Ord. No. 81-3, § 1, 2-3-81) 
9-24.2   Individual Prices Required.
    All self-service stores within the City of North Miami Beach shall have marked or affixed to each item of consumer goods the numerical price of said item. 
(1957 Code, § 13-72; Ord. No. 81-3, § 1, 2-3-81) 
9-24.3   Exception from Individual Price Marking Requirement.
    The following consumer goods shall not be regulated pursuant to subsection 9-24.2: 
a.  Articles specially ordered from the seller, including prescription drugs. 
b.  Fresh fruits and vegetables which are not individually wrapped or packaged. 
c.  Articles which are offered for sale according to trade custom and usage as the price per unit of weight, quantity or measure. 
(1957 Code, § 13-73; Ord. No. 81-3, § 1, 2-3-81) 
9-24.4   Integration with Subsection 9-24.2.
    All self-service stores within the City shall conspicuously and clearly display the numerical price of all consumer goods which are not regulated under subsection 9-24.2, except articles specially ordered from the seller, in close proximity thereto. 
(1957 Code, § 13-74; Ord. No. 81-3, § 1, 2-3-81)
