No. 84-16 § 2, 10-2-84; Ord. No. 86-14 § 3, 9-16-86; Ord. No. 92-1 § 2, 2-18-92; Ord. No. 2000-5, 8-1-00; Ord. No. 2004-16, 12-2-04; Ord. No. 2004-17, 11-2-04; Ord. No. 2005-1, 3-15-05; Ord. No. 2007-7 § 6-2, 9-4-0; Ord. No. 2010-18 § 2, 8-17-10) 
14-1.4   Quick Permits.
    Effective October 1, 2000, the City Manager, or designee, shall establish and make public, procedures for the issuance of permits on the spot upon application to the Building Division. Application may be in person, over the telephone, by telefax or by e-mail, as may be appropriate. Such permit types shall be building permits, electrical permits, mechanical permits and plumbing permits which the City Manager in his discretion determines are appropriately issued over the counter. 
(Ord. No. 2005 § 6-2.1, 8-1-00; Ord. No. 2007-7 § 6-2.1, 9-4-07) 
14-1.5   Same-Refunds.
    Full refunds may be granted to a permit holder whose valid permit is canceled by owner authorization where work has commenced and such owner selects a second contractor to complete the work. The second contractor shall pay a full fee unless the first contractor waives his right to a refund in writing, or if the property owner can provide proof that the first permit holder has been reimbursed for the permit fee. In that case, the second contractor is entitled to a permit to cover the same work on a no-charge basis. If the first permit expires, the second contractor shall pay a full permit fee to complete the work. 
(1957 Code § 6-3; Ord. No. 66-13 § 3, 10-18-66; Ord. No. 75-19 § 1, 8-19-75; Ord. No. 78-14 § 3, 9-19-78; Ord. No. 80-47 § 3, 9-3-80; Ord. No. 82-11 §§ 5, 6, 4-6-82) 
14-1.6   Owner-Builder Permits.
    Any natural person, whether a licensed con-tractor or not, shall be issued a permit for the construction or alteration of a building in the City of North Miami Beach under the following conditions, restrictions, and exceptions: 
a.  If for construction, the applicant owns the land and it is their primary residence and the applicant does not intend to sell, lease or rent the property for a one year period on which the construction will be made and furnishes to the Department of Community Development satisfactory proof of ownership. 
b.  If for construction, the type of building shall be limited to a single-family residence or an addition thereto; or if other than a family residence, shall be limited to an addition limited to a single story with a maximum floor area of five hundred (500) square feet. 
c.  If for construction, not more than one (1) permit shall be issued under the authority of this section to the same person in any twelve (12) month period for his own use and occupancy and not intended for sale. 
d.  If for construction, the applicant files with the Department of Community Development a survey, prepared by a registered land surveyor, of the land on which the construction will be made. 
e.  If for alteration, the applicant owns the building which is to be altered and is the sole occupant and furnishes to the Department of Community Development satisfactory proof of ownership. 
f.  If for alteration on a building other than a family residence of the applicant, the work shall be nonstructural and the cost of the work, as determined by the Department of Community Development, shall not exceed seventy-five thousand ($75,000.00) dollars. 
g.  The applicant files with the Department of Community Development two (2) copies of the plans and specifications of the construction or of the alteration. 
h.  The applicant files with the Department of Community Development a cash bond, of an amount to be determined by the Department of Community Development, for the completion of the construction or of the alteration, and for cleanup upon completion of the construction or of the alteration. 
i.  The applicant uses for any and all electrical work an electrical contractor; for any and all plumbing work, a plumbing contractor; for any and all roofing work, a roofing contractor; and the applicant does not himself do, or cause to be done, any such work by other than the appropriate licensed contractor. 
j.  The applicant uses only such contractors as are certified by the State of Florida, Miami-Dade County and furnishes to the Department of Community Development a list of all contractors to be used. 
k.  The applicant complies and shows competency with the Florida Building Code and Ordinances of the City of North Miami Beach and applies for all inspections required by the Florida Building Code and for any other inspections required by the Department of Community Development. 
l.  The applicant obtains liability insurance for the construction project or the alteration project in the amount as specified by the Florida Statutes, for property damage; and furnishes to the Department of Community Development satisfactory proof of such insurance coverage. 
m.  The applicant complies with any and all other conditions and requirements for the issuance of construction or alteration permits in the City of North Miami Beach, excepting the requirement that the applicant be a licensed contractor. 
n.  The applicant has not placed, or caused to be placed, property in his name as owner or had not occupied the premises, for the sole purpose of evading, for himself or for another, the licensing requirements for contractors in the City of North Miami Beach. 
o.  The applicant reads and properly executes an affidavit stating that he (she) is not attempting to circumvent the intent of this section. 
p.  The applicant agrees that if at any time during the construction and until a certificate of occupancy is issued for his (her) own single-family residence, the applicant decides to sell the lot and house under construction, the applicant will notify the Department of Community Development whereupon the permit will be canceled and all fees forfeited. A new permit may be issued to a new applicant upon payment of a new permit fee. 
(1957 Code § 6-4; Ord. No. 73-5 § 1, 4-3-73; Ord. No. 81-7 § 3, 3-17-81) 
14-1.7   Penalty for Violation of Subsection 14-1.6.
    Violation of any of the provisions of subsection 14-1.6, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine of five hundred ($500.00) dollars per violation and/or up to sixty (60) days imprisonment. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(1957 Code § 6-5; Ord. No. 73-5 § 2, 4-3-73; Ord. No. 81-7 § 4, 3-17-81) 
14-1.8   Permit Revocation.
    Should any permittee or permittee's agent violate any City ordinance, the City may issue a cease and desist order or revoke the building permit at the City's sole discretion. 
(1957 Code § 6-6; Ord. No. 81-13 § 2, 4-21-81) 
14-1.9   Reserved.
14-1.10   Performance Bond for Construction Required.
    Before any permits shall be issued by the Building Inspector of the City, the owner or contractor applying for the permits for construction, clearing, excavating, filling or grading of land within the City, in compliance with any of the laws of the City, the Board issuing the permit, shall require the posting of a performance bond or cash deposit by the owner or contractor, the amount of same to be determined as hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 350 § 1, 3-16-54; 1957 Code § 6-8) 
14-1.11   Amount of Bond.
    The Chief Building Inspector, or his duly authorized representative, shall consider the value of public property and improvements at the site for which the permit is to be issued, to determine and fix the amount of the performance bond or cash deposit required for the permit. The performance bond fee schedule shall be established as follows and shall become part of the appendix to the land development regulations known as the City's Land Development Fee Schedule:

14-1.12   Receipt for Deposit.
    The Chief Building Inspector or his duly authorized representative shall give the owner or contractor the receipt for any cash deposit. 
(Ord. No. 350 § 3, 3-16-54; 1957 Code § 6-10) 
14-1.13   Excessive Bond.
    If the owner or contractor shall determine that the bond or deposit so fixed by the Chief Building Inspector or his representative to be excessive, he may appeal by writing a letter to the Director of Planning and Zoning Board. 
(Ord. No. 350 § 4, 3-16-54; 1957 Code § 6-11) 
14-1.14   Return of Bond or Deposit.
    The Chief Building Inspector or his duly authorized representative shall return the bond or deposit to the owner or contractor after final inspection has been made of the site for which the permit was issued, if there has been no damage to public property or improvements, and the site has been cleared of all rubbish, construction debris, construction sheds or other undesirable materials as a result of construction, excavating, filling or grading of land. 
(Ord. No. 350 § 5, 3-16-54; 1957 Code § 6-12; Ord. No. 96-35 § 3, 6-20-95) 
14-1.15   Forfeiture of Bond or Deposit.
    In the event there has been damage to public property or improvements, or that rubbish, construction debris, construction sheds or other undesirable materials have been left at the site for which the permit is issued, then the Chief Building Inspector or his duly authorized representative, shall notify the owner or the contractor to commence correction of the above mentioned conditions within five (5) days. In the event the owner or contractor fails to make a bona fide attempt to correct the conditions caused by the issuance of the permit, the Chief Building Inspector shall be authorized to have the repairs made or undesirable materials or sheds removed, and pay for the same from the cash deposit or moneys received from the surety on the performance bond. In the event there should be a difference between the deposit and the bond remaining after such work is done, the amount unexpended shall be returned to the owner or contractor. All performance bonds which expired prior to October 19, 1988 and which remain unclaimed by the owner or contractor are considered abandoned by the owner/contractor and are hereby forfeited to the City. After October 19, 1993, the City shall publish annual notice of all expired bonds. All performance bonds which remain unclaimed by the owner or contractor for more than thirty (30) days following the published notice shall be considered abandoned and forfeited to the City. Prior to forfeiture the City shall send letter notice to the owner/contractor at the last known address. No interest shall accrue or be due on any performance bonds held by the City. Performance bonds that are claimed by the owner or contractor following publication of notice as provided herein shall be subject to a pro-rata share of administrative costs which shall be deducted by the City. 
(Ord. No. 350 § 6, 3-16-54; 1957 Code § 6-13; Ord. No. 93-9 § 2, 10-19-93; Ord. No. 95-3 § 4, 6-20-95) 
14-1.16   Type of Construction Required of All Buildings and Placement of Wire Utilities Serving such Buildings.
a.  All buildings erected within the City shall be constructed pursuant to the requirements of the Florida Building Code, as amended, its revisions and interpretations, and pursuant to all other applicable codes, and be constructed primarily of: 
b.  Reserved. 
c.  Wire utilities serving all newly constructed buildings within the City shall be underground, including electric service, telephone, cable, Internet and any others. 
d.  Those buildings constructed prior to the enactment of requirement paragraph b. above shall place all existing wire utilities, including electric service, telephone, cable, Internet and any other wire utilities, underground upon the reconstruction, renovation, addition to or other major modification to the building that comprises a construction value of a minimum of fifty (50%) percent of the value of the building as listed by the Miami-Dade County Property Appraiser's office. 
(Ord. No. 400 § 1, 12-7-54; 1957 Code § 6-14; Ord. No. 65-21 § 1, 7-20-65; Ord. No. 2005-20 § 2) 
Amendment note- Prior to amendment of § 14-1.15 by Ord. No. 65-21, § 1 said § 14-1.15 required that all structures be of concrete block construction except as otherwise provided in Ch. XXIV. 
14-1.17   Reserved. [3] 
14-1.18-14-1.21   Reserved.
14-1.22   Filling in Land; Submission of Plan.
    The owner, developer, and/or party or parties in interest shall, prior to the filling in of any land in the City, have prepared at their own expense and submit to the Building Department for its approval a topographic plan of the area involved, prepared by a Florida registered engineer or a Florida registered surveyor. Upon obtaining such approval and a permit as outlined hereafter, such owner, developer and/or party or parties in interest shall have the privilege to fill in the land, provided, however, that they shall do so in conformance with the topographic plan, and provided further, that upon completion they shall have prepared at their own expense and submit to the City Building Department a certification from a Florida registered surveyor or a Florida registered engineer that an inspection has been caused to be made, and that such fill has been placed upon the land in conformance with the topographic plan theretofore submitted. 
(Ord. No. 611 § 1, 11-20-56; 1957 Code § 6-20) 
14-1.23   Approval of Plan, Issuance of Permit.
    Such topographic plan shall be approved by the City Building Department and the City Engineer as a condition precedent to the issuance of a permit to fill said land pursuant to said plan. 
(Ord. No. 611 § 2, 11-20-56; 1957 Code § 6-21) 
14-1.24   Permit Fee.
    The fee for the issuance of such permit is hereby set at ten ($10.00) dollars and shall be issued by the City Building Department when the requirements of subsections 14-1.22 and 14-1.23 have been met. 
(Ord. No. 611 § 3, 11-20-56; 1957 Code § 6-22) 
14-1.25   Survey Required of Buildings Over Five Hundred Square Feet in Area-When Due; Required Information.
    All structures over five hundred (500) square feet in area shall be required to furnish a survey, by a licensed surveyor, to be submitted to the City Building Department immediately upon erection of any, and/or, all walls to a height of sixteen (16) inches above the crown of the road. The survey shall show the property in question and the location of existing structures, if any, and the building or buildings under construction, the proposed location of other parts or portions of the structure or structures in question which may not yet be constructed at the time the aforementioned survey is made, with the relationship of the outer walls to the property lines clearly indicated thereon, and said survey shall also show the proposed finished elevation of the finished floor or floors with relation to the grade of the road or street contiguous to the property in question. 
(Ord. No. 1018 § 1, 5-5-59; 1957 Code § 6-22.1) 
14-1.26   Prerequisite to Structural Inspection.
    No structural inspections of such buildings by the City Building Department shall be made until the survey described in subsection 5-1.19 shall have been submitted for approval by the Chief Building Inspector, or his duly authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 1018 § 2, 5-5-59; Ord. No. 69-1 § 1, 1-21-69; 1957 Code § 6-22.2) 
Amendment Note- Ord. No. 69-1, § 1, amended § 14-1.26 by substituting the word "structural" in lieu of "tie beam." 
14-1.27   Reserved.
14-1.28   Utility Cabinets, Locations; Specifications, Etc.
a.  No utility room or utility cabinet as hereinafter defined shall be constructed or altered in the City of North Miami Beach unless it conforms to the following provisions of the Code of the City of North Miami Beach. 
b.  All utility rooms or utility cabinets are hereby defined as: A secondary structure of ordinary masonry construction or prefabricated metal [provided such prefabricated cabinet has been approved by the Product Control Section of the Miami-Dade County Building and Zoning Department and the City of North Miami Beach Building Department, as conforming to the applicable sections of the Florida Building Code, as evidenced by "Notice of Acceptance" from Miami-Dade County Product Control Supervisor and Construction Control Supervisor; a label bearing the manufacturer's name and model number to be conspicuously affixed to each unit] with maximum dimensions eighty-four (84) inches in height; one hundred twenty (120) inches in depth; and one hundred twenty (120) inches in width, to be utilized for the sole purpose of housing the usual and ordinary gardening tools, supplies and equipment, etc., normally used by one-family residences in the care and tending of the grounds thereof. The structure may not be used as an accessory use, or for any purpose other than storage. 
c.  All utility rooms shall be located in the rear of the property, or side rear of the main structure; provided, however, insofar as this paragraph relates to structures located on corner lots, utility rooms will not be permitted on the side where the wall is facing the street thereof; provided, further that utility rooms shall not be installed in front or side setback areas. 
d.  Each application for a permit for such utility cabinet or utility room shall be submitted with a plot plan locating all structures, septic tank and electric service. 
e.  In the event the structure is prefabricated, two (2) sets of prints of the approved detail sheets shall be submitted with each application for permit. 
f.  In the event the structure is prefabricated, it shall be set on a four (4) inch concrete base, reinforced with six by six (6 × 6) inch ten (10) gauge wire mesh. 
g.  The rear setback requirements in relation to the location of such utility room or utility cabinet shall be five (5) feet or more from the rear property line, provided no easement exists in excess of five (5) feet. In the event such easement does exist, then the maximum setback shall be the point of distance where the easement line is furthest from the rear property line. 
(1957 Code § 6-22.4; Ord. No. 60-117; Res. No. R61-38; Res. No. R61-39 § 1, 4-4-61; Ord. No. 70-7 § 1, 7-7-70; Ord. No. 70-17 § 1, 11-17-70) 
14-1.29   Construction Prohibited on Unzoned or Unplatted Land.
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any structure or engage in any construction of any kind on any real property in the City which has not been platted and zoned. 
b.  No occupational license shall be issued by the City Clerk for the use or occupancy of any structure on land in the City which has not been platted and zoned. 
c.  The Building Department and the City Clerk may make such investigation as may be necessary to determine that the condition required by paragraph a. has been complied with prior to the issuance of a building permit or occupational license. 
d.  The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to any building or other structure erected or constructed prior to the effective date hereof nor shall the provisions of this section prohibit the issuance of any occupational license or certificate of occupation in connection with the use of any building or structure on any unplatted or unzoned lands, which building or other structure was erected prior to September 17, 1963. 
(1957 Code § 6-22.5; Ord. No. 63-18 §§ 1-3, 9-17-63; Ord. No. 63-24 § 1, 11-5-63) 
Cross reference- Zoning Ch. XXIV.

14-2 - BUILDING OFFICIAL. 
14-2.1   Office of Chief Building Official.
    There is hereby created the Office of Chief Building Official whose duty it shall be to see that all ordinances relative to the construction, alteration, repair and maintenance of buildings within the City shall be enforced. 
(Ord. No. 136 § 1, 6-3-47; 1957 Code § 6-23) 
14-2.2   Office Combined With Those of Plumbing and Electrical Inspectors.
    The Office of Building, Plumbing and Electrical Inspectors are hereby consolidated and the duties and functions of said office shall be by one (1) person, whose title shall be Chief Building Official. 
(Ord. No. 152 § 1, 2-3-48; 1957 Code § 6-24) 
14-2.3   Powers as to Abatement of Nuisances; Abatement by City.
    The Chief Building Official is authorized to examine into nuisances with regard to fire, hurricane and public health and safety hazard, and to report his findings in writing to the City Council. The Building Official is instructed to submit to the City Council proper legal descriptions of such nuisances. The findings of the Building Official shall be examined by the Council and approved or disapproved. Should the City Council find the ruinous buildings to be fire and hurricane hazards and of immediate danger to the health and welfare of adjacent persons and properties, the City Council shall instruct the City Clerk to notify the owners of the properties, by registered mail, that the buildings thereon constitute a nuisance under this section and the owner thereof shall be given sixty (60) days from the date of mailing to either repair or remove said ruinous building or buildings. At the end of the sixty (60) day period, if the owner of ruinous building or buildings has not repaired or removed the same, the City Council shall then order the ruinous building or buildings to be removed, and the cost of removal to be assessed against the property or properties upon which the ruinous building or buildings are located. 
(Ord. No. 201, 4-4-50; 1957 Code § 6-27) 
Cross reference- For offense of creating a nuisance, see § 9-1.4. 
14-2.4   Duties and Powers.
    The Chief Building Inspector shall be the field inspector and shall be charged with all duties pertinent to inspection of the construction of all buildings within the City; and shall be deputized to arrest all persons violating the building code. 
(Ord. No. 335 § 4, 9-14-53; 1957 Code § 6-28) 
14-2.5   Chief Plumbing Inspector, Qualifications, Etc.
a.  There shall be and is hereby established a job classification known as Chief Plumbing Inspector. 
    All applicants shall meet minimum standards of having a Miami-Dade County competency certificate and a current journeyman's card as a journeyman plumber and must have a Master Plumber's License for a minimum of five (5) years. 
(1957 Code § 6-28.1; Ord. No. 863 §§ 1-3, 5-27-58; Ord. No. 1038 § 1, 6-9-59) 
14-2.6   Digging of Rock Pits Prohibited; Definitions.
a.  Definition. As used in this chapter: 
    Rock pit shall mean any place from which either rock or natural growth has been removed, making or causing a depression where none formerly existed and which depression, excavation or digging or sinking of wells or other necessary excavations in connection with construction or maintenance of improvements on land. 
b.  Excavations Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to dig, excavate or create rock pits within the City limits. 
(Ord. No. 49 § 1; 1957 Code § 6-29) 
c.  Exceptions. The provisions of paragraphs a. and b. do not apply in cases of digging or excavating in connection with wells or the construction or maintenance of improvements on land within the City limits, where a permit has first been obtained as required by the City. 
(Ord. No. 49 § 2; 1957 Code § 6-30) 
14-3 - STRUCTURE-MOVING REGULATIONS.[4] 
14-3.1   Permits Required.
    It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, business or corporation to move any structure, whether same be residential, business or of any other category, from without the City limits to any circumscribed area within the City, nor from one (1) area lying within the City to any other circumscribed area lying within the City, without first obtaining a structure-moving permit from the Building Inspector and making payment of the fee required by subsection 14-3.7. 
(1957 Code § 6-31; Ord. No. 61-34 § 2, 11-21-61) 
14-3.2   Conditions Precedent to Issuance of Structure-Moving Permit.
    As a condition precedent to the issuance of such a permit as aforesaid, the applicant shall submit with his application the following information: 
a.  The floor plan and photographs of the existing structure. 
b.  Plot plans for the new location. 
c.  A drawing of proposed architectural treatment. 
d.  An authorization to the Building Department of the City to inspect the plumbing, electrical and general construction of the structure. 
e.  An authorization to an inspection committee composed of the Building Official, the City Manager, and a member of the City Council (the latter to be designated by the president of the Council as each occasion arises), to examine the structure to insure that same shall fit in with its new surroundings. 
(1957 Code § 6-32; Ord. No. 61-34 § 2, 11-21-61) 
14-3.3   Duties of Building Official and Inspection Committee in Relation to This Section.
    It shall be the duty of the Building Official upon the filing of such application for a structure-moving permit to examine such floor plan and photographs of the existing structure, plot plans for the new location and drawing of the proposed architectural treatment; to make a plumbing, electrical and general construction inspection; and, if it appears that the proposed structure is in compliance with the building and zoning requirements as set out in the Code, and all other laws and ordinances of the City, he shall then submit his findings to the Inspection Committee as provided for hereinabove; and, if the recommendations of the Building Official and a majority of the Inspection Committee concur the permit shall be issued. Thereupon, the Building Official shall issue the structure-moving permit to which there shall be attached the conditions of improvement, if any, which the Building Official and the Inspection Committee shall have recommended. 
(1957 Code § 6-33; Ord. No. 61-34 § 2, 11-21-61) 
14-3.4   Bond Requirements.
    Every applicant for a permit shall, before the permit is granted, file with the Building Official a continuing bond in the penal sum of one thousand ($1,000.00) dollars executed by the applicant and a surety company to be approved by the City Attorney, and conditioned for the faithful observance of the provisions of this section and all amendments thereto, and of all laws and ordinances relative to removal of structures as aforesaid, and which shall indemnify and save harmless the City from any and all damages, judgments, costs or expenses which the City may incur or suffer by reason of the granting of said permit. 
(1957 Code § 6-34; Ord. No. 61-34 § 2, 11-21-61) 
14-3.5   Insurance Requirements.
    A liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State of Florida to protect the City from liability for any damage incurred to third parties while in transit operations shall be submitted to the Building Official by applicant prior to issuance of any permit. 
(1957 Code § 6-35; Ord. No. 61-34 § 2, 11-21-6) 
14-3.6   Occupancy Permit.
    In the event that a structure-moving permit has been granted and the structure has been removed to the new site, it shall not be occupied unless and until there shall have been issued to the original applicant an occupancy permit. The Building Official shall not issue such occupancy permit until he and the Inspection Committee shall have first concurred that there has been fulfillment and compliance with all of the recommendations, if any, of the Committee and the Building Official, and that the structure is in full compliance with all of the applicable ordinances, laws, rules and regulations of the City. 
(1957 Code § 6-36; Ord. No. 61-34 § 2, 11-21-61) 
14-3.7   Permit Fees.
    An applicant, upon being granted a structure-moving permit hereunder, shall pay to the City Clerk the permit fees as are now outlined and required by the Code. 
(Ord. No. 61-34 § 2, 11-21-61; 1957 Code § 6-37) 
14-3.8   Revocation of Permits.
    The Building Official is authorized and empowered to revoke any permit issued by him upon failure of the holder thereof to comply with any provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 61-34 § 2, 11-21-61; 1957 Code § 6-37.1) 
14-3.9   Penalties.
    Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon being convicted thereof shall be fined a sum not exceeding two hundred fifty ($250.00) dollars or by imprisonment in the City Jail not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day such violation is committed, or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 61-34 § 2, 11-21-61; 1957 Code § 6-37.2) 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- As to charges for moving structures, see § 14-1.2. 

14-4 - SWIMMING POOLS. 
14-4.1   Application of Building Code.
    All matters appertaining to swimming pools and construction shall be governed by Chapter 41 of the Florida Residential Code and the Florida State Statutes as heretofore adopted by the City, [5] with the exception of those matters which are in conflict with the following provisions herein or which have not been dealt within the Florida Building Code. 
(1957 Code § 6-38; Res. No. R61-30 § 1, 4-4-61) 
14-4.2   Special-Type Pools.
    Any container installed, constructed, made or fabricated of any materials whatsoever which is designed for or capable of holding water of more than twenty-three (23) inches in depth, having a total capacity in excess of two hundred (200) but less than eight hundred (800) cubic feet of water, shall for the purposes of this section, be considered to be a "special-type" swimming pool, subject only to the requirements prescribed in subsections 14-4.3, 14-4.4, and 14-4.5. However, final approval shall be first obtained from the Building Department of the City with reference to such swimming pool structure as to location and installation procedures and requirements. 
(1957 Code § 6-39; Res. No. R61-30 § 2, 4-4-61) 
14-4.3   Safety Requirements.
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of any property situated within the City limits to construct or maintain a swimming pool which does not meet with the safety requirements hereinafter set out: 
a.  Safety Barrier Required. No swimming pool shall be installed, constructed, reconstructed or structurally altered unless there is erected a safety barrier as hereinafter provided. 
b.  Material of Safety Barrier. The safety barrier shall take the form of a wooden fence, a wire fence, a rock wall, a concrete block wall, or other materials so as to enable the owner to blend the same with the style of architecture planned or in existence on the property, screened-in patio, as defined in subsection 14-4.6 shall be considered to be a required safety barrier. 
c.  Height and Location of Barrier. The minimum height of the safety barrier shall be not less than four (4) feet. The safety barrier shall be erected around the swimming pool or around the premises on which the swimming pool is erected. In either event, it shall enclose the area entirely, prohibiting unrestrained admittance to the enclosed area. 
d.  Gates Generally. Gates shall be of the spring lock type, so that they shall automatically be in a closed position at all times. 
e.  Safety Locks for Gates. Gates shall also be equipped with a safety lock and shall be locked when the swimming pool is not in use. 
f.  Fence to be Nonclimbable. In the wooden type fence, the boards, pickets, louvers or other such members shall be spaced, constructed and erected so as to make the fence nonclimbable and impenetrable. 
g.  Walls to be Nonclimbable; Broken Glass, Etc., Not to be Used. Walls, whether of rock or block type, shall be so erected to make them nonclimbable; provided, however, broken glass or other sharp materials shall not be used in the wall. 
h.  Wire fences. Wire fences shall be the two (2) inch chain link or diamond weave nonclimbable type, or of an approved equal, with top rail. They shall be of a heavy, galvanized material. Barbed wire shall not be used. 
i.  Existing Barriers. If the premises where the swimming pool is located or to be installed is already enclosed in substantial conformity with paragraphs a. through h. above, it shall not be necessary to erect any additional safety barriers around the pool; however, the plans submitted shall show existing enclosure in detail and in the event the Building Official finds, upon actual inspection, that the enclosure is not adequate to prevent small children from gaining access to the pool, the plans shall be revised to provide an adequate barrier before a permit shall be issued. 
j.  Maintenance of Premises. It shall be the responsibility of both the owner and the occupant (if different from the owner) of the premises upon which the swimming pool is located to maintain the same swimming pool so that the water shall be clean and nonstagnant and the water clarity shall be of a level to allow clear visibility from water surface to the pool bottom and to maintain the swimming pool and the safety devices required by this section in good and safe condition at all times. 
k.  Use of Pool after Sundown. It shall be unlawful for any person to be in the swimming pool after sundown or for any owner of any property to allow a swimming pool to be used after sundown, unless there are adequate lighting facilities, both within and without the pool, as meet with the requirements of the City Building Inspector. 
l.  Compliance. No swimming pool may hereafter be maintained or installed in violation of any of the provisions contained in this section. 
(1957 Code § 6-40; Res. No. R61-30 § 3, 4-4-61; Ord. No. 86-9 § 2, 7-14-86) 
14-4.4   Noncompliance.
    If at any time the Building Official finds that any swimming pool hereafter installed, constructed, reconstructed or structurally altered does not comply with the safety requirements prescribed in subsection 14-4.3, it shall be his duty to either refuse a permit therefor or to withhold certificate of approval thereof, and, if necessary, to revoke a permit or certificate of approval previously issued; and, if installation or construction thereof continues or is completed or if such pool is used or water kept therein, the Building Official shall cause a warrant to be issued for the arrest and prosecution of the owner (and the applicant, if different from the owner) under the penalty provisions of this Code. 
(1957 Code § 6-41; Res. No. R61-30 § 4, 4-4-61) 
14-4.5   Height of Fences.
    All fences separating corner property from City streets on two (2) sides of the property henceforth shall be four (4) feet in height on such corner lots, both front and side fences. Specifically, all corner lots on which a swimming pool is to be constructed shall comply strictly with the provisions of this section. 
(1957 Code § 6-44; Res. No. R61-30 § 7, 4-4-61) 
14-4.6   Permit Fees.
    The Building Department shall charge and collect for permits at the rates as set forth in subsection 14-1.2 a, 1, 9 and 12. 
(1957 Code § 6-45; Res. No. R61-30 § 8, 4-4-61) 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- See § 14-1.1. 

14-5 - HOUSE TRAILERS AND AUXILIARY BUILDINGS, HOUSEBOATS AND TENTS.[6] 
14-5.1   General Prohibitions and Restrictions; Recreational and Camping Equipment.
    No mobile residence shall be parked in any area of the City other than camps or parks officially designated for such use, except temporarily during daylight hours in accordance with traffic laws. Minimum lot area per trailer shall be two thousand four hundred (2,400) square feet. Cottages in trailer parks shall conform to the above requirements and shall have not less than four hundred (400) square feet of floor area for single-family use, and three hundred (300) square feet for each unit in multiple-family use buildings. No houseboat which is not propelled by its own power shall be permitted to fasten to a dock, or to anchor, or to remain in any waterway in the City. It shall be unlawful to live aboard any type of watercraft within the corporate limits of the City for more than seven (7) consecutive days at one (1) time or for more than a total of twenty (20) days per year unless the watercraft is connected or harbored at a facility having proper sanitary sewage and trash disposal. Further, the owner(s), tenant(s) or user(s) of the watercraft must submit a notarized affidavit stating that such owner(s), tenant(s) or user(s) shall comply with all rules and regulations of the facility regarding the use of the sanitary sewage and trash facilities. Pleasure boats whether private or for hire may use approved wharves or docks by complying with the City ordinances. 
a.  Recreational and Camping Equipment. Recreational and camping equipment in the form of travel and camping trailer, truck camper, recreation vehicle and motor travel home, designed and used as temporary living quarters for recreation, camping or travel use, shall only be parked in the open on sites containing a single-family or duplex residence, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Not more than one (1) such equipment shall be parked on such site. 
2.  Such parking shall be limited to such equipment owned or leased by the occupant-owner or occupant-lessee of the site concerned, or owned or leased by a bona fide out-of-Dade-County house guest of the occupant-owner or occupant-lessee of the site concerned, with the parking of such equipment by the guest not to exceed fourteen (14) days. 
3.  The location for such parked equipment shall be in the rear yard or in the side yard to the rear of a line established by the front building line furthest from the street and set back to at least the rear building line wherever possible, but in no event in front of such front building line. Such equipment shall be set back from side property lines at least a distance equivalent to the required side setback for the principal building and shall be set back from the rear property line at least ten (10) feet where no alley exists. 
4.  Such equipment and the area of parking shall be maintained in a clean, neat, and presentable manner, and the equipment shall be in a usable condition at all times. 
5.  Such equipment shall, at all times, have attached a current vehicle registration license plate, and, if required, a current inspection sticker. 
6.  No major repairs or overhaul work on such equipment shall be made or performed on the site (or any other work performed thereon which would constitute a nuisance under existing ordinances). 
7.  When parked on the site, such equipment shall not be used for living or sleeping quarters, or for housekeeping or storage purposes, and shall not have attached thereto any service connection lines, except as may periodically be required to maintain the equipment and appliances. 
8.  Such equipment shall not exceed the maximum length, width, height, and weight permitted under applicable provisions of the motor vehicle laws of the State of Florida; provided, however, the maximum length shall not exceed thirty (30) feet and the maximum height shall not exceed twelve (12) feet. 
9.  Such equipment shall be so secured so that it will not be a hazard or menace during high winds or hurricane. 
10.  A seller (dealer or individual) offering for sale such new or used equipment, must furnish and attach to such equipment a true copy of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 186 § 3, 5-3-49; 1957 Code § 6-49; Ord. No. 68-23 § 1, 9-3-68; Ord. No. 68-32 §§ 1, 2, 10-3-68; Ord. No. 81-5 § 2, 2-17-81; Ord. No. 86-3 § 2, 3-18-86; Ord. No. 90-23 § 2, 10-16-90) 
14-5.2   Securing Trailer to Ground Required.
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any lot, tract or parcel of land, unoccupied as well as occupied, in the City, maintain or permit to remain thereon any trailers, auxiliary buildings, outbuildings, accessory buildings and like structures, which are not secured adequately to the ground. 
(Ord. No. 273 § 1; 1957 Code § 6-50) 
14-5.3   Removal of Unsecured Structures.
    It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any lot, tract or parcel of land, unoccupied as well as occupied, in the City, to remove from such lot, tract or parcel of land, any trailers, auxiliary buildings, outbuildings, accessory buildings and like structures, which are not securely attached to the ground. 
(Ord. No. 273 § 2; 1957 Code § 6-51) 
14-5.4   Notice to Remove Unsecured Structures.
    If, after due notice to the owner or occupant of any lot, tract or parcel of land in the City from the City Building Official, such owner or occupant shall fail, refuse or neglect to remove therefrom such trailers, auxiliary buildings, outbuildings, accessory buildings and like structures, then such owner or occupant shall be served with a thirty (30) day notice in writing by the City Building Official, directing such owner and/or occupant, as the case may be, to abate the nuisances existing on the real estate by reason of any trailers, auxiliary buildings, outbuildings, accessory buildings and like structures not securely fastened to the ground. 
(Ord. No. 273 § 4; 1957 Code § 6-52) 
14-5.5   Failure to Abate Nuisance; Abatement by City, Costs.
    If, within the thirty (30) days, the owner or occupant should fail, refuse or neglect to abate the nuisance, the City may undertake to abate the same through the use of its own personnel, facilities, or equipment, or the City may contract with an independent contractor or contractors to do the work and cause the nuisance to be abated, and in either event the costs incurred by the City to accomplish the abatement of the nuisance shall be assessed against and be a lien upon the lot, tract, or parcel of land where the nuisance existed. 
(Ord. No. 273 § 5; 1957 Code § 6-53) 
Cross reference- Offense of creating a nuisance, § 9-1.4. 
14-5.6   Method of Service.
    Service upon the owner and/or occupant of the thirty (30) day notice hereinbefore provided for shall either be by personal service or by mailing the notice to the addressee's last known address as the same appears on the records of the City. In the event the lot, tract, or parcel of land is unoccupied and the address of the owner is unknown, service of the notice shall be made upon the owner by posting the same on such lot, tract, or parcel of land. 
(Ord. No. 273 § 6; 1957 Code § 6-54) 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- See also "Places of Public Assemblage," Section 12-21. 

14-6 - BOILER INSPECTION. 
14-6.1   Inspection of Boilers Required Annually.
    All steam boilers and other pressure vessels operating under a pressure of fifteen (15) pounds or over per square inch for any purpose within the City together with their settings and safety appliances shall be inspected internally once a year and externally with the same frequency by the Mechanical Inspector who shall pass on their safety and have power to order the owner, person, or user to have same replaced, repaired or reset if found in an unsafe condition and a menace to life and property. 
(1957 Code § 6-73; Ord. No. 942 § 1, 11-25-58) 
14-6.2   Inspection Fees; Additional Examination, Charges; Waiver of Fee.
a.  The fee for each internal inspection shall be ten ($10.00) dollars annually and for each external inspection five ($5.00) dollars annually. 
b.  The Mechanical Inspector may make examinations and inspections at other times than above stated if he deems necessary, but no charge shall be made for such additional inspections unless they are made upon request of the owner or user. 
c.  The inspection fees shall be waived by the City as fixed by this subsection upon the filing of an inspection report of an insurance company inspector who has a commission issued by the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors, or who otherwise has been certified satisfactorily to the City boiler inspector. 
(1957 Code § 6-74; Ord. No. 942 § 1, 11-25-58) 
14-6.3   Exceptions to Effect of Section.
    This section shall not apply to the following objects: 
a.  Boilers or unfired pressure vessels under Federal control. 
b.  Hot water heating boilers carrying a pressure of not more than thirty (30) pounds per square inch, provided they are built and installed in accordance with A.S.M.E. Code requirements. 
c.  Boilers and unfired pressure vessels located in private residences. 
d.  Air tanks installed on right-of-way of railroads and used directly in the operation of trains. 
e.  Unfired pressure vessels for containing only water under pressure for domestic supply including those containing air, the compression of which serves only as a cushion or in air-lift pumping systems. 
f.  Unfired pressure vessels for flammable liquids and/or gases at a temperature of over three hundred (300o F) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(1957 Code § 6-75; Ord. No. 942 § 1, 11-25-58) 
14-6.4   New Installations or Re-installation Must Conform to Regulations.
    No new steam boilers or other pressure vessels, which have not been previously operated in this City shall be installed in the City unless they conform with and to the rules and regulations pursuant to this section, or to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (A.S.M.E.) Boiler Construction Code, current edition. A permit shall be obtained on forms furnished by the City to make new installations or re-installations of boilers or other pressure vessels. 
(1957 Code § 6-76; Ord. No. 942 § 1, 11-25-58) 
14-6.5   Time of Inspections.
a.  On and after sixty (60) days from November 25, 1958, each boiler or other pressure vessel used or proposed to be used within the City shall be thoroughly inspected internally and externally while not under pressure by the boiler inspector or by one (1) of the authorized insurance companies inspectors, provided for herein, as to its design, constructions, installation, condition and operation. 
b.  If at any time a hydrostatic test shall be deemed necessary to determine the safety of a boiler, same shall be made at the discretion of the inspector, by the owner or user thereof. 
c.  Not more than twelve (12) months shall elapse between internal inspections, and external inspections shall also be made at no greater intervals. 
d.  Provided, that boilers or other pressure vessels that are regularly inspected by companies authorized to inspect and insure boilers in the City shall be relieved of duplicate inspections on the part of the City, and the owners or users thereof from payment of the inspection fees as provided for in this section. Each such insurance company shall, within thirty (30) days after making an internal inspection, file a copy of its inspection report with the boiler inspector, upon appropriate forms as promulgated by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. 
(1957 Code § 6-77; Ord. No. 942 § 1, 11-25-58) 
14-6.6   Report to be Made by Companies Making Internal Inspections.
    Each company authorized to inspect and insure boilers in the City shall within thirty (30) days after making an internal inspection, file a copy of its inspection report with the boiler inspector, upon appropriate forms as promulgated by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. 
(1957 Code § 6-78; Ord. No. 942 § 1, 11-25-58) 
14-6.7   Certificate, Fee, Issuance, Duration; Disposition of Fees.
a.  If a boiler or other pressure vessel shall, upon inspection, be found to be suitable and to conform to the rules and regulations formulated or adopted by the City boiler inspector or to the A.S.M.E. Code, the owner or user of such boiler or other pressure vessel, shall pay directly to the City two ($2.00) dollars. 
b.  Whereupon the boiler inspector of the City shall issue to such owner or user an inspection certificate specifying the maximum pressure which the boiler or other pressure vessel may be allowed to carry. 
c.  Such certificate shall be valid for not more than twelve (12) months from the date of inspection and shall be posted under glass in the boiler room or the room in which the pressure vessel is installed. 
d.  Insurance companies shall also give the boiler inspector notice within thirty (30) days of a new business, rejections and cancellations. 
e.  All fees collected under the provisions of this section shall be paid into the general fund of the City. 
(1957 Code § 6-79; Ord. No. 942 § 1, 11-25-58) 
14-7 - SEWERS.[7] 
14-7.1   Sewers Connections Mandatory.
a.  When application is made to permit construction of any residence, or any other building or structure in which sanitary facilities are provided or required by law or regulation of any governmental agency, it shall be mandatory that applicant and/or owner agrees to disconnect from the sanitary sewer system serving the building and connect into the City's sewer system, when the sanitary sewer system facilities become available to the residence or other building or structure. Such connection shall be made within thirty (30) days of notice to the applicant and/or owner that the facilities are available. 
b.  The cost of disconnecting from the sewer system serving the building, and connecting into the City's sewer system, shall be borne by the applicant and/or owner. 
(1957 Code § 6-91; Ord. No. 69-14 §§ 1, 2, 8-7-69) 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Sewer rate table, § 19-30. 

14-8 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT OF BUILDING, PLANNING AND ZONING REGULATIONS. 
14-8.1   Authority of Building Official.
a.  The Building Official, under the supervision of the City Manager or department head duly delegated and appointed by the City Manager, shall administer and enforce Chapter XXIV of the Code of Ordinances, the Building Code, the Planning and Zoning Code, and the Zoning Plan of the City of North Miami Beach. He may be provided with the assistance of such other officers and employees of the City as the City Manager may direct and may utilize the procedures of the Code Enforcement Board as set forth herein. 
    The Building Official shall have the power to enter and inspect all housing units under construction or repair, including single family, duplex, and multi-family dwellings, as well as all commercial properties, to determine compliance therein with the provisions of the Code of Ordinances of the City of North Miami Beach, with the Florida Building Code, and with the Miami-Dade County Minimum Housing Standard Ordinance, pursuant to relevant law. 
b.  If the Building Official shall find that any of the provision of Chapter XXIV, Zoning, of the Code of Ordinances, the Building Code, the Planning and Zoning Code, and the Zoning Plan of the City of North Miami Beach, including, but not limited to, all pertinent resolutions and conditions or provisions of variances heretofore or hereafter granted by the City Council or the Planning and Zoning Board, and agreements or assurances made by applicants for such variances are being violated, he shall notify the person responsible for such violations, in writing, indicating the nature of the violation and ordering the action necessary to correct it. He shall order discontinuance of illegal use of land, buildings or structures, removal of illegal buildings or structures or of additions, alterations or structural changes thereto, discontinuance of any illegal work being done, or shall take any other action authorized by Chapter XXIV, Zoning, of the Code of Ordinances, this section, the Building Code, the Planning and Zoning Code, or the Zoning Plan of the City of North Miami Beach, to ensure compliance with or to prevent violation of their provisions. 
c.  The Code Enforcement Officers of the Department of Community Development shall inspect each unit of any multi-family residential building being prepared for sale as condominium units instead of rental units with the exception of duplex buildings. Each unit shall comply with the provisions of Chapter 17 of the Miami-Dade County Code of Ordinances and Chapter XIV, Building and Housing, of the Code of Ordinances of the City of North Miami Beach. If any conflict appears between the two, the highest standard established shall govern. 
d.  Any violation of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 21(12) of the City Charter. Failure to obtain inspection for each unit shall constitute a separate offense. 
(1957 Code § 6-101; Ord. No. 69-32 § 1(A), 1-20-70; Ord. No. 80-22 § 2, 4-14-80; Ord. No. 80-43 § 3, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 92-9 § 3) 
14-8.2   Scope of Building Permit Requirements; Issuance Regulated; Effect of Issuance.
a.  No building or other structure shall be erected, moved, added to, or structurally altered without a permit therefor, issued by the Building Official. No building permit shall be issued except in conformity with the provisions of Chapter XXIV, Zoning, of the Code of Ordinances, the Building Code, the Planning and Zoning Code, and the Zoning Plan of the City of North Miami Beach, except as directed by the Planning and Zoning Board or the City Council. 
b.  The issuance of a permit upon plans and specifications shall not prevent the Building Official from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in said plans and specifications or preventing the building operations being carried on thereunder when in violation of this section, or any City ordinance. 
c.  No building permit shall be issued for any addition or alteration to a single family home which would obviously function independently of the main residence. 
(1957 Code § 6-102; Ord. No. 69-32 § 1(B), 1-20-70; Ord. No. 92-9 § 4) 
14-8.3   Certificate of Occupancy for Nonconforming Structures.
a.  No nonconforming structure or use shall be maintained, renewed, changed, or extended until a certificate of occupancy shall have been issued by the Building Official. The certificate of occupancy shall state specifically wherein the nonconforming use differs from the provisions of Chapter XXIV, Zoning, of the Code of Ordinances, the Building Code, the Planning and Zoning Code, and Zoning Plan of the City of North Miami Beach, which may have been passed subsequent to the establishment of such nonconforming use; provided, that upon enactment or amendment of this section, owners or occupants of nonconforming uses or structures shall have fifteen (15) days from receipt of notice by the Building Official of the provisions of this section, and the manner in which the use fails to comply, to apply for certificates of occupancy. Failure to make such application within fifteen (15) days from receipt of the afore described notice by the Building Official shall be presumptive evidence that the property was in conforming use at the time of enactment or amendment of this section or the above-described ordinances. Failure to obtain a certificate of occupancy shall be deemed a violation of this section. 
b.  Any person, firm, or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of Chapter XXIV, Zoning, of the Code of Ordinances, the Building Code, the Planning and Zoning Code, and Zoning Plan of the City of North Miami Beach shall be fined not more than five hundred ($500.00) dollars or shall be imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days, or both, in the discretion of the County court. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist after notice shall constitute a separate offense. 
(1957 Code § 6-102.1; Ord. No. 78-11 §§ 1, 2, 6-20-78) 
14-8.4   Application for Site or Use Approval from Appropriate Department, Board or City Council; Submission, Accompanying Data Prescribed.
a.  Whenever approval for construction or use of property within the City is required under the provisions of Chapter XXIV, Zoning, of the Code of Ordinances, the Building Code, the Planning and Zoning Code, and the Zoning Plan of the City of North Miami Beach an application shall be made therefor to the body required under such provisions through the Building Department or City Clerk, and shall be accompanied by seven (7) copies of a plot or site plan, drawn to such scale as may be determined by the Building Department, showing, with dimensions, the lot lines, the building or buildings, the location of the buildings on the lot, and such other information as may be necessary to provide for the enforcement of the pertinent ordinances and regulations, including, if necessary in the opinion of the Building Official, a boundary survey and a staking of the lot by a competent surveyor and complete construction plans. The drawings shall contain suitable notations, indicating the proposed use of all land and buildings, and shall be submitted to the applicable Department, Board or City Council of the City. 
b.  No building permit or business tax receipt shall be issued for any construction or use requiring such approval until such approval has been properly obtained from the Department, Board or City Council required pursuant to the provisions of the laws of the City of North Miami Beach. 
c.  A careful record of the original copy of such application and plot or site plans shall be kept by the Building Department and a duplicate copy shall be kept at the building at all times during construction. 
(1957 Code § 6-103; Ord. No. 69-32 § 1(C), 1-20-70) 
14-8.5   Application for Building Permit; Submission, Accompanying Data Prescribed.
All  applications for building permits for any structure and its accessory buildings shall be accompanied by two (2) sets of mechanically reproduced drawings, at a convenient scale, showing the following: 
a.  The actual dimensions and shape of the lot or lots to be built upon, including the location and actual boundaries of abutting watercourses and water bodies. 
b.  The exact sizes and locations on the lot of buildings already existing, if any. 
c.  The location and dimensions of the proposed buildings or alterations. 
d.  The location and layout of the proposed sewage disposal system. 
e.  When applicable, the required parking space, loading and unloading spaces, maneuvering space and openings for ingress and egress; and landscaping for vehicular use areas or off-street parking areas. 
f.  When applicable, grading and drainage plans showing any and all cuts, fills and provisions for adequately carrying off surface water on premises plus provisions for any surface water which would naturally flow over or through the area. Such plans shall be reviewed and approved by the Building Department, and, in the case of commercial, industrial, multiple family or hotel construction, the approval of the Public Works Department of the City, and any and all other departments of the City which may be affected by such use. 
g.  Such other information as lawfully may be required by the Building Official, including existing or proposed building or alteration, existing or proposed uses of the building and land, the number of families, housekeeping units or rental units the building is designed to accommodate, conditions existing on the lot, and such other matters as may be necessary to determine conformance with, and provide for the enforcement of, this section. 
h.  For buildings and/or structures, alterations, repairs or improvements, replacements and additions, shall be prepared in accordance with the Florida Building Code and Florida Statutes, the Chief Building Official may require that plans be prepared by and bear the seal of a registered professional engineer, regardless of the cost of such work. 
i.  Plans for work which is preponderantly of architectural nature shall be prepared by and bear the seal of a registered architect, and such work which involves extensive computation based on structural stresses shall, in addition, bear the seal of a registered professional engineer. 
Plans for work in which definite mechanical or electrical problems are involved shall, at the discretion of the Building Official, be prepared by and bear the seal of a registered professional engineer. 
j.  Plans for work which are preponderantly of a structural nature shall be prepared by and bear the seal of a registered professional engineer. 
k.  Plans shall be mechanically reproduced prints on substantial paper or approved electronic media showing completely all foundations, wall sections, floor plans, roof plans and elevations at a convenient scale, and the main details at a scale not less than one-quarters (1/4) inch equals one (1) foot, together with the use or occupancy of all parts of the building, a plot and site plan showing all occupied and unoccupied portions of the lot or lots, and complete structural, mechanical, plumbing and electrical plans, and such other reasonable information as may be required to clearly show the nature, character and location of the proposed work. Computations, stress diagrams, shop drawings, results of site tests, floor plans of existing buildings to which additions are proposed and other data necessary to show compliance with Chapter XXIV, Zoning, of the Code of Ordinances, the Building Code, the Planning and Zoning Code, and the Zoning Plan of the City of North Miami Beach, including, but not limited to, all pertinent resolutions and conditions or provisions of variances which may have been granted in regard to such proposed construction, and agreements or assurances made by applicants for such variances, the correctness of the plans and the sufficiency of structural and mechanical design, shall be included when required by the Building Official. 
Any specifications in which general expressions are used to the effect that "work shall be done in accordance with the Building Code" or "to the satisfaction of the Building Official" shall be deemed imperfect and incomplete, and every reference to the Florida Building Code shall be by section or subsection number applicable to the materials to be used, or to the methods of construction proposed. Plans shall be adequately identified. 
l.  Application for permit for new construction and additions shall be accompanied by a registered land surveyor's certificate and plan in duplicate on which shall be clearly indicated the property corner stakes, property line dimensions, existing structures and their location, existing right-of-way, sidewalks, easements, street zoning and property zoning of record, critical elevations and building setbacks required by law, general block plan and other pertinent survey data which may be required. The Building Official may waive the requirements for such survey when property line stakes are existing and known to be in place, and the work involved is minor and/or is clearly within building lines. 
m.  The Building Official may authorize the issuance of a permit without plans and specifications for small or unimportant work, but in no instance where the work is of a structural nature. 
n.  One (1) copy of the plans shall be returned to the applicant by the Building Official, after he shall have marked such copy either as approved or disapproved and attested same by his signature on such copy. A careful record of the original copy of such plans, similarly marked, shall be retained by the Building Inspector, and a duplicate copy shall be kept at the building at all times during construction. 
(1957 Code § 6-104; Ord. No. 69-32 § 1(D), 1-20-70) 
14-8.6   Temporary Conditional Permit for Partial Occupancy; Issuance, Duration, Restrictions.
    A temporary conditional permit for partial occupancy of a building may be issued by the City Manager, upon a recommendation of the Building Department, for a period not exceeding six (6) months during alterations or final completion of a building pending its completion, provided that such temporary permit may require such conditions and safeguards as will protect the safety of the occupants and the public. 
(1957 Code § 6-105; Ord. No. 69-32 § 1(E), 1-20-70) 
14-8.7   Expiration of Building Permit.
a.  If the work described in any building permit has not begun within one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of issuance thereof, said permit shall expire; it shall be canceled by the Building Official and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected. 
(Ord. No. 69-32 § 1(G), 1-20-70; 1957 Code § 6-107) 
14-8.8   Construction and Use to Conform to Applications, Plans, Permits and Certificates of Occupancy.
    Building permits or certificates of occupancy issued on the basis of plans and applications approved by the Building Official, or upon variance duly and regularly granted, authorize only the use, arrangement and construction set forth in such approved plans and applications and, if on variance, according to such provisions, limitations or conditions of such variance, and assurances and agreements of the applicant, and no other use, arrangement or construction. Use, arrangement or construction at variance with that authorized shall be deemed a violation of this section. 
(1957 Code § 6-108; Ord. No. 69-32, § 1(H), 1-20-70) 
14-8.9   Complaints Regarding Violations.
    Whenever a violation of this section occurs, or is alleged to have occurred, any person may file a written complaint. Such complaint, stating fully the causes and basis thereof, shall be filed with the Building Official in such form as he may require, including, but not limited to, requiring affidavits from the complainant, and other substantiating affidavits or documents as he may reasonably require. The Building Official shall record properly such complaint, immediately investigate, and take action thereon as provided by this section. 
(1957 Code § 6-109; Ord. No. 69-32 § 1(I), 1-20-70) 
14-8.10   Penalties for Violations.
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of Chapter XXIV, Zoning, the Building Code, the Planning and Zoning Code, and Zoning Plan of the City of North Miami Beach, shall be fined not more than five hundred ($500.00) dollars or shall be imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days, or both, in the discretion of the appropriate tribunal. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist after notice shall constitute a separate offense. 
(1957 Code § 6-110; Ord. No. 69-32 § 1(J), 1-20-70; Ord. No. 91-7 § 2, 3-5-91) 
14-8.11   Code Inspector Defined.
    "Code Inspector" shall mean the Code Enforcement Officer, Building Official, Building Inspector and Director of Community Development of the City of North Miami Beach, whose duty it is to ensure code compliance. 
(1957 Code § 6-111; Ord. No. 80-43 § 4, 9-16-80) 
14-8.12   Minimum Housing Enforcement Officer.
    The Chief Code Enforcement Officer of the City of North Miami Beach, together with his assistants, is hereby designated as the Minimum Housing Enforcement Officer for the City of North Miami Beach pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 17 of the Miami-Dade County Code of Ordinances, and shall have the full authority and responsibility established therein. The authority provided herein is in addition to all other remedies provided in the North Miami Beach Code of Ordinances for the enforcement of any and all housing standards created by the North Miami Beach Code of Ordinances, the Florida Building Code, the Miami-Dade County Code or the Laws of the State of Florida. 
(Ord. No. 92-9 § 6; 1957 Code § 6-111.1) 
14-8.13   Code Enforcement Board; Organization; Special Magistrates.
a.  There is hereby created and established a Code Enforcement Board to enforce the business tax receipts regulations, building, zoning, sign and other related codes and ordinances, which Board shall consist of seven (7) members and may additionally have up to two (2) alternate members to serve in the absence of Board members, appointed by the Mayor and City Commission for three (3) year terms, except as set forth herein. 
    Four (4) members, who represent seats 1, 3, 5, and 7, shall be appointed to serve from November 15 of that year, and three (3) members, who represent seats 2, 4, and 6, shall be appointed to serve from November 15 of that year. For the first board only, members appointed representing seats 1, 3, 5, and 7 shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, while members appointed representing seats 2, 4, and 6 shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. Appointments to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired term only. Vacancies shall be filled by the Commissioner's seat that made the appointment. Upon a seat becoming vacant, the City Clerk shall immediately notify, in writing, the Commissioner who made the appointment, and if no nomination is made within the next two ensuing regularly scheduled City Commission Meetings, a majority of the City Commission will appoint a member to fill the vacant position. 
    Effective November 15, 2012, the first Code Enforcement Board shall consist of newly-appointed members, in accordance with the intent of the City Commission and the City Charter. All board members shall be newly appointed at the City Commission meeting on November 6, 2012. Alternates shall be appointed by the Mayor and City Commission. Members of the Code Enforcement Board shall be subject to the provisions of Florida Statutes Section 286.012, relating to voting at meetings of the board, and to the provision of Florida Statutes Sections 112.311-112.3175, inclusive, relating to financial disclosure and conflicts of interest, and to the provisions of Florida Statute Section 112.501, relating to suspension and removal from office. 
    Members of the Code Enforcement Board shall be residents of the City of North Miami Beach. No person holding an elective office of the City shall be eligible to appointment to the Code Enforcement Board until at least one (1) year following termination of his/her elective office. Appointments shall be made on the basis of experience or interest in the fields of zoning and building control. The membership of the Code Enforcement Board shall, whenever possible, include an architect, a businessperson, an engineer, a general contractor, a subcontractor and a realtor, but shall not be limited to these professions. 
b.  Members of the Code Enforcement Board shall be appointed for three (3) year terms to commence on November 15 of the year of appointment. Service as an alternate member shall not preclude service as a regular member. Appointments to fill a vacancy shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. If any member fails to attend two (2) of three (3) successive meetings without cause and without prior approval of the Chairperson, the Code Enforcement Board shall declare the member's office vacant, and the Mayor and City Commission shall promptly fill such vacancy for the remainder of the term. 
c.  At each December Code Enforcement Board meeting, members of the Code Enforcement Board shall elect a Chairperson and a Vice-Chairperson from the members of the Board and each shall be a voting member of the Board. The presence of four (4) or more members shall constitute a quorum. Members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for such travel, mileage and per diem expenses as may be authorized by the Mayor and City Commission. 
d.  Special Magistrates shall be appointed by the City Commission to preside over code enforcement hearings in the same capacity as the Code Enforcement Board and shall have the same status as an Enforcement Board, pursuant to Florida Statute Chapter 162. The Special Magistrate shall be an attorney-at-law admitted to practice law in the State, a member in good standing of the Florida Bar, shall possess outstanding reputations for civic pride, interest, integrity, responsibility, and business or professional ability, and have significant knowledge of the City's Code enforcement matters and City Code. 
e.  The City Attorney or Assistant City Attorney shall either be counsel to the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate or shall represent the City by presenting cases before the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate. However, in no case shall the same attorney serve in both capacities. 
(1957 Code § 6-112; Ord. No. 80-43 § 5, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 82-21 §§ 1, 2, 7-6-82; Ord. No. 91-2 § 2, 2-5-91; Ord. No. 2000-4 § 2, 5-2-00; Ord. No. 2010-9 § 2, 5-4-10; Ord. No. 2012-27, § 2, 10-16-12 ; Ord. No. 2017-05 , § 2, 5-16-17) 
14-8.14   Enforcement Procedures.
a.  It shall be the duty of the Code Inspector to initiate enforcement proceedings of the various codes. No member of the Board or Special Magistrate shall have the power to initiate such enforcement proceedings. 
b.  Except as provided in paragraph c, if a violation of any code is found, the Code Inspector shall notify the violator and give him reasonable time to correct the violation. Should the violation continue beyond the time specified for correction, the Code Inspector shall request a hearing pursuant to the procedure in the following section. Written notice shall be mailed or hand-delivered to said violator as provided herein. Notice may also be served by publication or posting. 
c.  If the Code Inspector has reason to believe a violation or condition causing the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety or welfare, or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible in nature, the Code Inspector may proceed directly to the procedure set forth in subsection 14-8.15. 
d.  If the owner of property which is subject to a Code Enforcement proceeding changes ownership of the property between the time when the initial notice was served and the time of the hearing, the owner shall: 
1.  Disclose in writing the violation to the prospective transferee. 
2.  Deliver a copy of the violation to the prospective transferee. 
3.  Disclose in writing that the new owner will be responsible for compliance. 
4.  File a notice with the City's Department of Code Compliance and send a copy to the new owner stating the identity and address of the new owner within five (5) days after the date of transfer. 
(a)  Failure to make the disclosures before the transfer creates a rebuttable presumption of fraud. 
(b)  If the property is transferred before the hearing, the case shall not be dismissed, but the new owner shall be given a reasonable time to correct the violation before the hearing. 
(1957 Code § 6-113; Ord. No. 80-43 § 6, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 2000-4 § 2, 5-2-00; Ord. No. 2010-9 § 3, 5-4-10; Ord. No. 2012-27, § 3, 10-16-12 ) 
14-8.15   Conduct of Hearing.
a.  The Chairman of the Board or Special Magistrate may call hearings. Hearings may also be called by written notice signed by at least three (3) members of the Board or by a Special Magistrate. The Board or Special Magistrate, at any hearing, may set a future hearing date. The Board or Special Magistrate shall hold hearings as necessary. Minutes shall be kept of all hearings and all hearings shall be open to the public. The City shall provide clerical and administrative personnel as may be reasonably required for the proper performance of the Board's and Special Magistrate's duties. 
b.  Each case before the Board or Special Magistrate shall be presented by the City Manager or his/her authorized designee. 
c.  The Board or Special Magistrate shall proceed to hear the cases on the agenda for that day. The Board or Special Magistrate shall take testimony from the Code Inspector and alleged violator. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall be observed and govern the proceedings. 
d.  At the conclusion of the hearing, the Board or Special Magistrate shall issue findings of fact based on evidence and conclusion of law and shall issue an order affording the proper relief consistent with powers granted herein. The findings of the Board shall be by motion approved by a majority of those present and voting, except that at least four (4) members of the Board must vote for the action to be official. 
e.  The City Attorney or his/her authorized designee shall serve as counsel and advisor to the Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrate. If the City prevails at the hearing before the Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrate, it shall be entitled to recover all costs incurred in presenting the case before the Board or Special Magistrate and such costs may be included in the lien. 
(1957 Code § 6-114; Ord. No. 80-43 § 7, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 80-67 § 2, 1-6-81; Ord. No. 82-21 § 3, 7-6-82; Ord. No. 2000-4 6-114, 5-2-00; Ord. No. 2010-9 § 4, 5-4-10; Ord. No. 2012-27, § 4, 10-16-12 ) 
14-8.16   Powers of the Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrates.
    The Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrates shall have the power to: 
a.  Adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings. 
b.  Subpoena alleged violators and witnesses to its hearings. Subpoenas may be served by the Police Department of the City of North Miami Beach or the Miami-Dade County Police Department. 
c.  Subpoena evidence to its hearings. 
d.  Take testimony under oath. 
e.  Issue orders having the force of law commanding whatever steps are necessary to bring a violation into compliance. 
(1957 Code § 6-115; Ord. No. 80-43 § 8, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 82-21 § 4, 7-6-82; Ord. No. 2000-4 § 2, 5-2-00; Ord. No. 2010-9 § 5, 5-4-10) 
14-8.17   Administrative Fines; Costs of Repairs; Liens.
a.  The Board or Special Magistrate, upon notification by the Code Inspector that a previous order of the Board has not been complied with by the set time or upon finding that a repeat violation has been committed, may order the violator to pay a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty ($250.00) dollars for each day the violation continues past the date set for compliance and a fine not to exceed five hundred ($500.00) dollars per day for repeat violations and in addition may include all costs of repairs. 
1.  Repeat violation means a violation of the City Code and ordinance by a person who has been previously found through a Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate to have violated or who has admitted violating the same provision within five (5) years prior to the violation even though the violation occurred at different locations. 
b.  If the violation involves a serious threat to the public health, safety and welfare, the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate shall notify the City. The City may make all reasonable repairs which are required to bring the property into compliance and charge the violator with the reasonable cost of the repairs along with the fine. Making such repairs does not create any liability upon the City for damages to the property if the repairs were completed in good faith. 
c.  If, after due notice and a hearing, the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate finds a violation to be irreparable or irreversible in nature, it may impose a fine not to exceed five thousand ($5,000.00) dollars per violation. 
d.  The Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate may reduce a fine. 
e.  A certified copy of an order imposing a fine may be recorded in the public records and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the land on which the violation exists or, if the violator does not own the land, upon any other real or personal property owned by the violator. Upon petition to the Circuit Court, the order shall be enforced in the same manner as a court judgment by the Sheriffs of this State, including levy against the personal property, but shall not be deemed otherwise to be judgment of a court except for enforcement purposes. A fine imposed shall continue to accrue until the violator comes into compliance or a judgment is rendered. A lien from a fine runs in favor of the City and City may execute a satisfaction or release of lien.
