After three (3) months from the filing of any such lien which remains unpaid, the Board or Special Magistrate may authorize the City Attorney to foreclose on the lien or to recover money judgment for the amount of the lien plus accrued interest. 
(1957 Code § 6-116; Ord. No. 80-43 § 9, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 82-21 § 5, 7-6-82; Ord. No. 90-21 § 2, 10-16-90; Ord. No. 2000-4 § 2, 5-2-00; Ord. No. 2010-9 § 6, 5-4-10) 
14-8.18   Duration of Liens.
    No lien shall continue for a period longer than twenty (20) years after the certified copy of an order imposing a fine has been recorded unless an action to foreclose on the lien is commenced first. In an action to foreclose on a lien, or for money judgment, the prevailing party is entitled to recover all costs and a reasonable attorney's fee. City shall also be entitled to collect all costs incurred in recording and satisfying a valid lien. Actions for money judgments under this chapter be pursued only on fines levied after October 1, 2000. 
(Ord. No. 2000-4 § 6-117, 5-2-00) 
14-8.19   Appeals.
    An aggrieved party, including the City, may appeal a final administrative order of the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate to the Circuit Court. The appeal shall not be a hearing de novo but shall be limited to appellate review of the record created before the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate. An appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days of the date of the written order appealed. 
(1957 Code § 6-117; Ord. No. 80-43 § 10, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 82-21 § 6, 7-6-82; Ord. No. 2000-4 § 2[6-118], 5-2-00; Ord. No. 2010-9 § 7, 5-4-10) 
14-8.20   Notices.
a.  All notices required by this section shall be by: 
1.  Certified mail, return receipt requested, or where mail would not be effective, and is returned as unclaimed or refused, then the property may be posted. 
2.  By hand delivery of a person designated by the City. 
3.  By leaving the notice at the violator's usual place of residence with a person over fifteen (15) years of age and informing the person of the contents of the notice. 
4.  By leaving the notice with the manager or other person in charge if the violation involves commercial premises. 
5.  By publication: 
(a)  Notice shall be published once during each week for four (4) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in Miami-Dade County. 
6.  By posting property. 
(a)  Notice shall be posted at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing at the property where the violation exists and also in City Hall. 
(b)  Proof of posting shall be by affidavit stating the date and place of posting and the violation. 
(c)  Evidence that an attempt has been made to hand deliver or mail notice along with proof of publication or posting shall be sufficient to meet notice requirements whether or not alleged violator actually received notice. 
b.  In lieu of to providing notice as set forth in paragraph a. at the option of the Code Enforcement Board, notice may also be served by publication or posting, as follows: 
1.  (a)  Such notice shall be published once during each week for four (4) consecutive weeks (four (4) publications being sufficient) in a newspaper of general circulation in Miami-Dade County. The newspaper shall meet such requirements as are prescribed under Chapter 50, Florida Statutes for legal and official advertisements. 
(b)  Proof of publication shall be made by affidavit. 
2.  (a)  If there is no newspaper of general circulation in Miami-Dade County, three (3) copies of such notice shall be posted for at least twenty-eight (28) days in three (3) different and conspicuous places in such County, one (1) of which shall be at the front door of the courthouse in Miami-Dade County. 
(b)  Proof of posting shall be by affidavit of the person posting the notice, which affidavit shall include a copy of the notice posted and the date and places of its posting. 
(c)  Notice by publication or posting may run concurrently with, or may follow, an attempt or attempts to provide notice by hand delivery or by mail as required under paragraph a. 
    Evidence that an attempt has been made to hand deliver or mail notice as provided in paragraph a, together with proof of publication or posting as provided in paragraph b, shall be sufficient to show that the notice requirements of this part have been met, without regard to whether or not the alleged violator actually received such notice. 
(1957 Code § 6-118; Ord. No. 80-43 § 11, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 94-3 § 2, 2-14-94; Ord. No. 2000-4 § 6-119, 5-2-00) 
14-8.21   Code Enforcement Method; Option.
    None of the provisions contained in this section shall be considered exclusive. The Code Enforcement Official or Code Inspectors shall have the option to use any method provided by the Code of Ordinances to enforce the provisions of the various city codes. 
(1957 Code § 6-119; Ord. No. 80-43 § 12, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 2000-4 § 6-121, 5-2-00) 
14-8.22   Enforcement of Municipal Codes or Ordinances.
a.  Code Enforcement Officer means any designated employee or agent of the City whose duty it is to enforce City Codes and ordinances. 
b.  The City may designate certain of its employees or agents as Code Enforcement Officers. The Code Enforcement Officer shall not have the power to arrest. 
c.  A Code Enforcement Officer is authorized to issue a citation to a person when, based upon personal investigation, the Officer has reasonable cause to believe that the person has committed a violation of the City Codes or ordinances. 
1.  Prior to issuing a citation, the Code Enforcement Officer shall provide notice to the alleged violator and shall establish a reasonable time within which the violation can be corrected. Such time period shall be less than thirty (30) days. If the alleged violator fails to correct the violation in the time prescribed, then the Code Enforcement Officer may issue a citation to the alleged violator. 
2.  If a repeat violation is found; if the Code Enforcement Officer believes that the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety or welfare or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible, the officer does not have to provide a reasonable time period in which to correct the violation prior to issuing the citation. 
3.  A citation issued by a Code Enforcement Officer shall include: 
(a)  The date and time of issuance. 
(b)  The name and address of the person to whom the citation is issued. 
(c)  The date and time the violation was committed. 
(d)  A statement of facts. 
(e)  The section number or ordinance violated. 
(f)  The procedure to follow in order to pay the civil penalty or contest the citation. 
(g)  The civil penalty if the person either elects to contest the citation or elects not to contest the citation. (h) A statement indicating that failure to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed or failure to appear to contest the citation shall waive the right to contest the citation and judgment may be entered against the person. 
4.  Any person who willfully refuses to sign and accept a citation issued by a Code Enforcement Officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree, punishable as prescribed under Florida Statutes. 
d.  The provisions of this section shall not apply to violations of the Minimum Building Codes, The Standard Building Codes, The EPCOT Code, The One and Two-Family Dwelling Code, and The Florida Building Code. 
e.  Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the City from enforcing its Codes and ordinances by any other means. 
(Ord. No. 2000-4 § 6-121, 5-2-00) 
14-9, 14-10 - RESERVED. 
14-11 - SEA WALLS AND BULKHEADS. 
14-11.1   Scope.
    This section with its specifications is intended to cover the construction of sea walls and bulkheads to be permanently installed along any lake, creek, river, canal, or channel within the City. 
(1957 Code § 17A-1; Ord. No. 811 § 1, 2-20-58) 
14-11.2   Materials.
a.  Sea walls or bulkheads shall be constructed of materials which are resistant to salt water corrosion or which are adequately protected against salt water corrosion. 
b.  Sea walls or bulkheads shall be constructed of materials which are not susceptible to attack by marine organisms or which shall be adequately protected against attack by marine organisms. 
(1957 Code § 17A-2; Ord. No. 811 § 2, 2-20-58) 
14-11.3   Design; Description, Sketch to Accompany Application.
    The structural design of any sea wall or bulkhead shall be certified by an engineer registered in the State of Florida. The application for a permit to construct a sea wall or bulkhead shall be accompanied by a brief description of the design methods and assumptions to include unit weight assumed for soils, angle or internal friction for soils, and a sketch to show elevations of any structural unit or any material adjoining a structural unit. If a surcharge, either soil or of a moving type is expected behind the top of the sea wall or bulkhead, this surcharge must be noted on the sketch accompanying the application for permit. 
(1957 Code § 17A-3; Ord. No. 811 § 3, 2-20-58) 
14-11.4   Boring Required Where Subsurface Information is Uncertain.
    If, in the opinion of the Building Official the subsurface information in the area of the bulkhead is uncertain or unknown, a boring or borings may be required. A location sketch showing the proposed construction shall accompany the application. 
(1957 Code § 17A-4; Ord. No. 811 § 3, 2-20-58) 
Cross reference- For provisions relating to the Building Department see § 14-2.1 et seq. 
14-11.5   Construction; Notification of Building Department; Substandard Work to be Redone.
    After a permit for construction is obtained, the Building Department is to be notified twenty-four (24) hours before construction of any bulkhead or sea wall is to begin. 
    If, in the opinion of the Building Department, poor construction practices or inferior materials are being used in the sea wall or bulkhead, the work may be stopped by the Building Department. The unsatisfactory portion thereof shall be removed at the expense of the builder and the work shall then be allowed to proceed. 
(1957 Code § 17A-5; Ord. No. 811 § 4, 2-20-58) 
Cross reference- For provisions relating to the Building Department see § 14-2.1 et seq. 
14-11.6   Construction Criteria.
    As a minimum criteria, the following shall be observed: 
a.  All concrete shall have a minimum compressive strength at twenty-eight (28) days of not less than two thousand five hundred (2,500) p.s.i. 
b.  All exposed steel shall be covered with the appropriate primer and two (2) coats of coal tar enamel or asphalt having a minimum thickness of twenty (.020) mils. 
c.  Reinforcing steel shall be new billet stock of intermediate grade steel deformed to conform to A.S.T.M. A-305. 
d.  If a precast king-pile and precast slab type sea wall is proposed, the pile shall be designed to carry the load from the slab in bending and shear. Such a slab shall be designed with a minimum steel ratio of reinforcing area to concrete area of .0043. 
e.  All reinforcing steel shall have a minimum cover of two (2) inches of concrete. 
f.  The surfaces of any poured-in place joints in precast construction shall be thoroughly cleaned and rinsed with fresh water before the joint is poured. 
(1957 Code § 17A-6; Ord. No. 811 § 5, 2-20-58) 
14-11.7   Standards for Completed Sea Wall or Bulkhead.
    The finished sea wall or bulkhead shall be true to the proposed lines and elevations and in no case shall the following limits of line and elevation be exceeded: 
a.  The top of the sea wall or bulkhead shall show no variation more than one quarter (1/4) inch under a ten (10) foot straight edge. 
b.  The water side of the sea wall or bulkhead shall show no variation more than one half (1/2) inch under a ten (10) foot straight edge. 
(1957 Code § 17A-7; Ord. No. 811 § 5, 2-20-58) 
14-12 - RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS. 
14-12.1   Rental Building, Inspection and Permitting.
    There shall be annual inspection and permitting of all buildings with rental units that are rented. 
a.  No person, natural or corporate, shall offer for rent or lease any residential units located in a building or with three (3) or more residential units unless the building has been inspected by the City of North Miami Beach Code Compliance Division and a residential rental permit has been issued by the City to the owner of record of the building. 
b.  Any person, natural or corporate, who at the time of the adoption of this section, rents or leases units in a building containing three (3) or more residential units shall have thirty (30) calendar days from the date the owner receives a residential rental permit application (provided by the City), to file for application with the City for permit issuance. 
c.  The date of the City's initial inspection shall establish an annual anniversary date. 
d.  All owners shall appoint/designate/assign a local manager/agent/designee to any residential rental property located within the City of North Miami Beach to accept service of process on behalf of the owner of title and to be held accountable for the maintenance of the property and compliance with all City codes. The local manager/agent/designee shall be indicated on each and every residential permit application. It shall be the owner's responsibility to notify the City of the manager/agent/designee's name and local address. 
(Ord. No. 92-15 § 2, 8-14-92; Ord. No. 94-2 § 2, 2-14-94; Ord. No. 2009-1 § 2, 2-3-09) 
14-12.2   Procedures and Standards for Residential Rental Permit Issuance.
a.  The City's Code Compliance Division shall be charged with the responsibility, subject to the approval of the City Manager, of establishing administrative rules and regulations pertaining to the issuance of residential rental permits. No such permit shall be issued, however, unless and until the following has occurred: 
1.  Each applicant for permit issuance has completed a form application made available by the Code Compliance Division. 
2.  Each applicant has paid the fee established by the City Council, which may be adjusted annually by an amending ordinance so as to reimburse the City for the cost of conducting the annual inspection. 
b.  On initial application, the inspection fee must be paid prior to the issuance of the permit. Each year thereafter, upon renewal of the permit, the inspection fee must be paid as a condition precedent to the issuance of the renewal permit. 
c.  Each property inspected pursuant to the application requested must meet the following standards established by the City in addition to and supplemented by other requirements adopted by the City in order to maintain and enhance property values as well as to provide for the safety of the occupants of the property inspected. 
d.  Exterior Building Condition. 
1.  Exterior wall surfaces-Maintained in good condition to prevent deterioration; repainted, cleaned or recovered when twenty-five (25%) percent or more of any exposure becomes discolored (from its originally intended design) or is peeling. All parts of the structure that show dry rot or other deterioration shall be repaired, replaced or refinished to be in conformity with the rest of the structure. The exterior surfaces shall be kept free from materials, objects and conditions which will have an adverse effect on adjacent premises. There shall be a number affixed to the front of the structure or at the front of the property identifying the address of the property. 
2.  Stairs, porches and railings-The stairs, porches and railings affixed to the exterior of every structure used for human habitation shall be kept in good repair and structurally sound. They shall be kept free from holes and serious cracks and shall be capable of supporting imposed loads. 
3.  Roofing and guttering-Maintained in good condition to prevent water from leaking into the building structure; painted roofs will be repainted and all other types of roofing will be cleaned when twenty-five (25%) percent or more of any exposure becomes discolored by mildew or is peeling. 
e.  Outside Property Condition. 
1.  Off-street parking-The number of required off-street parking spaces shall be maintained. Paving (whether gravel, concrete, paver stones, asphalt, or other), striping, curbing, wheel stops, as well as drainage facilities must be repaired or replaced when any deterioration occurs to the extent that the roadrock or subbase is showing. 
2.  Landscaping-All landscaping shall be provided and maintained as required by City code. 
3.  Garbage, trash and refuse-Each residential living unit must be provided with close fitting solid waste storage equipment which meets the requirements of the City code. The property shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, free of accumulations of garbage, trash and refuse. 
4.  Accessory structures-Every accessory structure shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, free from rodents, vermin and infestations. Fences, garden walls and similar enclosures shall be maintained in a good state of repair. 
5.  Swimming pools and patios-Maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, free from debris, trash, garbage or vegetation. There shall be a perimeter safety fence surrounding the pool area as required by Code. 
6.  Abandoned property-Abandoned property shall not be permitted to remain on private property or open easements contiguous to private property. 
7.  Personal property-Personal property must be stored in either an approved container or in some other type of enclosed facility. 
(Ord. No. 92-15 § 2, 8-14-92; Ord. No. 2009-1 § 2, 2-3-09) 
14-12.3   Unsafe Dwellings.
a.  A dwelling shall be deemed unsafe and referred to the appropriate agency, department or board for remedial action when: 
1.  It is abandoned, unguarded and open at doors or windows; or 
2.  There is an accumulation of dust, debris or other combustible material therein or directly adjacent thereto; or 
3.  There is a falling away, hanging loose or loosening of any siding, block, brick or other building material; or 
4.  The building is partially destroyed; or 
5.  There is a deterioration of the structure or structural parts; or 
6.  An unsanitary condition exists by reason of inadequate or malfunctioning sanitary facilities or waste disposal systems. 
(Ord. No. 92-15 § 2, 8-14-92; Ord. No. 2009-1 § 2, 2-3-09) 
14-12.4   Failure to Comply with Standards; Temporary Permit; Inspections.
a.  The Director of Code Enforcement (and his or her agents) shall have the authority to issue a temporary permit for operation pending compliance with the standards established by this section following any inspection. Such temporary permit shall, however, in no event exceed sixty (60) calendar days, with the exact number of days to be within the discretion of the Director of Code Enforcement. Any extension will be strictly based upon an estimate of the number of working days needed to comply with the standards established by this section. 
b.  Reinspection must be accomplished prior to the expiration of the temporary permit. 
(Ord. No. 92-15 § 2, 8-14-92; Ord. No. 2009-1 § 2, 2-3-09) 
14-12.5   Enforcement.
    The enforcement of terms and conditions of this section shall be through the City of North Miami Beach Code Enforcement Board and anyone failing to obtain a residential rental permit will be brought before the Board for failing to obtain a residential rental permit. Anyone failing to correct a violation under this section will be brought before the board for failing to comply with the violation(s) cited. 
(Ord. No. 92-15 § 2, 8-14-92; Ord. No. 2009-1 § 2, 2-3-09) 
14-12.6   Definitions and Standards.
    The following definitions and standards shall apply to this section: 
    Abandoned property shall mean personal property that is not in use or able to be used and which is not stored in an approved container or some type of enclosed facility. 
    Anniversary date shall mean the date the initial inspection is performed during the fiscal year and each property will be inspected in the same month of each fiscal year and not the date the permit is issued. 
    Approved container shall mean a container including but not limited to storage sheds, garages, car ports and other storage containers that are designed to maintain private property in a secure manner and out of public sight. 
    Approved manner shall mean deemed correct by the Building Official at the time the certificate of occupancy was issued. 
    Clean and sanitary shall mean that the exterior of the property and building is free from accumulations of garbage, trash, debris and human and/or animal excrement. 
    C lose fitting, solid waste storage equipment shall mean any cylindrical, light gauged steel, plastic or galvanized receptacle closed at one (1) end, water tight and opened at the other, furnished with a tight fitting top or lid and appropriate lifting handles, or any detachable metal container designed or intended to be mechanically serviced and varying in size from two (2) to forty (40) cubic yards. 
    Deterioration shall mean the condition or appearance of a building, or parts thereof, characterized by holes, breaks, rot, crumbling, cracking, peeling, rusting or other evidence of physical decay, neglect or lack of maintenance. 
    Discolored shall mean when the present wall/surface/roof coloring is different from the original surface coloring due to weather, fading or vandalism. 
    Exterior property shall mean open space on the premises. 
    Garbage shall mean the animal, vegetable and mineral wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Good condition shall mean the building feature is performing according to its originally intended design function. 
    Good repair shall mean that any repair made to a building feature will cause that feature to come into compliance with its originally intended design function. 
    Inspection date shall mean the actual date the initial residential rental permit inspection is performed. 
    Owner shall mean any person, firm, corporation or legal entity who alone or jointly or severally with others: 
1.  Shall have legal or beneficial title to any building arranged, designed or used, in whole or in part, to house three (3) or more dwelling units; 
2.  Shall have charge, care or control of any building arranged, designed or used, in whole or in part, to house three (3) or more dwelling units, as owner or agent of the owner, or as a fiduciary of the estate of the owner or any officer appointed by the court. Any such person thus representing the actual such owner shall be bound to comply with the terms of this section and any notice of rules and regulations pursuant thereto, to the same extent as if he/she were the owner. 
    Personal property shall mean property that is owned by the tenant and/or property owner and stored on the property. 
    Supplied utility shall mean those public or private utilities including, but not limited to: electricity, water, sewer, telephone, cable television and gas. 
    Trash and debris shall mean any accumulation of the following, but not limited to: grass clippings, hedge and tree trimmings, palm fronds, leaf rakings, and other such debris resulting from the maintenance of lawns and yards. 
    Vegetation shall mean plant or mold materials that are growing in a manmade aquatic environment and presents a nuisance or health hazard (real or potential) to users of the manmade aquatic environment or to adjacent residents. 
    Ventilated shall mean that the building features intended to circulate air to specific sections of the building are operating according to their originally intended design function. 
    Vermin proof shall mean that the building feature is acting as a barrier against insects according to its originally intended design function. 
    Weather tight shall mean that the building is acting as a barrier against wind or water according to its originally intended design function. 
(Ord. No. 92-15 § 2, 8-14-92; Ord. No. 2009-1 § 2, 2-3-09) 
14-12.7   Annual Inspection Fees.
a.  The following annual inspection fees have been established for each type of residential structure. These fees are subject to change by ordinance if administrative costs for the program change: 
Triplex $100.00 Fourplex $110.00 Five units $120.00 Six units $130.00 Seven units $140.00 Eight units $150.00 Nine units $160.00 Ten units $170.00 10-20 units $200.00 20-30 units $250.00 Over 30 units $300.00  
(Ord. No. 92-15 § 2, 8-14-92; Ord. No. 2009 § 2, 2-3-09) 
CHAPTER XV - FIRE PREVENTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate construction of buildings so as to secure safety from fire, Charter § 21(21)(22). 

15-1 - LIFE SAFETY CODE. 
15-1.1   Adopted of National Board of Fire Underwriters Code by Reference.
    There is hereby adopted by the City, for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, that certain code known as the Life Safety Code (2006) and the whole thereof, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended, of which Code and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the City. 
(1957 Code § 9-1; Ord. No. 61-4 § 1, 2-7-61) 
15-1.2   Definitions; Amendments.
    As used in the Code adopted in subsection 15-1.1: 
a.  Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the Life Safety Code, it shall be held to mean the City of North Miami Beach. 
b.  Wherever the term "corporation counsel" is used in the Life Safety Code, it shall be held to mean the Attorney for the City of North Miami Beach. 
c.  Wherever the term "fireworks" is used in the Life Safety Code it shall have the following meaning and shall be subject to the exceptions hereinafter set forth: 
1.  The term fireworks shall mean and include any combustible or explosive composition, or any substance or combination of substances, or, except as hereinafter provided, any article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or an audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include blank cartridges and toy cannons in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, Dago bombs, and any fireworks containing any explosives or flammable compound or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance. 
2.  The term fireworks shall not include sparklers, toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper caps containing twenty-five hundredths (0.25) grains or less of explosive compound are used, providing they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion, and the toy pistol paper caps which contain less than twenty hundredths (0.20) grains of explosive mixture, the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times. 
(1957 Code § 9-1.1; Ord. No. 61-4 § 3, 2-7-61; Ord. No. 64-22 §§ 1, 2, 6-23-64) 
15-1.3   Establishment of Limits of Districts in Which Storage of Flammable Liquids in Outside Aboveground Tanks is Prohibited.
a.  The National Fire Protection Association 58 and 59 and National Fire Protection Association 30, or other applicable regulatory authority, shall be for the best interests, the health, welfare and safety of the citizenry of the City and its visitors; subject, however, always, to the final ratification of the City Council. 
b.  Such areas as those zoned solely for residential occupancies and for mercantile establishments primarily retail in character which, to the Building Department of the City of North Miami Beach or other applicable regulatory authority, shall be for the best interests, the health, welfare and safety of the citizenry of the City and its visitors. 
(1957 Code § 9-1.2; Ord. No. 61-4 § 4, 2-7-61; Ord. No. 79-30 § 2, 11-20-79) 
15-1.4   Establishment of Limits in Which Bulk Storage of Liquefied Petroleum Gases is Restricted.
    The limits referred to in National Fire Protection Association 30 of the Life Safety Code, in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, are hereby established as follows: Such heavily populated and congested commercial areas which, to the Chief of the Fire Department Miami-Dade County, or other applicable regulatory authority, shall be for the best interests, the health, welfare and safety of the citizenry of the City and its visitors. 
(1957 Code § 9-1.3; Ord. No. 61-4 § 5, 2-7-61; Ord. No. 79-30 § 3, 11-20-79) 
15-1.5   Establishment of Limits of Districts in Which Storage of Explosives and Blasting Agents is Prohibited.
    The limits referred to in Section 12.6b of the Life Safety Code, in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are hereby established as follows: Such principal business districts, closely-built commercial areas and heavily populated areas which, to the Chief of the Fire Department of the Miami-Dade County, or other applicable regulatory authority, shall be for the best interests, the health, welfare and safety of the citizenry of the City and its visitors. 
(1957 Code § 9-1.4; Ord. No. 61-4 § 6, 2-7-61; Ord. No. 79-30 § 4, 11-20-79) 
15-1.6   Enforcement; Inspectors; Reports, Etc.
a.  The Life Safety Code shall be enforced by the Fire Department of Miami-Dade County or other applicable regulatory authority. 
b.  The Chief of the Fire Department of Miami-Dade County, or other applicable regulatory authority, may detail such members of the applicable fire department as inspectors as shall, from time to time, be necessary. As per Section 633.34, Florida Statutes, inspectors shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the Fire Department, and appointments made after examination shall be for an indefinite term with removal only for cause. 
c.  A report of the Fire Department of Miami-Dade County, or other applicable regulatory authority, shall be made annually and transmitted to the Chief Executive Officer of the City. It shall contain all proceedings under the Code adopted by this section, with such statistics as the Chief of the Fire Department Miami-Dade County, or other regulatory authority [may wish to include therein, and he] shall also recommend any amendments to the Code which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. 
(1957 Code § 9-1.5; Ord. No. 61-4 § 2, 2-7-61; Ord. No. 79-30 § 5, 11-20-79) 
15-2 - FIRE EXTINGUISHERS. 
15-2.1   Number Required and Locations.
    Every hotel, rooming house, apartment house and restaurant shall be provided with one (1) fire extinguisher of a style and size as approved by the National Board of Fire Underwriters on each floor containing twenty-five hundred (2,500) square feet or less of floor area and one (1) additional fire extinguisher on each floor for each twenty-five hundred (2,500) square feet or less of additional floor space, which fire extinguishers shall be placed or kept in a convenient location in a public hallway outside of the sleeping rooms, at or near the head of the stairs where stairs exist or if there be no hallway then in some public place, and such fire extinguishers shall always be kept in conditions for use for the purpose of extinguishing fires. 
(Ord. No. 595 § 1, 10-23-56; 1957 Code § 9-2) 
15-2.2   Inspections and Repair or Replacement.
a.  Every fire extinguisher required by law to be kept upon any premises in the City shall be inspected at least once during every year by one (1) or more inspectors, authorized and approved by the Chief of the Fire Department of Miami-Dade County, or other applicable regulatory authority. (National Fire Protection Association 1, Chapter 6). 
b.  Every fire extinguisher included within the purview of Section 15-2 which, upon inspection, is found to be defective or unfit for the service for which it is required by law to be kept upon the premises, shall immediately be repaired or replaced by a serviceable extinguisher and the person legally required to keep such extinguisher upon the premises shall have such repairs or replacement made in accordance with instructions issued by the inspector by whom such extinguisher is declared to be defective. 
(Ord. No. 595 §§ 2-6, 10-23-56; 1957 Code § 9-3; Ord. No. 60-135, 1-17-61; Ord. No. 79-30 § 10, 11-20-79) 
15-2.3   Manual 10, Adoption by Reference.
    The National Board of Fire Underwriters Manual Number 10 and more particularly Sections 2 and 3 thereof be and the same is hereby adopted and made a part of this chapter by reference as if fully set out herein, and such manual and sections shall be referred to for classification of and description of fire extinguishers in other occupancies, other than referred to in subsection 15-2.1 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 595 § 8, 10-23-56; 1957 Code § 9-5) 
15-3 - RESERVED.[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Former Section 15-3, Stationary Engineers, Operators and Firemen, previously codified herein and containing portions of 1957 Code §§ 9-3, 9-5, 9-7, 9-8, 9-8.1, 9-9-9-13 and 9-15 and Ordinance Nos. 595, 675, 707, 937, 60-135, 79-30, 80-66, 81-10, 81-37, 82-26, 90-13 and 97-3 was repealed in its entirety by Ordinance No. 2009-14. 

CHAPTER XVI - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE 

16-1 - MINIMUM EXTERIOR BUILDING STANDARDS. 
16-1.1   Created; Title.
    There is hereby created a set of minimum exterior building standards for the maintenance of dwelling units and commercial buildings in the City as set out in this section which shall be known as the "minimum exterior maintenance standards for dwelling units and commercial buildings." 
(1957 Code § 6-127; Ord. No. 79-13 § 2, 7-17-79) 
16-1.2   Application.
    This section shall apply to the exterior portion of every building in the City and its appurtenant facilities, as well as any and all adjoining grounds, areas or other premises. In any situation where a provision of this section conflicts with any other building, housing, litter, health, safety, or zoning regulations, the higher standard shall prevail. 
(1957 Code § 6-128; Ord. No. 79-13 § 3, 7-17-79) 
16-1.3   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    Commercial building shall mean any building in the City of North Miami Beach not used as a dwelling unit. 
    Dwelling unit shall mean a structure or part of a structure that is used as a home, residence or sleeping place by one (1) person or by two (2) or more persons who maintain a common household. 
    Exterior property areas shall mean the open space on the premises and on adjoining property under the control of owners or occupants of such premises. 
    Premises shall mean a dwelling unit or commercial building, and the structure of which it is a part, and the appurtenant facilities and grounds. 
    Structure shall mean an assembly of materials forming a construction for occupancy or use, including but not limited to buildings, water tanks, storage tanks, open sheds, carports, shelters, fences, swimming pools and display signs. 
(1957 Code § 6-129; Ord. No. 79-13 § 4 7-17-79) 
16-1.4   Requirements Relating to the Safe and Sanitary Maintenance of Dwelling Units and Commercial Buildings.
    All buildings shall meet the following criteria: 
a.  Comply with the requirements of all applicable building, housing, litter, health, safety, or zoning codes. 
b.  All foundation walls shall be structurally sound, reasonably rodent-proof and maintained in good repair. Foundation walls shall be considered to be sound if they are capable of bearing imposed loads and of resisting normal forces, and there is no evidence of rot or decay. The foundation elements shall adequately support the building at all points. 
c.  Every building shall be reasonably weathertight, watertight and rodent-proof. Floors, walls, ceilings and roofs shall be capable of affording adequate shelter and shall be kept in good repair. Windows and exterior doors shall be reasonably weathertight, watertight and rodent-proof, and shall be maintained in good working condition. All parts of the structure that show evidence of rot or other deterioration shall be repaired or replaced. 
d.  Every outside stairway, porch, and every appurtenance thereto, shall be maintained in a safe condition and shall be capable of supporting loads which normal use may impose. 
e.  Every chimney, smoke pipe and all flue and vent attachments thereto, shall be maintained in such condition to prohibit leakage or backing up of smoke and/or noxious gases into the dwelling or building. 
f.  All exterior surfaces subject to deterioration shall be properly maintained and protected from the elements by paint or other approved protective coating applied in a workmanlike fashion. Every foundation, exterior wall, roof and all other exterior surfaces shall be free of holes, breaks, loose or rotting boards or timbers, and any other conditions which might admit rain or dampness to the interior portions of the walls or to the occupied spaces of the building. 
g.  Roofs shall be structurally sound, tight, and have no defects which might admit rain and roof drainage and shall be adequate to prevent rainwater from causing dampness in the walls or interior portion of the building. 
h.  All accessory structures, including detached garages and swimming pools, shall be maintained in structurally sound condition and in good repair. 
(1957 Code § 6-130; Ord. No. 79-13 § 5, 7-17-79) 
16-1.5   Responsibilities of Owners and Occupants.
    No person shall occupy or let to another for occupancy, any dwelling unit or commercial building for the purpose of living or working therein, which does not comply with the following requirements: 
a.  Every unit shall be safe, clean, sanitary and fit for human habitation. 
b.  Every occupant of a dwelling unit or commercial building shall keep that part of the building, premises, and exterior property areas thereof which he occupies and controls, including yards, lawns, courts and driveways in a safe, clean and sanitary condition. The provisions of this subsection shall also apply to vacant lots and to premises of business establishments located adjacent to dwellings and dwelling units. 
c.  Every owner of a building containing two (2) or more dwelling units or offices shall be responsible for maintaining the shared or public areas of the dwelling and premises thereof in a clean and sanitary condition free from any accumulation of litter. 
d.  Exterior premises shall be kept free from accumulation of rubbish, excessive growth of weeds, grass and other flora. The term "excessive" shall be interpreted as meaning detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of the occupants or the public. The provisions of this subsection shall also apply to the vacant lots and to the premises of commercial establishments located adjacent to dwellings and dwelling units. 
e.  Every occupant of a building shall dispose of rubbish, garbage, litter and other waste materials in an approved, sanitary manner. Garbage and litter shall be placed in the garbage disposal facilities or storage containers required under this Code. 
f.  Every occupant of a building containing a single unit shall be responsible for the extermination of insects, rodents, vermin, or other pests therein or on the premises. Every occupant of a building containing more than one (1) unit shall be responsible for such extermination whenever his unit is the only one (1) infested, except that whenever such infestation is caused by the failure of the owner to carry out the provisions of this section, extermination shall be the responsibility of the owner. In every building containing one (1) or more units, the owner shall exterminate all infestations of insects, rodents, vermin or other pests therein or on the premises, except where such pests are the responsibility of the occupant, as provided in the preceding sentence. 
g.  Every owner of a building shall provide approved door and window screens whenever such screens are required under the provisions of this Code, and shall repair or replace them when necessary before renting or subletting to another occupant. 
h.  Upon commencement of each occupancy, the owner of every building which is let for occupancy furnished, shall initially deliver to the occupant such personal property constituting housekeeping equipment which is operable, clean, safe and sanitary. 
i.  Every owner of a building shall grade and maintain the exterior premises so as to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon. 
j.  Animals and pets shall not be kept in any building or dwelling unit or on any premises in such a manner so as to create unsanitary conditions or constitute a nuisance. 
(1957 Code § 6-131; Ord. No. 79-13 § 6, 7-17-79) 
16-1.6   Maintenance of Nondwelling Structures and Fences.
    Every accessory structure used for nondwelling purposes, including but not limited to garages, carports, cabanas, storage buildings, and every fence shall comply with the following requirements: 
a.  Every foundation, exterior and interior wall, roof, floor, ceiling, window and exterior door shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair. 
b.  Every accessory structure shall be kept in a reasonably clean and sanitary condition free from rodents, insects, and vermin. 
c.  The roof of every accessory structure shall be well drained of rainwater. 
d.  All exterior surfaces subject to deterioration shall be properly maintained and protected from the elements by paint or other approved protective coating, applied in a workmanlike fashion. 
(1957 Code § 6-132; Ord. No. 79-13 § 7, 7-17-79) 
16-1.7   Enforcement.
    This section shall be enforced by the Code Enforcement Officers of the City of North Miami Beach, through the issuance of notices of violation stating the violation and the remedial action required. Failure to comply and correct the violation within a reasonable time shall be punishable as set forth herein. 
(1957 Code § 6-133; Ord. No. 79-13 § 8, 7-17-79) 
16-1.8   Penalty.
    Should the owner or occupant of any property situated in the City violate any or all of the provisions of this section, such owner or occupant shall be subject to a fine of up to five hundred ($500.00) dollars in addition to other penalties and remedies provided in Section 1-8 of this Code, upon conviction of such violation. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(1957 Code § 6-134; Ord. No. 79-13 § 9, 7-17-79) 
16-1.9   Dish Antennas.
a.  Location. Dish antennas may be located on residential or business property, but must be located in the rear yard of same or other suitable location as determined by the City Manager and/or his designee. Sufficient landscaping must be provided to obscure the antenna from ground view from the surrounding and adjacent properties with no part of the apparatus extending into the required setback areas. On corner properties, no portion of the apparatus may extend beyond the imaginary extensions of the lines of the house structure. Dish antennas shall be limited as to size and number and shall be located and designed to reduce visual impact from surrounding properties at street level and from public streets. 
b.  Safety Regulations. All antennas and the construction and installation thereof shall conform to applicable City Building Code and Electrical Code regulations and requirements. Antennas shall meet all manufacturers specifications, be of non-combustible and corrosive-resistant material, and be erected in a secure, wind-resistant manner. Every antenna must be adequately grounded for protection against a direct strike of lightning. 
c.  Permit. Anyone wishing to erect a dish antenna must first submit plans for same together with a lot survey to show the location of the antenna on the lot and the landscape plans to the City Manager and/or his designee for review and approval. Upon approval, a permit will be issued after payment of a fifty ($50.00) dollar permit fee. 
d.  Any permit applicant who cannot administratively resolve his permit request shall have the right to apply for a zoning variance pursuant to Section 24-86(C)(5) et seq. of this Code. The fifty ($50.00) dollar permit application fee, in addition to the actual cost of providing the required notices and advertisements for the protection of the surrounding community, shall constitute the entire official filing fee for an application for a variance pursuant to this section. 
e.  Existing Antennas. All dish antennas legally existing on the date this section becomes effective shall be permitted to remain but may not be increased in size. 
(1957 Code § 6-135; Ord. No. 82-25 § 1, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 89-11 § 2, 10-17-89) 
16-2 - UPKEEP OF LOTS, PARCELS AND TRACTS. 
16-2.1   Certain Conditions of Lots, Parcels and Tracts Declared Unlawful.
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of any lot, parcel or tract of land within the City, whether the lot, parcel or tract of land is improved or unimproved, to permit weeds, grass, or undergrowth to grow thereon to a height of twelve (12) inches except for the first one hundred (100) feet in depth from the property line which shall not exceed a height of eight (8) inches or more from the ground, or to permit rubbish, trash, debris, dead trees, growth of noxious plants or weeds, or to permit unsightly or unsanitary matter to remain thereon, or to permit the existence of depressions or excavations or any other condition on such premises wherein water may accumulate and stand in such a manner or fashion as to make possible the propagation of mosquitoes therein. 
(1957 Code § 10-25; Ord. No. 61-15 § 1, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 80-27 § 3, 5-20-80; Ord. No. 84-8 § 2, 9-4-84) 
16-2.2   Maintenance of Swale Areas.
    It shall be the duty of all owners and/or occupants of improved or unimproved property to maintain in good condition the non-paved area between their property line and the street curb or edge of the paved road known as the swale area. Maintenance of the swale area shall include keeping the area free of holes, hidden dangers or other obstructions and the grass or weeds at a height of no more than eight (8) inches. 
(1957 Code § 10-25.1; Ord. No. 81-38 § 2, 1-5-82; Ord. No. 84-8 § 3, 9-4-84) 
16-2.3   City Manager to Give Notice of Violations.
    Upon the failure or refusal of the owner and/or occupant of any lot, parcel, tract of land or swale area within the City, whether the lot, parcel, tract of land or swale area is improved or unimproved to keep such premises free of weeds, grass or undergrowth of a height of twelve (12) inches depending upon the location on the property as set forth in subsection 16-2.1 or more from the ground, or free of rubbish, trash, debris, dead trees or other unsightly and unsanitary matter, except garden trash put out for pickup by the Department of Public Works, or to keep such premises free of excavations or depression as provided above, the City Manager shall give notice, as hereinafter provided, to the owner and/or occupants, if any, of such property to comply with the requirements of this section within fifteen (15) days after service of such notice. 
(1957 Code § 10-26; Ord. No. 61-15 § 2, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 80-27 § 4, 5-20-80; Ord. No. 81-38 § 3, 1-5-82; Ord. No. 84-8 § 4, 9-4-84) 
16-2.4   City Manager Authorized to Remedy Condition Remaining Uncorrected; Cost to Constitute Lien.
    Upon failure of the owner and/or occupant of such premises to remedy the condition existing in violation of the requirements hereof (of this section) within fifteen (15) days after service of notice to do so as provided herein, the City Manager shall proceed as prescribed below to have such conditions remedied, and the cost thereof shall be and become a lien against such property to the same extent of character as the lien for special assessments and with the same penalties and with the same rights of collection, foreclosure, sale and forfeiture as obtained for special assessment liens. 
(1957 Code § 10-27; Ord. No. 61-15 § 3, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 80-27 § 5, 5-20-80) 
16-2.5   Notice to Owner.
    The City Manager shall, by certified mail, addressed to the owner if the property is unoccupied, or to the owner and/or occupant if the property is occupied, of any lot or swale area to be cleared at the address of such owner as contained in the rolls of the Tax Assessor, notify such owner and/or occupant of the intent of the City to clear such lot or swale area and impose a lien thereon for the costs of such work and an administrative fee of fifty ($50.00) dollars per lot cleared should the owner and/or occupant fail to do so within fifteen (15) days from the service of such notice. In the event the lot, tract, parcel of land or swale area is unoccupied and the address of the owner is unknown, service of the notice shall be made upon the owner by posting the same on such lot, tract, or parcel of land. The notice shall contain the legal description of the lot, parcel, tract of land or swale area. The notice shall be in substantially the following form: 
To: (Name of owner and/or occupant) 
(Address of owner and/or occupant) 
    Our records indicate you to be the owner and/or occupant of the following property in the City of North Miami Beach: 
(Description of Property) 
    An inspection of this property discloses that it is in such condition as to be in violation of Chapter XVI of the Code of Ordinances of the City of North Miami Beach in that it (state nature of violation). 
    Chapter XVI of the Code of Ordinances of the City of North Miami Beach makes it unlawful for you to allow this condition to continue and you are hereby notified that unless this condition is remedied within fifteen (15) days from the date hereof, the City of North Miami Beach will proceed to remedy such condition and the costs of such work and an administrative fee of fifty ($50.00) dollars per lot cleared will be imposed as a lien upon the above-described property. 
    Please be governed accordingly. 
___________ 
City Manager 
(1957 Code § 10-28; Ord. No. 61-15 § 4, 5-6-61; Ord. No. 63-25 § 1, 12-3-63; Ord. No. 80-24 § 2, 5-6-80; Ord. No. 80-27 § 6, 5-20-80; Ord. No. 81-38 § 4, 1-5-82; Ord. No. 85-5 § 2, 3-5-85) 
16-2.6   City Manager to Proceed With Clearance.
    Upon failure of the owner and/or occupant of any land to remedy a condition thereon constituting a violation of this chapter within fifteen (15) days after the notice from the City Manager as provided in subsection 16-2.5 hereof, the City Manager shall cause such condition to be remedied by contract or by use of City employees and equipment or by any combination thereof. 
(1957 Code § 10-29; Ord. No. 61-15 § 5, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 63-25 § 2, 12-3-63; Ord. No. 80-27 § 7, 5-20-80; Ord. No. 81-38 § 5, 1-5-82) 
16-2.7   Sanitation Lien Book.
    The City Manager shall furnish a copy of each notice mailed pursuant to the provisions of subsection 16-2.5 to the Department of Finance and the Director of Finance shall cause to be entered into a book kept for that purpose, designated as "Sanitation Lien Book" the information contained in such notice, to wit: The legal description of the property, the name of the owner, the date of the notice. Thereafter, the Director of Finance shall cause to be entered into such book at the place where the foregoing information is recorded the date of completion of the work, the date of publication of notice of completion, the final cost of such work, the aforesaid administrative fee, which shall be the amount of the lien against the property. 
(1957 Code § 10-30; Ord. No. 61-15 § 6, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 63-25 § 3, 12-3-63; Ord. No. 80-24 § 3, 5-6-80; Ord. No. 85-5 § 3, 3-5-85) 
16-2.8   Work by City, Publication of Notice of Lien.
    As soon as practicable after completion of the work by City or by any party contracting with the City for such purpose, the City Manager shall cause to be filed with the Department of Finance a statement of costs, the aforesaid administrative fee and a certification of the completion of the work and the date of completion. The Director of Finance shall, thereafter, cause to be published in a newspaper of qualified circulation under the laws of the State of Florida to publish legal notices in Miami-Dade County a notice to the owner which notice shall contain a description of the property, the cost of the work performed, the aforesaid administrative fee, the date upon which the work was completed, and the claim by the City of a lien upon the property for the amount of such cost. 
(1957 Code § 10-31; Ord. No. 61-15 § 7, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 63-25 § 4, 12-3-63; Ord. No. 80-24 § 4, 5-6-80; Ord. No. 85-5 § 4, 3-5-85) 
16-2.9   Procedure for Protesting the Amount of Cost Incurred by City to Correct Condition.
    The cost of clearing such lands or removing or remedying the condition thereof, found to be violative of this section and the aforesaid administrative fee shall be and become a lien against such lands and properties, to the same extent and character as the lien for special assessments, as of the date of completion of the work by the City; provided, that any person owning all or any interest in the property shall have the right at any time within thirty (30) days after publication of the notice of completion of work aforesaid to present to the City Clerk a sworn petition stating his or her interest in the property and alleging that in the opinion of the petitioner the cost of the work as entered in said Sanitation Lien Book exceeds the actual cost thereof or is otherwise erroneous. Such petition shall be thereupon presented to the Council for its consideration at its next regular meeting, at which time and place the Council shall consider the same and make due inquiry into the question involved, and if it shall appear to the satisfaction of the Council that the cost as entered is erroneous, then the Council shall by ordinance so declare and shall have entry thereof in the Sanitation Lien Book corrected, and shall fix and confirm the amount to be charged against such lot, parcel, tract of land or swale area as it shall find just and proper, and the amount so fixed shall stand as the amount of the lien, effective as of the date of completion of the work aforesaid; or the Council may confirm the lien in the amount as originally entered in the sanitation lien book. 
(1957 Code § 10-32; Ord. No. 61-15 § 8, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 80-24 § 5, 5-6-80; Ord. No. 81-38 § 6, 1-5-82; Ord. No. 85-5 § 5, 3-5-85) 
16-2.10   Payment of Cost Due Thirty Days After Publication of Notice; Sale of Delinquent Liens.
    The lien for the cost of clearing such lots, parcels, tracts of land or swale area, or of removing or remedying the condition thereof found to be violative of this section, shall become due and payable thirty (30) days after publication of the notice of completion of such work, except in cases wherein a petition is filed within such period as aforesaid, and where, upon consideration of such petition, the Council has changed and corrected the amount of lien as entered in the Sanitation Lien Book, and in such cases the lien shall become due and payable thirty (30) days after such Council action. After the respective due dates above fixed all unpaid liens shall become delinquent and shall thereafter bear interest at the rate of twelve (12%) percent per annum until sold at the next annual tax sale of this City, at which time and thereafter the liens shall be subject to the same charges and penalties as provided by law in the case of general City taxes. All delinquent liens shall be offered for sale at the annual tax sale of the City next following the date of delinquency. 
(1957 Code § 10-33; Ord. No. 61-15 § 9, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 81-38 § 7, 1-5-82) 
16-2.11   Terms of Payment for Costs Exceeding Two Hundred Dollars.
    The lien for the cost of clearing any lot, parcel, tract of land or swale area, or of removing or remedying the condition thereof found to be violative of this section, if the same is in excess of two hundred ($200.00) dollars may be paid in two (2) equal installments, due respectively on November 1 following the due date prescribed above, and on November 1 of the year following, provided that the owner or owners of the lot, parcel, tract of land or swale area shall file with the City Manager, on or before the said due date, a written undertaking waiving any and all irregularities or illegality in connection with the imposing of such lien. Such deferred installments shall bear interest at the rate of ten (10%) percent per annum from and after the due date of the lien, but any lien or installment thereof may be paid at any time when accompanied by the payment of interest due upon the entire unpaid balance of the lien to date of payment. Failure to pay any such installment when the same shall become due shall, without notice or other proceeding, cause the entire unpaid balance of said lien to become due and payable forthwith, provided that if before said lien is sold at an annual tax sale the amount of such delinquency and all interest upon the entire unpaid balance is paid, then the further installment or installments shall again be due and payable at the time set forth in said written undertaking. 
(1957 Code § 10-34; Ord. No. 61-15 § 10, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 81-38 § 8, 1-5-82; Ord. No. 85-5 § 6, 3-5-85) 
16-2.12   Penalties for Violations.
    Any person, association or persons, co-partnership or corporation, violating any of the provisions of this section, upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine not exceeding two hundred fifty ($250.00) dollars, or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, within the discretion of the appropriate tribunal. 
(1957 Code § 10-35; Ord. No. 61-15 § 11, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 91-6 § 2, 3-5-91) 
16-3 - PROCEDURE FOR SALE OF LIENS. 
16-3.1   Official Record.
    The City Manager shall see that there shall be kept in the office of the Comptroller an official record of the City of North Miami Beach indicating all properties from which delinquent fees are owed pursuant to Section 19-5 and Section 16-2 of the Code of Ordinances. Such record shall include the legal description of the property, the name of the record owner, the amount of the monies delinquent and owing the City of North Miami Beach, the date and nature of services provided by the City of North Miami Beach to cause monies to be due and owing the City of North Miami Beach. 
a.  Residential. The amount of collection fee imposed by this subsection is hereby declared to be a debt due to the City, and any person required under the terms of this section to have accumulation of garbage, trash and garden trash removed and disposed of by the City shall be liable to the City for the amount of applicable collection fee due therefor, and such fee shall be recoverable in any court of competent jurisdiction. In the case of garbage, trash and/or garden trash, the cost of collection or the amount of collection fee shall constitute a lien against the premises to the same extent and character as the lien for special assessments, and with the same penalties and with the same rights of collection, foreclosure, sale and forfeiture as obtained for special assessment liens, and may be handled in the same manner by the City. 
b.  Commercial. The amount of collection fee imposed by this subsection is hereby declared to be a debt due to the City and any person required under the terms of this section to have accumulation of garbage, trash and garden trash removed and disposed of by the City shall be liable to the City for the amount of applicable collection fee due therefor, and such fee shall be recoverable in any court of competent jurisdiction. In the case of garbage, trash and/or garden trash, the cost of collection or the amount of collection fee shall constitute a lien against the premises to the same extent and character as the lien for special assessments, and with the same penalties and with the same rights of collection, foreclosure, sale and forfeiture as obtained for special assessment liens, and may be handled in the same manner by the City. 
(1957 Code § 10-46; Ord. No. 76-30 § 1, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 1, 5-2-78) 
16-3.2   Notification of Property Owner of Delinquency; Filing of Lien.
    November 1 of each year shall be used as the due date for payment of real estate taxes, pursuant to Chapter 197 of the Florida Statutes. If the taxes upon any real estate shall not be paid on or before April 1 of the following year, the City Manager at that time, shall in writing, advertise and sell such real estate in the following manner: He shall make out a statement of all such real estate, specifying the amount due on each parcel, and shall keep the same on file in his office subject to public inspection. He shall also in writing, advise each record property owner that fees are delinquent and due and owing the City of North Miami Beach. Thereafter, the City Manager shall cause liens to be filed with the Clerk of the Circuit Court of Miami-Dade County against all properties listed in the aforementioned record book kept with the City Clerk along with a notice of lien to each record property owner. 
(1957 Code § 10-47; Ord. No. 76-30 § 2, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 1, 5-2-78) 
16-3.3   Publication of Notice.
    The City Manager shall cause to be published a notice of sale for delinquent taxes once each week for four (4) consecutive weeks in newspapers published in Miami-Dade County, Florida, or the City of North Miami Beach stating that all lots and lands delinquent for nonpayment of lawfully imposed taxes or local assessments will be offered for sale any time after May 1 of that year at the time specified in such notice. A complete list of such delinquent lots and lands is available in the office of the City Clerk of the City of North Miami Beach. The above sale of liens shall continue until such time as specified by the laws of the State of Florida. 
(1957 Code § 10-48; Ord. No. 76-30 § 3, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 1, 5-2-78) 
16-3.4   Filing of Copies of Advertisements.
    Copies of all of the advertisements herein provided shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk within ten (10) days after the last publication. 
(Ord. No. 76-30 § 4, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 2, 5-2-78; 1957 Code § 10-49) 
16-3.5   Sale.
    On the day designated in the notice of sale, the City Manager or his agent shall commence at 12:00 noon the sale of those lands which have delinquent fees assessed as aforesaid, and such sale shall continue from day to day until the proceeds from the sales are sufficient to pay the fees assessed against the real property in question. 
(1957 Code § 10-50; Ord. No. 76-30 § 5, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 3, 5-2-78) 
16-3.6   Payment by Purchaser.
    The purchaser of any lien certificate shall be required to make immediate payment to the City of North Miami Beach within twenty-four (24) hours. The City Manager may cancel the bid of any purchaser of a lien certificate that fails to tender full payment within twenty-four (24) hours to the City of North Miami Beach. If any purchaser of a certificate of lien neglects or refuses to make full payment for such certificate, the City Manager may refuse to accept any other bid of such purchaser or his agent during the aforementioned sale. Any certificate of lien that is not paid for in full within twenty-four (24) hours after the close of the sale shall be deemed to have been sold to the City in the same manner as heretofore described, and a certificate of lien thereof shall be issued to the City in the same manner as if the certificate had in the first instance been sold to the City. 
(1957 Code § 10-51; Ord. No. 76-30 § 6, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 4, 5-2-78) 
16-3.7   Listing of Liens Sold.
    Immediately after the sale of liens heretofore described, the City Manager shall direct that a list of all certificate of liens sold be certified and delivered to the Miami-Dade County Tax Collector for redemption purposes along with what other forms which may be required by the Miami-Dade County Tax Collector. A copy of the list shall be retained by the City Manager and another copy shall be filed with the Clerk of the Circuit Court of Miami-Dade County, Florida. Each list shall contain the date of sale of each lien certificate, the number of each lien certificate, the value received and the interest bid for each lien certificate, the legal description of lands for which said fee are owing, the name and address of the purchaser of each lien certificate, and an addendum to each list stating that the aforementioned sale was con-ducted according to law. 
(1957 Code § 10-52; Ord. No. 76-30 § 7, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 5, 5-2-78) 
16-3.8   Award of Certificate of Lien; Required Deposit.
    The City Manager shall ensure that only the person bidding the lowest interest rate within the maximum legal rate of eighteen (18%) percent allowed by law shall be awarded a certificate of lien, and that all bidders shall be required prior or simultaneously to actual bidding, to make a deposit of ten (10%) percent of the value of the lien for which they intend to bid and that such successful bidder's deposit is nonrefundable and may be used at the discretion of the City of North Miami Beach, provided that no law or Statute holds to the contrary, to insure the purchase of all lien certificates put up for public sale. 
(1957 Code § 10-53; Ord. No. 76-30 § 8, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 6, 5-2-78) 
16-3.9   Compliance With Section.
    The City Manager shall ensure that the successful bidder complying with all provisions expressed in this section and any other lawfully imposed requirements shall be awarded a certificate of lien expressing the amount of the bidder's interest and the real property to which the bidder has bid on, and the amount of interest accepted by the bidder. 
(1957 Code § 10-54; Ord. No. 76-30 § 9, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 7, 5-2-78) 
16-3.10   Redemption.
    The exclusive office for the redemption of said lien certificates shall be the Miami-Dade County Tax Collector in conformity with the laws of the State of Florida. 
(1957 Code § 10-55; Ord. No. 76-30 § 10, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 8, 5-2-78) 
16-3.11   Authority of Section.
    The provisions of this section are hereby expressed to be the exclusive guidelines by which lawfully imposed liens by the City of North Miami Beach on real property may be sold to the public at large. Except as herein otherwise provided, the General Laws and Statutes of the State of Florida governing and providing the method and procedure of and for the enforcement of collection of taxes shall be and remain in full force and effect to all intents and purposes as if the same were in this chapter incorporated and set forth at length. 
(1957 Code § 10-56; Ord. No. 76-30 § 11, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 1, 5-2-78) 
16-4 - LIEN RESEARCH: CHARGES. 
    There shall be a service charge of fifty ($50.00) dollars for preparing a written confirmation of any lien amounts owed to the City of North Miami Beach on properties subject to lien by the City for any reason. The written confirmation will be prepared in a reasonable amount of time. Expedited service (within one working day) will result in an additional charge of one hundred ($100.00) dollars. Nonverbal replies can be given. 
(1957 Code § 13-41B; Ord. No. 94-8 § 2, 4-5-94; Ord. No. 2007-9, 9-18-07) 
CHAPTER XVII - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- For various aspects of the City's authority over streets and sidewalks, see Charter § 21. 

17-1 - PERMIT TO CONVEY GARBAGE OVER STREETS. 
17-1.1   Permit Required.
    It shall be unlawful to remove or convey or cause or permit to remove or convey any garbage or other offensive material, trash, trees, fronds, vegetable matter, paper or material of like nature upon or along any public street or alley in the City without securing a permit. 
(Ord. No. 135 § 1, 5-20-47; 1957 Code § 19-1) 
Cross reference- Garbage, trash, etc., generally, Ch. XVIII. 
17-1.2   Prerequisite to Issuance of Permit.
    Permits shall be issued by the Building Department upon proof that the vehicle in which the material is to be conveyed is so constructed that none of the material can fall therefrom and litter the streets within the City. 
(Ord. No. 135 § 2, 5-20-47; 1957 Code § 19-2) 
17-1.3   Refusal by Building Department to Issue.
    In the event the Building Department is in doubt as to whether or not such permit should be issued, the Building Department shall refuse to issue such permit, and application therefor shall be made directly to the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 135 § 3, 5-20-47; 1957 Code § 19-3) 
17-2 - CUTTING OR TUNNELING UNDER STREETS. 
17-2.1   When Cutting Permitted; Approval of City Engineer Required.
    The cutting of streets, alleys, sidewalks and/or rights-of-way for any purpose whatsoever is hereby prohibited by the City, except upon certification by the Engineer of Record that the terrain is such that the street, alley sidewalk or right-of-way cannot be tunneled. A permit for cutting or tunneling shall not be issued by the Building Department without the consent of the City Engineer. 
(Ord. No. 615 §§ 1, 6, 12-11-56; Ord. No. 60-123 § 1, 11-15-60; 1957 Code § 19-4) 
17-2.2   Permit Application; Issuance and Fee.
    Application for the tunneling or cutting of City streets, alleys, sidewalks, and/or rights-of-way shall be made to the Building Department, as set fourth in subsection 17-2.1. A permit fee of seventy-five ($75.00) dollars for the first one hundred (100) feet or less and thirty ($30.00) dollars for each additional linear foot shall be charged for the purpose of the additional cost of maintaining such streets, sidewalks and rights-of-way so cut or tunneled. 
(Ord. No. 615 § 2, 12-11-56; Ord. No. 60-123 § 2, 11-15-60; 1957 Code § 19-5) 
17-2.3   Cash or Surety Bond.
    Applicants for such street or sidewalk cutting or tunneling shall file simultaneously with such application a cash or surety bond equivalent in amount to the costs of the repair, repaving or resurfacing of the streets, alleys, sidewalks or rights-of-way caused by such tunneling or cutting. Such cash bond to be returned or surety bond to be canceled when the repairs have been constructed to the satisfaction of the City Engineer; provided further that the repairs shall be effectuated within the time specified by the City Engineer; and in the failure thereof, the City shall have the right to make such repairs and deduct the costs thereof from the cash bond or to make demand upon the surety bond for same, whichever is applicable. 
(Ord. No. 615 § 3, 12-11-56; 1957 Code § 19-6) 
17-2.4   Notification of Police Department Required.
    Upon a permit being issued by the Building Department for the cutting or tunneling of City streets, alleys, sidewalks, or rights-of-way, the applicant shall inform the Police Department. The Police Department shall provide for the necessary safety precautions and time limitations for the closing of the cut or the completion of the tunneling. Fees to cover personnel overtime, and other expenses, if necessary, shall be assessed by the Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 615 § 4, 12-11-56; 1957 Code § 19-7) 
17-2.5   Freeing City of Liability.
    Applicants for such street or sidewalk cutting or tunneling shall release the City from all liability, criminal or civil, and damages to any person or property and forever holding the City free from such liability due to injury or harm to person or property caused by the street or sidewalk cutting or tunneling. 
(Ord. No. 615 § 5, 12-11-56; 1957 Code § 19-8) 
17-2.6   Repair Specifications.
    The following are the specifications for the repair of the street, alley or sidewalk when cut, to-wit: 
    Backfill: Trench shall be filled with clean fill, in layers of six (6) inches, each layer being thoroughly compacted and watered, to a level of eight (8) inches plus the thickness of the existing asphalt pavement below the existing road surface compacted to ninety-five (95%) percent of maximum density per lift or layer. The remaining trench is then brought to grade or level with the existing lime rock base with a minimum of eight (8) inches of lime rock compacted to ninety-eight (98%) percent of maximum density. Lime rock base shall be primed with RC-70 tack coat or equal, then a minimum first lift of one and one-half (11/2) inch of Type S-1 structural course asphaltic concrete, rolled laterally and longitudinally and a minimum second lift of one and one-half (11/2) inch of S-3 wearing course asphaltic concrete. For asphalt roadway pavement with less than three (3) inches of thickness, a minimum of one and half (11/2) inches lift to match the finish grade of the existing pavement, rolled laterally and longitudinally shall be required. Asphalt pavement must extend a minimum of one (1) foot on top of undisturbed lime rock base on both sides of the trench. Edges of existing asphalt pavement must be cut in a straight line. Option to use flowable fill shall be approved by the City Engineer. Consult with City Engineer for standard specification for restoration of trench and roadways. Restoration shall be minimum one full lane if the trench is parallel to the roadway or minimum 10 feet if perpendicular or crossing the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 615 § 7, 12-11-56; 1957 Code § 19-9) 
17-2.7   Open Excavations; Maintenance of Traffic Required.
    During the time while any such operations are being carried on as provided in subsection 17-2.1, the person to whom a permit shall have been granted shall be responsible to safely secure the site by use of City approved barricades and night time warning light(s) so as to apprise users of the street or sidewalk of the location of such excavation. Maintenance of Traffic plans shall be submitted and approved by the City Engineer. 
(Ord. No. 214 § 2, 7-15-50; 1957 Code § 19-10) 
17-2.8   Swale-Contour in Driveway Construction.
    In the construction of driveways swale-contour shall be followed. Should such a procedure not be feasible or necessary, in the opinion of the City Engineer, then some suitable means such as a culvert or a stormwater drainage system shall be constructed to manage excess storm water. 
(Ord. No. 536 § 2, 4-3-56; 1957 Code § 19-11) 
17-3 - STREET CONSTRUCTION[2] 
17-3.1   Construction to Comply with this Section.
    All streets constructed in the City shall be constructed in accordance with the specifications set out in this section. 
(Ord. No. 377 § 1, 9-21-54; 1957 Code § 19-12) 
17-3.2   Plans; Approval, Contents.
    No street or alley shall be constructed in the City unless and until a plan, or a working drawing, for construction thereof has been approved by the City Engineer. Plans shall be prepared by qualified engineers duly licensed in the State of Florida. Plans shall have the route and all necessary lines, grades, elevations, dimensions and notes pertaining to the streets shown thereon, per City and Miami-Dade County standards and specifications. Concrete curb and valley gutter (Type "F") and stormwater disposal management or drainage system shall also be required and approved by the City Engineer. 
(Ord. No. 377 § 3, 9-21-54; 1957 Code § 19-13) 
17-3.3   Changing Composition of Swale; Permit Required.
    The removal, modification, or changing of the context, elevation or composition of the swale of any roads or streets within the City by any person unless first obtaining a permit from the City Building Department and exhibiting to the Department in writing the type of change and the reason therefor, shall be unlawful. The Building Department of the City shall have the discretion to either affirm or deny the request for a permit. 
(Ord. No. 562 § 1, 6-26-56; 1957 Code § 19-14) 
17-3.4   Permit and Inspection Fees; Hiring Inspector.
a.  A permit fee shall be required. Said permit fee shall be the greater of two hundred ($200.00) dollars for construction of the first one hundred (100) lineal feet or less, and an additional fifty ($50.00) dollars for each additional one hundred (100) lineal feet or fraction thereof in connection with street paving and/or sidewalk construction work on any street or highway lying in the circumscribed area of the City. 
    Or, alternatively, the permit fee will be based on a fair market value of the construction improvements. A sliding scale shall be utilized for assessing such permit fee: First at two (2%) percent of fair market value for the first one hundred thousand ($100,000.00) dollars of value, then one and three quarters (13/4%) percent of fair market value for that portion of value between one hundred thousand and one ($100,001.00) dollars and five hundred thousand ($500,000.00) dollars then one and one-half (11/2%) percent for any portion of value over five hundred thousand and one ($500,001.00) dollars whichever is greater. 
    Calculation of permit fees for new construction shall be based on the construction value as determined by the latest edition of "Square Foot Costs" published by R.S. Means Company, Inc. A verified contract, which includes all systems, may be used to determine estimated construction costs (including all subtrades) with the approval of the Building Official. A copy of the signed construction contract stating the construction cost of the work must be submitted along with permit applications involving a contractor. 
    The minimum permit fee shall be two hundred ($200.00) dollars. 
b.  The City inspection services required with the issued permit are included in the permit fee. A fee of sixty ($60.00) dollars shall be assessed for each required re-inspection. 
c.  The inspections shall be performed by the City Building Department or by the City Engineer. 
(Ord. No. 395.1 § 1, 10-31-56; 1957 Code § 19-15) 
17-3.5   Road Designations; Width, Base Materials.
a.  Designation. All municipal roads in the City of North Miami Beach shall follow the road designations of Miami-Dade County road design and construction shall conform to all the requirements, standard construction details and specifications from the Miami-Dade County Public Works Manual and all current amendments and supplements thereto. 
17-3.6   Street and Sidewalk Construction, Subject to Miami-Dade County Public Works Standards.
    All street, driveway and sidewalk construction in the City shall meet all the requirements of the applicable provisions of the current edition of the Miami-Dade County Public Works Manual and all current amendments and supplements thereto as of the date of publication of request for bids where such work is to be performed for the City and as of the date of commencement of construction where the work is to be performed by or on behalf of any owner or person, firm, or corporation other than the City. 
(Ord. No. 64-44 § 1, 11-17-64; 1957 Code § 19-17) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- As to the financing of construction, see §§ 31 and 32. 

17-4 - CONSTRUCTION OF ROADS IN NEW SUBDIVISIONS. 
17-4.1   New Subdivisions; Agreement and Bond Required.
