    Unless specifically waived by the City Council in the resolution accepting and approving any particular plat, all persons submitting any plat to the Planning and Zoning Board for the subsequent acceptance and approval of the City Council shall accompany such proposed plat with an agreement providing for the construction of streets, including curbing, landscaping and storm water drainage system approved by the City Engineer along the full length of all streets shown thereon. All streets shall be included in the dedicatory provision set forth on the plat or in any separate dedicatory instrument to be filed therewith. The agreement shall be accompanied by a surety bond in the penal sum of not less than one hundred and ten (110%) percent of the estimated cost of such construction. The agreement and bond shall be on forms approved by the Engineer of Record and furnished by the City Clerk. The condition of the bond shall be such that if the principal shall fully and faithfully perform all the terms and conditions of the principal's agreement and within the time therein specified, then the same shall be void, otherwise the City shall have the right to construct such streets, or, at its option, to cause the same to be constructed pursuant to public advertisement and receipt and acceptance of bonds. The principal and surety jointly and severally shall agree to pay and indemnify the City, upon completion by the City, the final total cost of such construction, including, but not limited to engineering, legal and contingent costs together with any damages, either direct or consequential, which the City may sustain on account of the failure of the principal to comply with the terms of such agreement. 
(Ord. No. 377 § 4.1, 9-21-54; 1957 Code § 19-21) 
17-4.2   Combining with Sidewalk Agreement and Bond.
    The agreement and performance bond for construction of streets required by this section may be combined with the agreement and performance bond for the construction of sidewalks, alleys and other rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 377 § 4.3, 9-21-54; 1957 Code § 19-22) 
Cross reference- See § 17-5.16 for identical provision as to sidewalk contracts. 
17-4.3   Time for Performance.
    The agreement shall provide for the construction of streets at the City's option from and after the date of the approval of any such plat by the City Council; provided, however, the City Council may in case of unusual circumstances, extend the time for completion of such construction for a period not to exceed an additional six (6) months; provided, the principal first obtains and furnishes the City Council with the surety's written consent to such extension. 
(Ord. No. 377 § 4.2, 9-21-54; 1957 Code § 19-23) 
17-4.4   Requirements as to Existing Platted Areas.
    This section shall not apply to the construction of any building whether residential, business or otherwise, by any person on any lot or tract which is situated in an area which has been duly platted prior to the enactment of this section, except that if a street is nonexistent, or if the existing street is in a condition which will necessitate repaving or extensive general repairs within a period of five (5) years, and such is verified by the City Engineer, along the full frontage width of the lot or tract for which the building permit or permits are sought, then in that event it shall be mandatory that a street including curbing, landscaping and storm water drainage system be constructed along the frontage width of the lot or tract; and no building permits shall be issued for the construction of any building, whether residential, business or otherwise, when such a condition exists, unless and until the person applying for such permit either constructs such a street including curbing, landscaping and storm water drainage system along such full frontage or enters into an agreement with the City, providing for the construction of such a street. The agreement shall provide, among other things, that before a certificate of occupancy will be issued, construction of the street shall be completed in accordance with the specifications set forth in this section, and in accordance with plans approved by the City Engineer pursuant to subsection 17-3.6 hereof; provided, however, that upon application of the owner of the property, the City Building Department, in its sole discretion and for good cause shown, may authorize the issuance of a certificate of occupancy without construction and completion of such street upon the condition that the owner shall execute and deliver to the City Community Development Department an agreement (together with the deposit as referred to therein and an amount sufficient to pay the cost of its recording). The form for such agreement is set out in this section and marked Exhibit No. 1. 
(Ord. No. 377 § 4.4, 9-21-54; 1957 Code § 19-24) 
17-4.5   City's Option to Construct.
    If the City exercises its option to construct a street in accordance with such agreement, the City Community Development Department shall cause written notice thereof to be sent to the property owner not less than ten (10) days prior to commencement of construction; provided, however, the failure to give such notice shall not invalidate or in any way impair the City's lien afforded by the foregoing agreement or the property owner's obligation to pay for the street. Such notice shall specify the estimated cost of construction. If, within such ten (10) day period, the property owner obtains a commitment from a qualified contractor licensed in the City for construction of the street at a price less than the estimate specified in the notice, a contract for the work shall be awarded to such contractor. 
(Ord. No. 377 § 4.5, 9-21-54; 1957 Code § 19-25) 
17-4.6   Sample-Agreement Form.
"AGREEMENT 
    THESE PRESENT WITNESS: That in consideration of the issuance by City of North Miami Beach, Florida, a Certificate of Occupancy for the following described premises: 
___________ 
___________ 
___________ 
___________ 
    The undersigned as owner(s) thereof have deposited with the City, and the City hereby acknowledges receipt of the sum of $_____, which is an amount equivalent to one hundred ten (110%) percent of the estimated cost of constructing a street along the full frontage width of said premises computed at the estimated cost per lineal foot of frontage width. 
    It is agreed that the City shall hold this sum in a special fund or account for a period not to exceed ten (10) years for the purpose of paying the cost of constructing and completing such streets in accordance with the requirements and specifications set forth in Section 17-3 and Section 17-4, Chapter XVII, Code of Ordinances of the City. The City hereby reserving the option to cause such streets to be constructed and completed within such period and at such time as in its sole discretion it is deemed proper so to do; provided, however, that the owner(s) or successors in title may at their election so construct and complete such streets, in which event, upon application, the City will refund the deposit to the owner(s) or successors in title. 
    If, under its option, the City causes such streets to be constructed, it will pay the cost thereof out of the deposit and, upon application, will refund any excess to the owner(s) or successors in title. 
    If, at the expiration of ten (10) years, the City has not exercised its option to construct and complete such streets, it shall, upon application, refund the deposit to the owner(s) or successors in title. 
    The written receipt of the person to whom any refund is made under the terms of this agreement shall constitute a full and complete discharge of any and all liability of the City to any and all persons. 
    If the City under its option shall cause the street to be constructed and completed, and the cost thereof exceeds the amount of the deposit herein mentioned, the owner(s) or successors in title as the case may be, within ten (10) days after the mailing of a written demand therefor, shall pay such excess to the City, and in the event of a failure so to do, the City may assess and enforce a lien against the premises for the amount of such excess, with interest at six (6%) percent per annum, it being agreed that any and all formalities, requirements of law or other conditions precedent to the making of such an assessment are hereby expressly waived. 
    As used herein, the term "OWNER(S)" means the person(s) who advanced the deposit herein mentioned. The term "SUCCESSORS IN TITLE" means the person(s) who, at the time referred to, are shown as the owner(s) of the property on the tax roll of the City.

(Ord. No. 377, 9-21-54; 1957 Code § 19-26) 
17-4.7   Subdividers or Builders Paving Streets to Comply with City Specifications.
    All subdividers or builders providing and paving their own streets within a subdivision shall comply with all specifications enacted by the City for such street paving, whether done by the City or the subdivider and builder, as heretofore provided. 
(Ord. No. 934 § 1, 10-22-58; 1957 Code § 19-26.1) 
17-4.8   Drainage Swale Required.
    In addition to subsection 17-4.7, such builder or subdivider shall provide a drainage swale on each shoulder of the pavement so designed and contoured and graded as to provide proper drainage or shall construct a storm water drainage system as determined and approved by the City Engineer as not to allow water to stand on the pavement itself. 
(Ord. No. 934 § 2, 10-22-58; 1957 Code § 19-26.2) 
17-4.9   Permit Required for Cutting Trench Through Paved Street.
    Any person, firm, or corporation desiring to cut a trench through an already paved street, shall first apply for a permit from the City Building Department to cut the street for a legitimate purpose; such as, the laying of utility pipes, and shall provide with such application a blueprint or drawing of such proposed street cutting for the City Engineer's approval. 
(Ord. No. 934 § 3, 10-22-58; 1957 Code § 19-26.3) 
17-4.10   Specifications for Resurfacing Street Where Cutting and Ditching Occurred.
    Option No. 1. Trench shall be filled with clean fill, in lifts or layers of six (6) inches, each layer being thoroughly compacted and watered, to a level of eight (8) inches plus the thickness of the existing asphalt pavement below the existing road surface compacted to ninety-five (95%) percent of maximum density per lift or layer. The remaining trench is then brought to grade or level with the existing lime rock base with a minimum of eight (8) inches of lime rock compacted to ninety-eight (98%) percent of maximum density. Lime rock base shall be primed with RC-70 tack coat or equal, then a minimum first lift of one and one-half (11/2) inch of Type S-1 structural course asphaltic concrete, rolled laterally and longitudinally and a mini-mum second lift of one and one-half (11/2) inch of S-3 wearing course asphaltic concrete. For asphalt roadway pavement with less than three (3) inches of thickness, a minimum of one and one-half (11/2) inches lift to match the finish grade of the existing pavement, rolled laterally and longitudinally shall be required. Asphalt pavement must extend a minimum of one (1) foot on top of undisturbed lime rock or both sides of the trench. Edges of existing asphalt pavement must be cut in a straight line with a saw. 
    Option to use flowable fill shall be approved by the City Engineer. Restoration shall be minimum one full lane if the trench is parallel to the roadway or minimum 10 feet if crossing the roadway. Option No. 2. City Engineer's approval needed. Applicant shall compact the fill firmly in lifts or layers of six (6) inches, compacted to ninety-five (95%) percent of maximum density per lift or layer, no closer than seven (7) inches to the surface of the street pavement, six (6) inches of which shall be filled with reinforced concrete extending no more than one (1) foot beyond both side edges of the pavement, which in turn shall be topped and finished level with the original paving by one (1) inch of first-grade asphaltic concrete. 
(Ord. No. 934 § 4, 10-22-58; 1957 Code § 19-26.4) 
17-4.11   Plans, Drawings, Permits and Documents to Accompany Application to be Approved.
    All blueprints, plans, and drawings, either for curbing, landscaping, and storm water drainage system, drainage swales on street shoulders or for street cuttings for laying of utility pipes, shall be clearly exemplified by drawings presented with the permit application to the Building Department and shall, in turn, be approved by the City Engineer prior to beginning of construction package must also include permits from government agencies and documents that are required by the City to approve the permit. Plans and documents shall be original copies, signed and sealed by a Florida certified engineer and/or landscape architect as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 934 § 5, 10-22-58; 1957 Code § 19-26.5) 
17-4.12   Inspection of Completed Drainage Swale or Street Cutting, Required; Application.
    Upon completion, either of the curbing, landscaping and storm water drainage system street paving with drainage swale attached or of the street cutting, the person, firm, or corporation doing the paving or street cutting, shall apply to the Building Department for an inspection, with the street paving or street cutting repair being acceptable to the City only upon approval of the City Engineer. 
(Ord. No. 934 § 6, 10-22-58; 1957 Code § 19-26.6) 
17-4.13   Sketch and Profile, Incorporated by Reference.
    An engineering sketch and profile showing a typical cross-section or a Standard Detailed Drawing of a street may be found on file in the Engineering Department or Building Department which by reference is incorporated into subsections 17-4.7 through 17-4.14 and which is hereby set as a standard with which substantial compliance must be had and made by those coming within the purview of said sections. 
(Ord. No. 934 § 8, 10-22-58; 1957 Code § 19-26.7) 
17-4.14   Penalty for Subsections 17-4.7-17-4.13.
    Violations of subsections 17-4.7-17-4.13, upon conviction in the appropriate tribunal, may, in the discretion of the appropriate tribunal, be punished pursuant to Section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 934 § 7, 10-22-58; 1957 Code § 19-26.8) 
17-5 - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION. 
17-5.1   Construction to Conform to Requirements.
    All sidewalks constructed in the City shall be constructed in accordance with the specifications for sidewalks as provided in subsections 17-5.2 through 17-5.14 and in accordance with plans or working drawings as provided in subsection 17-3.2 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 1, 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-27) 
17-5.2   Official Elevations; Conformity of Sidewalks.
    Sidewalk elevations shall be shown on the plans and shall not be less than the street center or crown of the road elevations. Sidewalk elevations may exceed the street center or crown of the road elevations only with the approval of the City Engineer, provided however, whenever sidewalks are constructed along any street not shown on such map, whether the same be newly laid out or otherwise, a street center elevation shall be established by the Engineer of Record with the approval of the City Engineer and the sidewalk elevation shall conform thereto. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 1.0, 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-28) 
17-5.3   Permit and Inspection Fees.
    Permit and inspection fees for sidewalks shall be calculated as is provided in subsection 17-3.4. 
17-5.4   Construction Methods.
a.  Excavations. Excavation will be made to the required depth and subgrade or base upon which the sidewalk is to be set shall be an even surface and compacted to a ninety-eight (98%) percent of maximum density. 
b.  Forms. Forms for this work shall be made of either wood or metal. They shall be straight, free from warp or bends and of sufficient strength, when staked, to resist the pressure of the concrete without springing. If of wood, they shall be of two (2) inch surfaced plank; if of metal, they shall be of approved section and shall have a flat surface on top. 
    Form shall have a depth equal to the plan dimensions for the depth of the concrete being deposited against them. 
c.  Concrete. The concrete shall be plant mixed Class I and shall attain a minimum compressive strength of three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch in twenty-eight (28) days. It shall be placed in the forms to the depth specified and tempered and spaded until mortar entirely covers its surface. 
d.  The forms shall be removed within twenty-four (24) hours after the concrete has been placed, and minor defects filled with mortar composed of one (1) part of Portland cement to two (2) parts of fine aggregate. 
e.  Joints. [3] Joints for sidewalks shall be of the open type. The joint shall be formed by staking a metal bulkhead in place and placing the concrete on both sides of it. After the concrete has set sufficiently to preserve the width and shape of the joint, the bulkhead shall be removed. After the sidewalk has been finished over the joint, the slot shall be opened and edged with a tool having a one-half (1/2) inch radius. After the concrete has hardened and become dry, the slot shall be thoroughly cleaned of all debris and loose material for the full section of the sidewalk. 
f.  Working of Surface. All surplus water, debris or inert material shall be worked off the surface of the concrete with a one (1) foot straight edge or by some other method equally as satisfactory, which may be approved by the Engineer of Record. 
g.  Finish. The concrete sidewalk shall then be given a wooden float finish. The surface variations shall not be more than one-fourth (1/4) inch on the five (5) foot transverse section. The edge of the sidewalk shall be carefully finished with an edging tool having a radius of one-half (1/2) inch. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2(1), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-30) 
17-5.5   Concrete.
a.  Scope. The work shall consist of furnishing all materials and equipment and performing the necessary labor to do all concrete work shown on the drawings and/or incidentals to the proper execution of the work as specified. 
b.  Materials. 
1.  Fine aggregate. Fine aggregate shall be clean, hard, strong, durable, uncoated particles of natural sand known as Lake Wales, Inter Lachen or approved equal, grades as follows:

2.  Coarse aggregate. Coarse aggregate shall consist of hard, tough, durable particles, free from adherent coatings and vegetable matter, and shall not contain soft, friable, thin or elongated particles in quantities considered deleterious by the engineers. Coarse aggregate shall be well graded from fine to coarse and shall conform to the following gradation:

3.  Cement. Portland cement shall conform to standard specifications for Portland cement, A.S.T.M. Designation C150-07, Type 1. Only one (1) brand of cement shall be used in any individual structure unless otherwise approved by the consulting engineers. Portland cement shall be tested in accordance with A.S.T.M. Designation C183-02, C-184, C187-04, C188-95, C190. 
4.  Water. The water used in mixing concrete will be fresh and clean, and free from injurious amounts of oil, acid, alkali or organic matter.

c.  Strength. The mixes shall be designed to secure concrete having the following minimum compressive strength at the age of seven (7) and twenty-eight (28) days as determined by breaking standard six (6) inch diameter by two (2) inch height test specimens in accordance with the procedure set forth in A.S.T.M. Designations C31/C31-06 and C39-03. 
    Test specimens, to determine whether the compressive strength of the concrete is in accordance with that specified above, will be taken by the Engineer of Record. The test cylinders shall be tested in a recognized commercial testing laboratory at the expense of the contractor, who shall furnish two (2) certified copies of the tests to the Engineer of Record. 
d.  Storage. 
1.  Cement. Immediately upon receipt at the site of the work, cement shall be stored in a thoroughly dry, weather-tight, properly ventilated building with adequate provisions for the prevention of the absorption of moisture. 
Storage shall permit easy access for inspection and definite identification of each shipment. 
2.  Aggregate. The fine aggregate and each size of the coarse aggregate shall be stored separately and in a manner to be free from drainage or waste and to avoid the inclusion of any foreign material in the concrete. Stock piles of coarse aggregates shall be built in horizontal layers to avoid segregation. 
e.  Proportioning. 
1.  Basis. All concrete materials shall be proportioned by weight prior to placing any concrete in the structure, trial design mixes shall be made and cylinders tested to determine the mix to be used for each type of concrete. The selected mix shall be submitted to the consulting engineers for approval. 
2.  Measurements. A one (1) cubic foot bag of Portland cement will be considered as ninety-four (94) pounds. 
3.  Control. The proportions and exact amounts of all material entering into the concrete shall be as determined in the approval trial mixes. The proportions may be changed when, in the opinion of the consulting engineers, such changes become necessary to overcome deficiencies and obtain the specified strength or other factors. Consistency in the field shall be measured by the slump test in accordance with A.S.T.M. Designation C143/C143M-05a. The slump shall fall within the following tabulation: 
Type of Structure Slump in inches Minimum Maximum (1) Massive sections, pavements and slabs on ground 11/2 4 (2) Heavy slabs, beams or walls 3 5 (3) Thin walls and columns, ordinary slabs or beams 31/2 6  
4.  Aggregate content. The total columns of aggregate to be used shall be that necessary to produce a dense mixture of the required workability. 
f.  Mixing and Placing. 
1.  Equipment. Concrete shall be mixed by a mechanical mixer, the rated capacity of which is one-half (1/2) cubic yards or more. The mixer shall be equipped with adequate facilities for accurate measurement and control of each of the materials entering the mixer, and for changing the proportions to conform to varying conditions of the work. The mixer shall include provisions to facilitate inspection of operation and shall be subject to the approval of the Engineer of Record. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2 (2-01-2-06), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-31) 
17-5.6   Width.
    The sidewalk shall be placed in width of five (5) feet unless otherwise noted on the plans, in all residential areas; and in widths of six (6) feet in commercial areas unless otherwise directed at the time application is made for the building permit. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2 (2-07), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-32) 
17-5.7   Slope.
    The sidewalk shall slope downwards away from the property, at the rate of one-fourth (1/4) inch per foot. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2 (2-08), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-33) 
17-5.8   Thickness.
    The sidewalks shall be four (4) inches thick in all cases, except for a distance of twelve (12) feet in front of driveways. The extent of the twelve (12) feet may be determined by measuring six (6) feet on either side of the center of the driveway, or, if relocation of driveway is desired by property owner, the twelve (12) feet may be located in field. The thickness of the twelve (12) feet section shall be six (6) inches. In commercial districts where vehicular traffic may cross the sidewalk, the thickness shall be six (6) inches. The specifications for thickness in these areas will be made at the time application is made for the building permit. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2 (2-09), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-34) 
17-5.9   Expansion Joints.
    Expansion joints shall be required to include not more than one hundred fifty (150) and not less than one hundred (100) square feet of sidewalk. Such joints will be required to conform with construction methods as outlined in subsection 17-5.4 of these specifications. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2(2-10), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-35) 
17-5.10   Rebuilding Driveways and Walkways.
    In cases where sidewalk construction follows driveway and walkway construction, driveways and walkways which will be disturbed to such an extent that they will not match the sidewalk or otherwise be broken, or damaged, shall be rebuilt so that the slope at entrance shall not exceed ten (10) degrees, or two (2) inches in one (1) foot. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2; (2-11), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-36) 
17-5.11   Sidewalks in Dangerous Condition Prohibited; Notice Required, Contents; Penalty.
a.  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or agent thereof of any walk, sidewalk or curb (i.e., the owner, occupant or agent thereof of any property to which such sidewalk is contiguous) to allow such walk or sidewalk to remain in such a condition as to be dangerous or detrimental to citizens on their property. 
b.  Notice. In case the surface of any walk or sidewalk in the City shall become so uneven as to make walking over it dangerous or detrimental, or if the curbing shall become decayed, worn out or broken, it shall be the duty of the City Engineer to notify the owner, and if the owner cannot be served, to notify the occupant, and if there is no occupant, then to notify the agent of the owner of the property to which the sidewalk is contiguous to repair such walk or sidewalk. 
c.  Contents of Notice. The notice required in paragraph b. above shall be in writing and allow such owner, agent or occupant thirty (30) days in which to repair such walk or sidewalk; shall describe the walk, sidewalk or curb to be repaired; and shall set forth that such walk, sidewalk or curb shall be repaired, if surface work is to be done, with the same material as such walk, sidewalk or curb was originally constructed, and if curbing is to be put in, with concrete; and shall be served, returned and filed in the office of the City Engineer. 
d.  Penalty. After the expiration of the thirty (30) days notice hereinabove provided, failure of the owner to comply with the notice shall be punishable by a fine of not to exceed fifty ($50.00) dollars or one (1) day in jail and each day that the violation shall continue to exist after the expiration of the thirty (30) days notice shall constitute a separate violation hereof. 
(Ord. No. 821 §§ 1-4, 3-4-58; 1957 Code § 19-36.1) 
17-5.12   Replacing Disturbed Property.
    Any private property such as survey stakes, fences, etc., disturbed or damaged by the contractor shall be immediately replaced. Any trees or shrubs partly or wholly in the sidewalk shall be relocated or disposed at the direction of the City Engineer. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2 (2-12), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-37) 
17-5.13   Berm.
    The berm shall consist of a firm, good material subject to the approval of the City Engineer. Removal of existing material and replacement by more satisfactory material may be directed by the City Engineer in the field. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2 (2-13), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-38) 
17-5.14   Clarifying Omitted Details.
    Any dimension details which are not covered in this specification can be clarified at the office of the Engineer of Record. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 2, (2-14), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-39) 
17-5.15   Plans; Preparation, Approval.
    No sidewalk shall be constructed in the City unless and until a plan, or working drawing, for construction thereof has been approved by the City Engineer. Plans shall be prepared by a qualified engineer duly licensed in the State. Plans shall show the route and all necessary lines, grades, elevations, dimensions and notes pertaining to the sidewalks shown thereon. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 3, 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-40) 
17-5.16   New Subdivisions; Agreement for Construction of Sidewalks.
a.  Surety Bond Required. Hereafter, unless specifically waived by the City Council in the resolution accepting and approving any particular plat, all persons submitting any plat to the Planning and Zoning Board for the subsequent acceptance and approval of the City Council shall accompany such proposed plat with an agreement providing for the construction of sidewalks along the full length of all streets shown thereon. At corner lots or tracts such agreement shall require construction of a sidewalk along both thoroughfares abutting said corner lots or tracts. The agreement shall provide, among other things, that before a certificate of occupancy will be issued on any structure, construction of the sidewalk shall be completed in accordance with the specifications set forth in subsections 17-5.2 through 17-5.14 and in accordance with plans approved by the consulting engineers pursuant to subsection 17-5.15. The agreement shall be accompanied by a surety bond in the penal sum of not less than one hundred ten (110%) percent of the estimated cost of such construction. The agreement and bond shall be on forms approved by the consulting engineers and furnished by the City Clerk. The condition of the bond shall be such that if the principal shall fully and faithfully perform all the terms and conditions of the principal's agreement and within the time therein specified, then the same shall be void, otherwise the City shall have the right to construct such sidewalks, or, at its option, to cause the same to be constructed pursuant to public advertisement and receipt and acceptance of bids. The principal and surety jointly and severally shall agree to pay and indemnify the City, upon completion by the City, the final total cost of such construction, including, but not limited to, engineering, legal and contingent costs together with any damages, either direct or consequential, which the City may sustain on account of the failure of the principal to comply with the terms of such agreement. All sidewalks shall be included in the dedicatory provision set forth on the plat or in any separate dedicatory instrument to be filed therewith. 
b.  Combining with Street and Alley Agreement and Bond. [4] The agreement and performance bond for construction of sidewalks required by paragraph a. may be combined with the agreement and performance bond for construction of streets, alleys and other rights-of-way. 
c.  Time for Performance. The agreement shall provide for the construction of sidewalks at the discretion of the City from and after the date of the approval of any such plat by the City Council; provided, however, the City Council may, in case of unusual circumstances, extend the time for completion of such construction for a period not to exceed an additional six (6) months from the inception date; provided, the principal first obtains and furnishes the City Council with the surety's written consent to such extension. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 4, 9-7-54; 1957 Code §§ 19-41-19-43) 
17-5.17   Sidewalk Installation Required Prior to Issuance of Certificate of Occupancy for New Construction; Council to Approve Exception upon Execution of Agreement with City; Sidewalk Installation Required in Commercial Area in Accordance with Florida Statutes Chapter 170 Providing for Levying and Collecting Special Assessments.
a.  Exceptions to Provisions; Council Approval of Exceptions Required. All persons whether owner, contractor, builder or developer submitting plans for the new construction of any building shall be required to install sidewalks along the full frontage width of the property and along the side of the property if it is a corner lot and there is an abutting thoroughfare if requested and required by the City; except, that if a sidewalk exists along the full frontage width of the lot or tract next contiguous to the lot or tract for which the building permit is sought, then in that event it shall be mandatory that a sidewalk be constructed along the full frontage width of the contiguous lot or tract; and no building permits shall be issued for the construction of any building, whether residential, business or otherwise when such a condition exists, unless and until the person applying for such permit either constructs such a sidewalk along such full frontage or enters into an agreement with the City providing for the construction of such a sidewalk. The agreement shall provide, among other things, that before a certificate of occupancy will be issued, construction of the sidewalk shall be completed in accordance with the specifications set forth in subsection 17-5.14 and in accordance with plans approved by the consulting engineers pursuant to subsection 17-5.15 hereof; provided, however, upon application of the owner of the property, the Council, in its sole discretion and for good cause shown, may authorize the issuance of a certificate of occupancy without construction and completion of such sidewalk upon the condition that the owner shall execute and deliver to the City Clerk an agreement, together with the deposit as referred to therein, and an amount sufficient to pay the cost of its recording. Such agreement form is set out in subsection 17-5.19. 
b.  Changes in Zoning or Land Use Variance; Sidewalk Installation Required. All persons or applicants granted a change in zoning or a land use variance on property which has existing construction shall be required to install proper sidewalks when no sidewalks exist at the property location. 
c.  Sidewalks Required; Major Alterations to Existing Building; Exception. All persons or applicants making major alterations or construction to existing buildings amounting to thirty-five (35%) percent or more of the assessed valuation shall be required to install proper sidewalks when no sidewalks exist at the property location, except in single-family residential areas. 
d.  Installation in Commercial Areas; Cost Borne by Special Assessments. The City may require the installation of sidewalks in all commercial areas in the City of North Miami Beach when installation would be in the best interest of the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the City. The cost of the sidewalk installation shall be borne by levying and collecting special assessments on the abutting, adjoining, contiguous or other specially benefited property in accordance with Chapter 170, Florida Statutes, and the procedures set forth therein. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 4(4.4), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-44 Ord. No. 80-1 § 2, 2-5-80; Ord. No. 83-11 § 2, 8-2-83) 
17-5.18   City's Option to Construct; Notice to Owner.
    If the City exercises its option to construct a sidewalk in accordance with such agreement, the City Community Development Department shall cause written notice thereof to be sent to the property owner not less than ten (10) days prior to commencement of construction; provided, however, the failure to give such notice shall not invalidate or in any way impair the City's lien afforded by the foregoing agreement or the property owner's obligation to pay for the sidewalk. Such notice shall specify the estimated cost of construction. If, within such ten (10) day period, the property owner obtains a commitment from a qualified contractor licensed in the City for construction of the sidewalk at a price less than the estimate specified in the notice, a contract for the work shall be awarded to such contractor. 
(Ord. No. 376 § 4 (4.4), 9-7-54; 1957 Code § 19-45) 
17-5.19   Agreement Form.
    The following shall be the form of the agreement contemplated by this section: 
"AGREEMENT 
    THESE PRESENT WITNESS: That in consideration of the issuance by the City of North Miami Beach, Florida, of a certificate of occupancy for the following described premises: 
___________ 
___________ 
___________ 
___________ 
    The undersigned as owner(s) thereof have deposited with the City, and the City hereby acknowledges receipt of the sum of $_____, which is an amount equivalent to one hundred ten (110%) percent of the estimated cost of constructing a sidewalk along the full frontage width of said premises computed at a construction cost of $_____ per lineal foot of frontage width.

17-6 - DISCHARGE OF POLLUTANTS, SEDIMENTS AND EROSION FROM LAND-DISTURBING ACTIVITY. 
17-6.1   Prohibition of Illegal Discharges to Watercourses from Construction Activities.
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4), storm water drainage system and watercourses any materials, including but not limited to pollutants or waters containing any pollutants that cause or contribute to a violation of applicable water quality standards, other than storm water unless otherwise approved and permitted by the City. 
    The commencement, conduct or continuance of any illegal discharge to the storm water drainage system is prohibited except as described as follows: 
a.  The following discharges are exempt from discharge prohibitions established by this section: water line flushing or other potable water sources, landscape irrigation or lawn watering, diverted stream flows, rising ground water, ground water infiltration to storm drains, uncontaminated pumped ground water, foundation or footing drains (not including active groundwater dewatering systems), crawl space pumps, air conditioning condensation, springs, non-commercial washing of vehicles, natural riparian habitat or wet-land flows, dechlorinated swimming pools (typically less than one PPM chlorine), fire fighting activities, and any other water source not containing pollutants. 
b.  Discharges specified in writing by the authorized enforcement agency as being necessary to protect public health and safety. 
c.  Dye testing is an allowable discharge, but requires a verbal notification to the authorized enforcement agency prior to the time of the test. 
d.  The prohibition shall not apply to any non-storm water discharge permitted under an NPDES permit, waiver, or waste discharge order issued to the discharger and administered under the authority of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, provided that the discharger is in full compliance with all requirements of the permit, waiver, or order and other applicable laws and regulations and provided that written approval has been granted for any discharge to the storm drain system. 
17-6.2   General Requirements.
a.  All tracts or any persons shall not intentionally or unintentionally discharge pollutants into a lake or watercourse and must provide adequate pollution control measures, structures, devices in accordance with this section. 
b.  Erosion and Sedimentation Control Measures. All land-disturbing activities, including those that disturb less than an acre, shall provide adequate erosion control measures, structures, or devices in accordance with this section. 
c.  Plan Required. No person shall initiate, direct, allow or conduct any land-disturbing activity on a tract that meets any of the following criteria without having copy of an approved Erosion and Sedimentation Control Plan on the job site or a plan approved by the City Engineer with performance reservations on the job site. 
1.  Uncovers one (1) acre or more. 
2.  Disturbed area greater than one (1) acre. 
d.  Protection of Property. Persons conducting land-disturbing activity shall take all reasonable measures to protect all public and private property from damage caused by such activity and associated sedimentation. 
e.  More Restrictive Rules Shall Apply. Whenever conflicts exist between Federal, State or local laws, ordinances or rules, the more restrictive provision shall apply. 
f.  A Construction Generic Permit/Notice of Intent (CGP/NOI) shall also be required from the Florida Department of Environmental Protection for all land-disturbing activities of one (1) acre or more. 
CHAPTER XVIII - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Miami-Dade County Charter reference- For provisions enacted by the Miami-Dade County Commission relating to garbage and trash, see Ch. 15 of the Code of Miami-Dade County, Florida. 
Cross reference- Permit to convey garbage over city streets, § 17-1. 

18-1 - DEFINITIONS. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    Construction debris shall mean materials generally considered to be not water soluble and nonhazardous in nature, including, but not limited to, steel, glass, brick, concrete, asphalt, roofing material, pipe, gypsum wallboard, and lumber, from the construction or destruction of a structure as part of a construction or demolition project, and including rocks, soils, tree remains, trees, and other vegetative matter which normally results from land clearing or land development operations for a construction project, including such debris from construction of structures at a site remote from the construction or demolition project site. 
    Dwelling unit shall mean each unit with cooking facilities wherein resides a family, and every individual apartment in a multiple family building shall be considered a separate dwelling unit. 
    Garbage shall mean every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in, or storage of, meats, fish, fowl, fruit, or vegetables, and any other matter, of any nature whatsoever, which is subject to decay and the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which, during or after decay, may serve as breeding or feeding materials for flies or other germ-carrying insects; and any bottles, cans or other containers which due to their ability to retain water, may serve as breeding places for mosquitoes or other water-breeding insects. Any materials defined by Section 403.703, Florida Statutes, as Biomedical Waste, Biological Waste, Hazardous Substance, or Hazardous Waste shall not be considered garbage for purposes of this chapter. 
    Garbage can shall mean a ninety (90) or three hundred (300) gallon container or commercial one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), six (6) or eight (8) cubic yard container provided by the City. 
    Trash shall mean tree branches or limbs bound not to exceed four (4']) feet in length, bound paper and/or paper products, bound rugs or carpeting, bound electrical wire, bound piping, bagged or boxed yard clippings, bagged or boxed leaves, bagged or boxed clothes and other wearing apparel, bagged or boxed paint cans, tree trunks not to exceed five (5) feet in length, refrigerators and freezers (doors removed), stoves, furniture, washing machines, dryers, box spring and mattresses, sinks, toilets, bathtubs, window frames, lawn mowers and edgers, hot water heaters and water softeners. 
(Ord. No. 278 § 1, 9-16-52; 1957 Code § 10-1; Ord. No. 982 § 6, 2-3-59; Ord. No. 61-14 §§ 1-3, 5-16-61; Ord. No. 80-23 § 2, 5-6-80; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88; Ord. No. 95-3 § 1, 6-20-95; Ord. No. 2015-12 , § 2, 7-21-15) 
18-2 - RESPONSIBILITY FOR ENFORCEMENT AND ADMINISTRATION. 
    The responsibility of formulation of the manner, place of collection, type of notice, discount, penalties or additional charges, departmental responsibility, and the implementation of this chapter shall be placed on the City Manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 489 § 8, 11-15-55; 1957 Code § 10-2; Ord. No. 61-14 § 4, 5-15-61; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-3 - GARBAGE AND TRASH COLLECTION FEES; SCHEDULE. 
a.  The yearly garbage collection fee for which the owner of the property will be billed and will be responsible and which is based on a base facility charge and a commodity charge which includes the Miami-Dade County disposal and transfer fee pass-through charge shall be set by the Office of the City Manager and approved by motion of the City Council for the following categories and conditions of service: 
1.  Single residences and multiple dwellings with four (4) units or less. 
2.  Multiple dwellings, condominiums and apartment buildings with five (5) units or more. 
3.  Commercial establishments. The fee shall be based on a base facility charge and a commodity charge which includes the Miami-Dade County disposal and transfer fee pass-through charge, with a minimum charge of one hundred ($100.00) dollars per year; all commercial establishments (motel and hotels being considered in such category) shall be subject to such increases and weekly, monthly or yearly adjustments in the collection fee and subject to such rules and regulations as may be established as necessary from time to time by the Public Works Department. 
b.  Special commercial and industrial hauling of trash from commercial establishments shall be paid at a rate established by the office of the City Manager and approved by motion of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 278 § 4, 9-10-52; Ord. No. 489 § 4, 11-15-55; Ord. No. 640 § 1, 2-5-57; 1957 Code § 10-3; Ord. No. 68-17 §§ 1, 3, 6-6-68; Ord. No. 68-34 § 1, 10-15-68; Ord. No. 69-24 § 1, 9-29-69; Ord. No. 73-21 § 1, 9-28-73; Ord. No. 76-14 § 1, 9-21-76; Ord. No. 76-15 § 1, 9-21-76; Ord. No. 80-26 § 2, 5-20-80; Ord. No. 80-48 § 2, 9-16-80; Ord. No. 80-62 § 2, 11-4-80; Ord. No. 80-63 § 2, 11-4-80; Ord. No. 81-32 § 2, 9-15-81; Ord. No. 81-33 § 2, 10-20-81; Ord. No. 84-15 § 2, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 85-14 §§ 2-5, 9-18-85; Ord. No. 86-6 § 2, 5-6-86; Ord. No. 86-15 §§ 2, 3, 9-16-86; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
Cross reference- Fee for removal of excess trash, § 18-9. 
18-4 - ASSESSMENT PER UNIT. 
    Each unit in a multiple dwelling or apartment house shall be charged as a separate entity; that is to say, that if an apartment house contains eight (8) living units, such structure shall be assessed as if it were eight (8) separate residential dwelling houses. 
    Trailers shall be considered dwellings for the purposes of Sections 18-1 through 18-6, and each trailer shall be assessed as a single unit and to the same degree as a dwelling structure. 
(Ord. No. 489 § 3, 11-15-55; 1957 Code § 10-4; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-5 - INSTALLMENT COLLECTION TIMES. 
a.  The fee shall be collected at such times and in such installments as the City Manager deems appropriate and expedient, consistent with sound fiscal policies, administrative efficiency and convenience to the users of the City's garbage collection system. 
b.  Delinquent Fee. A delinquent fee shall be assessed for the late payment of garbage collection fees. 
1.  Residential. A late fee of ten (10%) percent shall be charged to any delinquent residential account for each unit of multiple dwelling or apartment house. 
2.  Commercial. A late fee of ten (10%) percent of the previous balance due at the time of billing or ten (10%) percent of the prior month's billing, whichever is less, shall be charged to any delinquent commercial sanitation account and shall be added automatically to the bill at the time of billing. 
c.  In the event that the garbage collection fee is unpaid after the expiration of thirty (30) days and after due notice by the City has been given to the commercial establishment, assessing the delinquent fee, then, within the ten (10) days after the delinquency notice has been sent, a lien will be placed on the property in accordance with paragraph d. below. 
d.  Lien for Delinquent Garbage Collection and Waste Fees. Unpaid garbage collection and waste fees, together with delinquent charges, shall become a lien against the real property upon which a multiple dwelling structure, residence, and/or commercial establishment is located; provided, that a notice of such lien be filed in the appropriate lien records of the city. Such notice shall recite the legal description of the property and the amount of the lien. Each such lien may be enforced by any of the methods set forth in Florida Statutes; provided, that if enforcement is by proceedings in equity to foreclose the lien of any delinquent waste fee, it shall be lawful to join in any bill for foreclosure any one (1) or more of the lots or parcels of land, by whomsoever owned, if charged with any delinquent waste fee. In case of garbage, trash and/or garden trash, the cost of collection fee shall constitute a lien against the premises to the same extent and character as a lien for special assessments, sale and forfeiture, as obtained for special assessment liens, and may be handled in the same manner by the City. 
(Ord. No. 489 § 2, 11-15-55; 1957 Code § 10-5; Ord. No. 1086 § 2, 10-20-59; Ord. No. 60-29 § 1, 3-15-60; Ord. No. 60-44, 4-26-60; Ord. No. 73-21 § 2, 9-28-73; Ord. No. 76-16 § 1, 10-5-76; Ord. No. 78-6 § 1, 5-2-78; Ord. No. 82-16 § 1, 5-4-82; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-6 - ASSESSED TO OWNER. 
    All garbage collection fees and charges for the entire multiple dwelling structures, residences and/or commercial establishments, shall be assessed to and be payable by the owner of the fee title, as recorded in the Tax Collector's office in the city. 
(Ord. No. 489 § 6, 11-15-55; 1957 Code § 10-6; Ord. No. 1086 § 4, 10-20-59; Ord. No. 78-6 § 1, 5-2-78; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-7 - GARBAGE CANS; COMMERCIAL CONTAINERS. 
18-7.1   Residential.
a.  Containers Loaned by City; Replacement Cost; Lien. Each owner or occupant of a dwelling unit is required to maintain a City of North Miami Beach garbage container on the property for use with the City of North Miami Beach Public Works rapid rail system. Each resident shall be furnished one (1) ninety (90) gallon container or shall jointly use one (1) three hundred (300) gallon container with a maximum of three (3) other residents. The initial container shall be furnished for use free of charge by the City. The container shall remain property of the City. Any missing container shall be replaced by the City, which cost shall be borne by the property owner. The replacement cost of the container shall appear on the next garbage collection bill issued for the residence and shall become due and payable within thirty (30) days of billing. The cost for the ninety (90) gallon container shall be established by the office of the City Manager. The replacement cost of the three hundred (300) gallon container shall be shared by the property owners of the up-to-four (4) residences using the container. Any charge for a replacement container that remains unpaid for more than sixty (60) days shall become a lien against the real property upon which the residence is located, which lien shall be enforced as set forth in this chapter. 
b.  Placement; Maintenance; Penalties. 
1.  Location of garbage cans: Garbage cans are required to be kept in a place easily accessible to the Sanitation Department of the City. They shall not be kept upon neighboring property not in the ownership or tenancy of the person by whom the garbage is accumulated, whether such neighboring property be vacant or improved. They are hereby required to be kept at a point upon the premises of the owner or occupant not closer to the street or streets upon which the premises abut than one-half (1/2) the depth of the premises from such street or streets, except that where the premises abut upon a used alley, the garbage can shall be placed on the portion of the premises which abuts the alley. 
2.  Collection, location; penalties: Garbage containers required to be placed near the street (ninety [90] gallon containers) for collection shall be placed near the street with lids closed and handle facing towards the house no earlier than 6:00 p.m. of the day prior to the designated collection day and no later than 7:00 a.m. of the designated collection day. The container shall be removed from the front of the property and returned to its location more than half-way back of the depth of the property measured from the street edge by 7:00 p.m. of the designated day of collection. Three hundred (300) gallon containers shall be positioned in a location approved by the Public Works Director or his designee. 
c.  Garbage and Trash in Cans; Requirements. 
1.  Only kitchen food waste, food containers, vegetable cans, flattened boxes and cartons, and grass cuttings and leaves shall be permitted in ninety (90) and three hundred (300) gallon containers. 
2.  All fish, fowl and meat and by-products for fish, fowl or meat shall be placed in plastic bags before disposal. 
d.  Garbage Cans; Replacement and Repair. 
1.  Residents will be responsible for reporting to the Department of Public Works all garbage cans which need replacement or repair of lids, wheels, axles, handles and container body. 
2.  Only the Department of Public Works shall repair or replace garbage cans. 
e.  Garbage Cans; Return. The property owner is responsible for the return of the garbage can to the Public Works Department at the time of the final payment of their water bill. 
f.  Garbage Cans; Responsibility in Rental Units. The property owner is accountable and responsible for the prevention of neglect, abuse or criminal acts to garbage can by his tenants. 
(Ord. No. 278 § 2, 9-16-52; 1957 Code § 10-7; Ord. No. 61-14 § 5, 5-15-61; Ord. No. 80-58 § 2, 10-7-80; Ord. No. 82-31 § 1, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-7.2   Commercial; Duplex; Multiple Apartment; Cooperatives; Motels and Hotels.
a.  Size and Number of Pick-Ups Required. 
1.  Commercial containers. The Director of Public Works or his designee shall determine container sizes and number of refuse pick-ups predicated upon the health, welfare and safety of each individual location. 
b.  Location of Commercial Containers. The location of commercial containers shall be approved by the Director of Public Works or his designee. 
c.  Commercial Containers; Enclosures. All commercial containers shall be enclosed in a structure that is approved and accepted by the Director of Public Works or his designee. The enclosure must be built and maintained by the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 278 § 2, 9-16-52; 1957 Code § 10-7 Ord. No. 61-14 § 5, 5-15-61; Ord. No. 80-58 § 2, 10-7-80; Ord. No. 82-31 § 1, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-7.3   Environmental Control Wastes, Material not Accepted by City.
    Sludge, asbestos, petroleum or their by-products, toxic chemicals, medical wastes, veterinarian wastes, infectious wastes, acids and pollution products are not acceptable in residential and commercial collections. 
(Ord. No. 278 § 2, 9-16-52; 1957 Code § 10-7; Ord. No. 61-14 § 5, 5-15-61; Ord. No. 80-58 § 2, 10-7-80; Ord. No. 82-31 § 1, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-8 - DRAINING AND WRAPPING GARBAGE, COVERING CANS. 
    All garbage, tin cans and bottles shall first be drained of all liquids, and shall be deposited in the garbage cans, herein required. The garbage shall be wrapped in paper, plastic or any other suitable material for the purpose of eliminating odors before being placed in the garbage can or approved container and the can or approved container shall be kept tightly covered at all times. All boxes placed in dumpsters or garbage cans shall be flattened before they are deposited therein. 
(Ord. No. 278 § 3, 9-16-52; 1957 Code § 10-8; Ord. No. 85-10 § 2, 7-2-85; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-9 - TRASH; SPECIAL COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL HAULING. 
a.  All commercial establishments, multiple dwellings, condominiums and apartment buildings with five (5) units or more may have trash, wood pallets, State road allowable vehicle tires and metal products which can not be discarded in a commercial container picked up and removed by the Department of Public Works for a special commercial and industrial hauling fee as established under Section 18-3. 
b.  Requests for special commercial and industrial hauling shall be made seventy-two (72) hours prior to service. 
c.  No trash shall be allowed to accumulate at commercial or industrial swale sites adjacent to the property owner's boundary line for a period longer than seventy-two (72) hours. 
d.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be assessed a penalty equal to twice the special commercial and industrial hauling fee. Such fine will be collected as a fee under Section 18-5. 
(1957 Code § 10-9; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-10 - RESIDENTIAL TRASH. 
18-10.1   Placement for Pick-up; Tree Branches, Etc.
    All owners or occupants of property in the City shall deposit trash, when and as it is accumulated, upon the swale immediately in front of the premises of the person by whom such accumulation is made, or where such premises are located upon a used alley, at a point easily accessible from and readily noticeable from such alley, provided that it is a minimum of ten (10) feet from a garbage can, but not to impede traffic or vehicles in such alley, for removal and disposition by the employees of the Public Works Department of the City, except that such owner or occupant shall arrange for the private removal and transportation of large amounts of trash to points approved and designated by the Director of the Public Works Department of the City, and under permits to be issued by the Department of Public Works. 
    Tree trunks or branches left for removal by the City shall be cut into length not to exceed five (5) feet or no single piece shall exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight. It shall be unlawful, and subject the violator to the penalties provided in this Code, for any such owner or occupant to deposit such trash upon any adjoining lot or premises, whether vacant or improved, occupied or unoccupied, or upon any other lot or premises, or street, alley or park, or in any canal or waterway, lake or pool within the City. Trash containing no combustible matter or matters which will during decay give off offensive odors, may be accumulated by the owner as a mulch or compost pile in the rear of the premises upon which accumulated. 
(Ord. No. 278 § 6, 9-16-52; 1957 Code § 10-10; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-10.2   Signed and Designated Zones.
a.  Where zones have been created for designated pickups, and signs installed for trash removal, no trash shall be allowed to accumulate for a period longer than forty-eight (48) hours. 
b.  Where zones have not been created, no trash shall be allowed to accumulate within ten (10) calendar days after a trash pickup. 
c.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be assessed a penalty equal to the special commercial and industrial hauling fee. Such fine will be collected as a fee under Section 18-5. 
(1957 Code § 10-10.1; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-11 - DEPOSITING OF DELETERIOUS SUBSTANCE IN LAKES, RIVERS, ROCK PITS, PROHIBITED. 
    No person shall deposit, or shall permit or allow any person in their employ or under their control, management or direction to deposit, in any of the waters of the lakes, rivers, canals, streams, ditches, rock pits or sumps, within the City limits of the City, any rubbish, filth, or poisonous or deleterious substance, or substances, liable to affect the health of persons, fish, or livestock, or place or deposit any such deleterious substance, or substances in any place where the same may be washed or infiltered into any of the water herein named. 
    Enforcement of this provision shall be effected through Chapter 162 of the Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 206 5-16-50; 1957 Code § 10-11; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-12 - MISCELLANEOUS UNLAWFUL ACTS. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to do or perform any of the following acts or practices: 
a.  Burial or Disposal. To deposit on or bury in or cause to be deposited on or buried in any land within the limits of the City any garbage or trash other than as provided in this chapter. 
b.  Removal or Conveyance on Streets. To remove or convey or cause or permit to be removed or conveyed any garbage or trash as defined herein upon or along any public street or alley, except as provided herein and in Section 17-1. 
c.  Building Material, Rock, Glass, Etc. To place or cause to be placed on or in any public street or alley discarded building material, dirt, rock, glass or scrap iron for collection. 
    Enforcement of this provision shall be effected through Chapter 162 of the Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 278 § 7, 9-16-52; 1957 Code § 10-12; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88) 
18-13-18-17 - RESERVED. 
18-18 - CITY AS THE EXCLUSIVE PROVIDER OF SOLID WASTE COLLECTION; PENALTIES. 
a.  The City shall be the sole and exclusive provider of solid waste collection and transportation for disposal from any premises over the streets or public rights-of-way within the incorporated area of the City. 
b.  Violation. 
1.  Owners/Occupant. It shall be a violation for an owner or occupant of property to allow the use of a private solid waste contractor for property located within the City limits. 
2.  Private Solid Waste Collection Contractor. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person or entity to collect and transport solid waste for disposal from any premises over the streets or public rights-of-way within the incorporated area of the City. 
    Each twenty-four (24) hour period will be considered a separate violation. 
    Any person or entity convicted of violating any provision of section 18-18(b)(1) shall be prosecuted in the City's special magistrate system. A first violation is punishable by a per day fine not to exceed two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00); repeat violations are punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day. 
    Any person or entity convicted of violating any provision of section 18-18(b)(2) shall be punished by imposition of a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days. 
( Ord. No. 2015-12 , § 2, 7-21-15) 
18-19 - PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION DEBRIS CONTAINER SERVICE HAULING, LIMITATIONS, BUSINESS TAX RECEIPT REQUIRED; SUPERVISORY CONTROL; SUSPENSION, REVOCATION, FEE. 
    Private construction and demolition debris hauling, shall be permitted within the City after first satisfying the requisites hereinafter set forth. 
a.  Business Tax Receipt Required. Before a private commercial enterprise shall engage in construction and demolition debris hauling within the City, a special construction and demolition debris hauling business tax receipt shall first be obtained. The business tax receipt required by this chapter shall be in addition to any other permit(s), registration or license(s) which may be required by federal, state or local law. 
b.  Violation. 
1.  Owner/Occupant. It shall be a violation for an owner or occupant of a property located within the City limits to allow the use of a private construction and demolition debris collection contractor which has not obtained a business tax receipt for such purposes. 
2.  Construction Contractors. It shall be a violation for any construction contractor to allow the use of a construction and demolition debris collection contractor which has not obtained a business tax receipt for such purposes, for any project within the City. 
3.  Construction and Demolition Debris Contractor. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person or entity to collect and transport construction and demolition debris for disposal from any premises over the streets or public rights-of-way within the incorporated area of the City without first obtaining the appropriate business tax receipt from the City to carry on such business. 
Each twenty-four (24) hour period will be considered a separate violation. Any person or entity convicted of violating any provision of section 18-19(b)(1) shall be prosecuted in the City's special magistrate system. A first violation is punishable by a per day fine not to exceed two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00); repeat violations are punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day. 
Any person or entity convicted of violating any provision of section 18-19(b)(2) and/or (3) shall be punished by imposition of a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days. 
c.  Supervisory Control. Collection and hauling of construction and demolition debris shall come under the direct supervision and control of the City's Director of Public Works, who shall have the necessary police power to enforce the City Sanitary Code, not only as to hauling of construction and demolition debris but as to all other matters relating to sanitary conditions being maintained throughout the City in accordance with health statutes and ordinances. The Director of Public Works and/or his designee shall have the authority to issue citations and summons for violations of the City's Sanitary Code as they pertain to this section. 
d.  Suspension; Revocation. The City Manager or designee, for good cause shown, shall have the right to recommend the suspension and/or revocation of any construction and demolition debris hauling business tax receipt for violation of the terms of this section or for violation of any other ordinance of the City. 
e.  Fee. The applicant shall pay the sum designated in section 12-31(39). 
(1957 Code § 10-19; Ord. No. 982 §§ 1-5, 7, 2-3-59; Ord. No. 70-12 § 1, 8-4-70; Ord. No. 80-41 § 2, 8-5-80; Ord. No. 84-13 § 2, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 88-5 § 2, 8-2-88; Ord. No. 95-3 § 6, 6-20-95; Ord. No. 95-8 § 2; Ord. No. 2015-12 , § 2, 7-21-15) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 2015-12 , adopted July 21, 2015, changed the title of § 18-19 from "PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS HAULING, COMMERCIAL TRASH AND/OR GARBAGE COLLECTION, AUTHORIZED; LIMITATIONS, BUSINESS TAX RECEIPT REQUIRED; SUPERVISORY CONTROL; SUSPENSION, REVOCATION, FEE" to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Provisions relating to the Department of Public Works, generally, § 2-7; licenses, generally, Ch. XII. 
18-20 - SEPARATION OF CERTAIN PORTIONS OF YARD WASTE. 
a.  Each owner, lessee or occupant of a dwelling unit is required to place leaves, grass clippings, and branches no longer than five (5') feet and no wider than six (6) inches in diameter in a pile separate from all other trash, to be located adjacent to but not abutting the garbage collection containers, which materials shall be picked up by the City to be recycled. Leaves, grass clippings, branches and other landscaping maintenance debris shall not be blown, swept or placed into public or private roadways or alleys or onto adjacent properties. 
b.  Each owner, lessee, or occupant of a dwelling unit is required to place palm fronds, tree sections larger than five (5) feet and wider than six (6) inches in diameter, weeds, soil, or any other materials not specifically described in paragraph a. in a second adjacent pile to be located adjacent but not abutting the garbage collection containers. 
c.  Each owner, lessee or occupant of a dwelling unit is required to prepare the leaves, grass clippings, and branches to meet the size limitations of the pile of materials to be recycled. 
    This section shall be enforced by the office of the City Manager or his designee. 
(1957 Code § 10-20; Ord. No. 90-2 § 2, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 95-4 § 2, 4-6-95) 
CHAPTER XIX - WATER AND SEWERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- As to control and power over watercourses, see § 21(35)(46)(51). 
Cross reference- As to business tax on bottled water companies, see § 12-31 W (152). 

Article I. - In General[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Public Services Department and Public Utilities Commission, § 2-20 et seq. 

19-1 - EXTENSION OF WATER AND SEWER SERVICES. 
    The Public Services Department of the City is herewith directed, instructed and required to refrain from extending its services in areas outside the City limits of the City and from entering into any contracts with respect thereto until it shall have first obtained approval of the City Council. 
    The areas affected herein are designated as those areas outside of the City limits which the City is not already serving or is required to service by virtue of provisions, acquisitions or contractual commitments. 
    This section in no way intends to limit of the extension of the services offered by the Public Services Department to outside areas, but has as its intention the exercise of close supervision beforehand with respect to the extension of services to other than the citizenry of North Miami Beach to whom the Department owes the primary duty to maintain the highest type of services at the most economical rate. 
(1957 Code § 23-01; Res. No. R60-74 §§ 1-3, 11-15-60; Res. R60-78 § 1, 12-6-60) 
19-2 - SCHEDULE OF RATES AND CHARGES; METHOD OF AMENDING. 
    The schedule of rates and charges for the services and facilities of the Water and Sewer System shall not be changed unless such change shall be first recommended by the Commission to the City Manager, and then approved by the City Council, or initiated by the City Council, except, however, where such change is governed by bond ordinances. 
(1957 Code § 23-02; Ord. No. 74-13 § 1, 10-1-74) 
19-3 - WATER AND SEWER CONNECTIONS. 
    Subject to the provisions of this article, the following schedule shall prevail with respect to granting permission to connect or hook up to the Water or Sewer Systems: 
a.  Where it is estimated that the applicant's water requirements will be under five hundred (500) gallons per day, permission may be granted by the Director of Public Utilities, without prior approval of the Public Utilities Commission. 
b.  Where it is estimated that the applicant's daily water requirements will be in excess of five hundred (500) gallons, but under two thousand five hundred (2,500) gallons per day, permission may be granted by the Director, but with prior approval of the Public Utilities Commission. 
c.  Where it is estimated that the applicant's daily water requirements will be in excess of two thousand five hundred (2,500) gallons, but under fifty thousand (50,000) gallons per day, permission may be granted by the Director, but only with the prior approval of the City Manager, who may seek the recommendation of the Public Utilities Commission. 
d.  Where it is estimated that the applicant's daily water requirements will be in excess of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons, permission shall be granted by the Director, but only with the prior approval of a majority vote of the City Council, who may seek the recommendation of the Public Utilities Commission. 
e.  No water will be sold outside of the service area of the City without the approval of the City Council. 
(1957 Code § 23-03; Ord. No. 74-13 § 2, 10-1-74) 
19-4 - WATER AND SEWER DEPOSITS. 
a.  The deposit schedules for new water and sewer accounts and reconnected accounts after disconnection due to nonpayment are as follows:
