b.  Customers with active water and/or sewer accounts within the City of North Miami Beach utility service area, wherein the City is holding a deposit as specified in Section 19-4(a), shall earn interest as set forth herein. The City shall pay interest in the form of a credit to the customer's account on such deposits at the same rate per annum as that earned by the City during the preceding calendar year less one-half (1/2) of one (1%) percent for administrative expenses, computed on February 1 of each calendar year for sums on deposit for the twelve (12) month period from January 1 of the preceding calendar year, beginning with calendar year 1994, the first interest to be credited in February 1995. In order to be eligible to receive this credit for the interest specified herein, all payments during the preceding calendar year must have been made in a timely manner. In the instance of accounts that are billed on a monthly basis, timely payments are those made within twenty (20) days of billing and in the instance of accounts billed on a quarterly basis, timely payments are those made within forty (40) days of billing. Eligibility for the payment of interest shall be forfeited if any customer shall make a payment via a check, bank draft, money order, or similar instrument during the preceding calendar year which is returned by the bank as unpaid. Any deposits held by the City for a period of time of less than one (1) year shall not earn interest, and if refunded to the customer prior to the expiration of one (1) year, shall not accrue any interest. The interest earned shall be shown as a credit on the first account billing processed after February 1 of each calendar year. 
(1957 Code § 23-04; Ord. No. 79-8 § 2, 5-15-79; Ord. No. 79-12 § 2, 7-3-79; Ord. No. 86-18 § 2, 10-21-86; Ord. No. 92-6 § 3, 5-5-92; Ord. No. 92-8 § 2, 6-12-92; Ord. No. 94-5 § 2, 4-5-94) 
19-5 - DECLARATION OF EXEMPTION; EQUALITY OF WATER AND SEWER RATES, FEES AND CHARGES. 
    To the fullest extent allowed by Section 180.191, F.S., as amended, it is hereby declared that the Water and Sewer Utility System Service of the City of North Miami Beach is exempt from regulation of water and sewer rates, fees and charges by the Miami-Dade Water and Sewer Board or other County agency. 
    The rates, fees and charges provided by this chapter shall be applicable to water and sewer utility service furnished by the City whether within the City limits or outside of the City limits. 
    Each of the rates, fees and charges provided by this ordinance shall be subject to municipal lien to the fullest extent authorized by Section 159.17, F.S., and any fees and charges previously incurred shall continue to be subject to said lien until paid. 
    The City Water and Sewer Utility Service shall provide for the billing of consumers for any applicable surcharge, pass through charge or other charge resulting from water and sewer costs otherwise imposed, which are not fully reflected in the charges provided herein, in accordance with the requirements of law. 
(Ord. No. 92-6 § 2, 5-5-92) 
19-6, 19-7 - RESERVED. 
Article II. - Water 

19-8 - COMPLIANCE WITH ARTICLE REQUIRED. 
    The rules and regulations for sale and distribution of water by the City and rates to be charged to consumers for water contained in this article are hereby adopted and promulgated, and shall be observed by the consumers of water supplied by the City. 
(Ord. No. 213 § A, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-1) 
19-9 - DEFINITIONS. 
    As used in this article: 
    Consumers shall mean party, person, firms, corporation or association using water in any premise supplied by the City. 
    Owner shall mean the person, firm, corporation, association, occupant or tenant having an interest whether legal or equitable, sole or only partial, in any premise which is or is about to be supplied with water by the City and the word "owners" means all interested. 
    Territory shall mean the corporate limits of the City. 
    Water Company shall mean the City of North Miami Beach Water Company. 
(Ord. No. 213 § A, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-2) 
19-10 - CONTRACTS. 
19-10.1   Application, Term; Change of Ownership; Turn-on Requests.
a.  All applications for water supply service must be made at the customer service office at the City Hall on a blank form prepared by the City for that purpose. 
b.  The owner of the premises proposed to be connected for water supply service, or his agent thereof duly authorized in writing, must sign the application for service pipe and water supply, except as hereinafter provided. 
c.  Such application becomes a binding contract upon both the owner and the City when the service connections for water supply service applied for have been installed and completed. Prior to the installation of such service connections, the owner may cancel or withdraw the application upon his written order to do so, after payment to the City for actual expense, of not less than one ($1.00) dollar, incurred by the City in connection therewith. 
d.  All contracts for water supply service shall expire at the end of the next succeeding calendar month from date of application, but all contracts shall be renewed without act or notice from either party to the other, from month to month, unless ten (10) days' notice is given in writing from either party to the other of the desire to terminate the contract at the expiration of the then calendar month, and all charges are paid in full. Payment of charges at any interval or period, other than monthly shall not be construed as altering the period of the contract or the renewals thereof under this rule. 
e.  In the event of any change in ownership or occupancy of any premises connected to the system, the City shall be immediately notified in writing of such change, giving in such notice the name of the new owner or occupant. In the absence of application for service, such new owner or occupant, the use of the City service may, at the option of the City, be taken and construed as acceptance by such new owner or occupant of all contract obligations of the preceding owner with the City. In the event any owner fails to notify the City in writing of the change in ownership or occupancy of any premises for water supply service, such owner shall continue to be liable to the City for all rates and charges accrued and accruing for such service until either the end of the contract period, in which he may then notify the City of his desire to cancel, or the City shall, of its own volition, have canceled the contract with the owner, but this clause shall not preclude the City from also demanding from the new owner or occupant the payment of all or any charges which shall, at the time of such demand, be unpaid or unsecured without regard to whether the same accrued prior or subsequent to such change in ownership or occupancy. Upon failure of such new owner to comply with such demand within twenty-four (24) hours after written notice thereof, the City shall have the right to shut off the water supply and discontinue the service. In no case of change of ownership shall the preceding owner or owners be released from any contract obligations with the City until the expiration of the contract, properly terminated in accordance with these rules and regulations, except at the option of the City, evidenced by a written release from the City. 
f.  When application for water supply service is made, the service together with the charges and rates therefor shall begin on the date of the completion of the service connection by the City unless the owner shall state in writing in the application that the service connection shall be shut off immediately upon its installation, in which event the connection shall then be shut off and shall thereafter be turned on by the City only upon the written request of the owner, in which event the charges and rates for water supply service shall commence on the date of such turn-on, in accordance with these rules and regulations in every respect as though such turn-on request had been an original application. However, in a case hereinabove provided, where there shall have been a change in ownership prior to a turn-on of the service connection, the new owner shall sign the application for water supply upon the regular form. 
(Ord. No. 213 § E, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-3; Ord. No. 92-6 § 3, 5-5-92) 
Charter reference- As to authority for building works for supplying water to the inhabitants of the City, see Charter § 21(39). 
19-10.2   Cancellation; Discontinuance of Service; Causes.
    All contracts shall be subject to cancellation and service thereunder, discontinued by the City: 
a.  For misrepresentations or concealment in the application as to the premises or fixtures to be furnished by the City supply service, or the use to be made of such service. 
b.  For waste or excessive use of water through improper or imperfect pipes and fixtures, or appliances, or in any other manner. 
c.  For refusal or neglect to make any advance payment, if such is required by the City, or for refusal or neglect to comply with any requirement of the City as to meter or service connection maintenance, alteration or renewal or other requirement relating to the water supply service of the City. 
d.  For the use of water supply service for or in connection with or for the benefit of any other premises or purpose than that in the application. 
e.  For an interference or tampering, whether by act of commission or omission, with the meter measuring the water supply, or with seals of any meter, or with any meter box or vault, or service pipes, or valves, or any seals thereon, or with the curb stop cock, or with any appliance of the City, or with any appliance of the owner which was or is required by the City for controlling or regulating the water supply service. For the purpose of this rule, an interference or tampering with any appliance used in connection with or for controlling or regulating the water supply service to any premises, shall be construed and taken to be the act of the owners and consumers using the water service at such premises. 
f.  In case of continued vacancy of the premises. 
g.  For violation of any rule of the City. 
h.  Where there has been a change in ownership of the premises, but no application from the new owner or owners has been made or approved by the City. 
i.  Where there has been discontinuance of the use of water or the service of the City. 
j.  Where the contract has been in any way terminated by the owner. 
k.  Where any owner or consumer refuses or neglects payment of a bill, account or charge by whomsoever incurred, or where the City is being defrauded in any way. 
(Ord. No. 213 § F, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-4) 
19-11 - WATER METERS. 
19-11.1   Separate for Separate Owners; Additional Meters; Contractor's Meter; Use From Fire Hydrants.
a.  In cases where a number of houses or premises are supplied through one (1) meter and one (1) service, if at any time, one (1) or more of the houses or premises are sold, or transferred, or otherwise pass into separate ownership, the owner shall be required to disconnect such house or houses and have separate meters installed for each separate owner. 
b.  Where the owner of the building containing more than one (1) store, dwelling, or other premises, desires that separate meters be installed to each separate store, dwelling or other premises, such additional meters shall be installed upon the payment in advance by the owner of the regular tapping charge for a new service for each meter installed. 
c.  Contractor and other persons will be supplied with water for temporary use according to the regular service charge provided for water supply. They will be required to deposit regular guarantee of payment deposit. Such deposit shall be held by the City as a guarantee of safety for the meter and for other equipment of the City Water Department. 
    Further, and for payment of charges for water used though such meter, the contractor, applicant, will be charged the regular tapping charges for cost of making the tap, setting the meter and the other expenses in connection therewith, for the removal of the meter and connection. Upon payment of all charges, for the removal and discontinuance of services through the meter, the City is authorized to refund the amount of deposit made by the applicant for such service. 
d.  Contractors or any other consumers desiring water for temporary use will not be allowed to use water from fire hydrant. 
(Ord. No. 213 § C, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-5) 
Charter reference- As to providing for the inspection of water meters see Charter § 21(58). 
19-11.2   Installing, Repairing, Reading, Testing, Fee Where Seal Broken.
a.  All meters shall be furnished and installed by the City at its own expense, upon the application of any owner or responsible party paying for the tapping service charge as provided, and all meters so furnished and installed shall become the property of the City and subject to the absolute and exclusive control of the City. 
b.  In every instance of needed water supply service, the owner shall provide and maintain the location for the meter, acceptable to the City. When any meter has once been placed, its position shall not be changed, except by the City and with its consent, the cost to be paid by the owner, and in the event any owner makes any change in his premises, which in the discretion of the City requires any change in the location or position of the meter or meter box, such change in location or position shall be made by the City at the cost of the owner. 
c.  Repairs, renewals and replacements of all water meters and meter boxes, with connections and appliances, shall be made by the City at its own expense where such repairs, renewals and replacements are due to the ordinary wear-and-tear of service. 
d.  Reading of meters are to be made monthly and if the meter is in good order and has been in good condition during the time since the last reading, bills are rendered in accordance therewith; but the City reserves the right at its option, in the case of large users of water supply service, or for any other reason deemed by it to be sufficient, to read any meter or meters and render any bills therefor in the same manner as stated above for quarterly readings, and monthly or more frequent intervals. All readings of meters shall be taken as near as practicable on the same calendar day of each month. 
e.  All meters shall be carefully tested before they are installed and after their installation they shall be tested as frequently as circumstances warrant. Should the owner, at any time, question the accuracy of the meter on his service, the City shall upon his written application, accompanied by the payment of one ($1.00) dollar for each meter in question to cover the cost of test thereof, remove the meter and test it in the presence of the owner or his authorized agent, if such presence is desired by the owner. If the test shows the meter has been over registering more than two (2%) percent, the one ($1.00) dollar paid shall be returned to the owner, and bill rendered based on the last reading of such meter or meters accordingly. If the test shows that the meter is not over registering more than two (2%) percent, as aforesaid, the one ($1.00) dollar paid by the owner shall be retained by the City and in addition thereto, if the test shows that the meter has been under registering more than two (2%) percent, as aforesaid, the one ($1.00) dollar paid by the owner shall be retained by the City and the bill rendered based on the last reading of such meter or meters, shall be corrected accordingly. The City reserves the right to remove and test any meter at any time, and if such meter is found to be inaccurate to substitute another meter of the same size in its place, either permanently or temporarily. In the event of such test last mentioned, the City further reserves the right to make any corrections on bills rendered based on the last reading of such meter, in accordance with the result of such test. 
f.  Quantity of water recorded by the meter shall be conclusive on both the owner and the City except when the meter has been found to be defective, or ceases to register. In case the meter has been found to be defective or has ceased to register the quantity of water since the last reading shall be determined by the average registration of another meter for a period of twenty (20) days, or for the same meter for a like period after it had been repaired, and tested; or by mutual agreement, the quantity of water supplied may be prorated upon the previous corresponding period of the last reading, preceding the time the meter has been or became defective or has failed to register to the time such meter is repaired or replaced. 
g.  The owner or consumer at every premises shall pay to the City the sum of five ($5.00) dollars for each time the seal on any meter or its coupling on or for such premises is found broken or removed. The City hereby reserves the right to put on such seal in or for any premises at any time, and upon the second occurrence, the City may, at its option shut off the supply and discontinue its service, and may further refuse to again turn on the same and resume its service to such premises, so long as the owner of or consumer of the premises, at the time of the breaking or removal of such seal, shall continue to be the owner of or consumer at the premises. 
(Ord. No. 213 § H, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-6)

19-11.4   Same-Private Fire Service Protection, Installing.
a.  Charges or rates for special private fire services as based upon the size of the connection with the City distribution system thereof, are as follows: 
1.  Six (6) inch private unmetered fire service connection, twenty-one dollars and eighty-two cents ($21.82) per month. 
2.  Eight (8) inch private unmetered fire service connection, twenty-nine dollars and nine cents ($29.09) per month. 
b.  The cost of installation of private fire service is to be paid for by the owner at actual cost plus ten (10%) percent. The City shall install fire line connections into a building up to the property line upon the owner signing regular form of contract, containing the following conditions: 
1.  This connection is to be used for fire protection only, and is to have no connection whatsoever with any taps that may be used for other than fire purposes; and because of the danger of pollution shall have no connection with any other source of supply. 
2.  The owner shall not draw any water whatsoever through this connection for any purpose except the extinguishment of fires or for the periodic test of the fire system, which test shall be made in the presence of a representative of the City. 
3.  Any authorized representative of the City shall have free access to the buildings at any reasonable time for the purpose of inspecting any equipment of the City. 
4.  At some future date convenient with the City, and in the event the City so desires and instructs such owner, the owner shall set in this connection at the line dividing the property of the owner and the street or alley, a weighted check valve fitted with a by-pass, the purpose of which shall indicate whether or not water is being used through this connection, for the further purpose of showing any leakage, if same exists. 
5.  Violation by the owner of any of the regulations of this section shall terminate regulations as set forth in paragraphs b.1. through b.4. of this subsection, and because of such violations the City may disconnect such pipe or pipes, or stop the flow of water through same. 
6.  The right is reserved by the City to shut off the supply in case of accident, or to make alterations, extensions, connections or repairs, and if possible the City agrees to give an ample notice of shut off. 
7.  The City shall not make any guarantee as to a certain pressure in this pipe or in the mains supplying the same and shall not be, under any circumstances, held liable for loss or damage to the owner for the inefficiency or failure of the supply of water, whether the occasion for shutting off water in the case of accident or alteration, extensions, connections or for any cause whatsoever. 
8.  When fire line valves or connections are used in case of fire or for any reason whatsoever, the owner shall immediately notify the City and the City shall forthwith reseal the used valves or connections. 
(Ord. No. 213 § D, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-8; Ord. No. 92-6 § 3, 5-5-92; Ord. No. 92-8 § 2, 6-2-92; Ord. No. 2005-14 § 2, 9-22-2005; Ord. No. 2006-19 § 2, 10-17-2006; Ord. No. 2007-8, 9-18-07; Ord. No. 2008-19 § 1, 9-23-08; Ord. No. 2009-21 § 2, 9-22-09; Ord. No. 2010-26 § 2, 9-28-10; Ord. No. 2014-9 , § 2, 9-23-14) 
19-12 - PAYMENT OF BILLS FOR WATER SERVICE. 
19-12.1   Payment, Adjustment.
a.  Payments of all bills and accounts of the City must be made at the cashier's office located at the City Hall. 
b.  Water service will be discontinued without further notice on all accounts not paid within thirty (30) days of date of bill. 
c.  The date of cancellation by the Post Office Department shall be taken as date of payment for all remittances by mail for bills on accounts due the City. 
d.  No abatements or reductions on meter charges shall be refunded or allowed except for errors on meter readings when such charges are based on inaccuracy in the registration of any meter or in the meter of an error on the part of the City in making any charge or in the amount thereof and then only provided claim for such abatement or adjustment is made in writing within ten (10) days after the date of the rendition of the bill or account in dispute. 
e.  No abatement or reduction on any bill, account or charge rendered or made by the City for any service or purpose other than meter service will be made or allowed, unless only when claim for such abatement or deduction is made in writing within ten (10) days after date of the rendition of the bill or account in dispute. 
f.  Under no circumstances will abatements, allowances, deductions, or refunds be made on actual or alleged excessive meter water supply service accounts or charges on account of water used, or lost or wasted through leaks, carelessness or neglect or otherwise, after the same has passed through the meter. 
(Ord. No. 213 § I, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-9; Ord. No. 92-6 § 3, 5-5-92) 
19-12.2   Delinquent Accounts; Shutting Off Water.
a.  All bills rendered or charges made by the City which are in arrears as provided in these rules shall be delinquent accounts. 
b.  All delinquent accounts, including meter water supply service, may result in the service of the City being discontinued and the water supply shut off from and to the premises of the owner or consumer of such account if in arrears immediately upon such account becoming delinquent or as soon thereafter as practicable and such service will not be resumed or the water turned on to such premises until the amount of the delinquent account and the sum of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars for shutting off and twenty-five ($25.00) dollars for restoring service has been paid. 
c.  When an owner or consumer vacates or sells his property leaving a delinquent bill against such property vacated or sold, the City may, at its option, refuse service on any other service the same owner or consumer may be using or intends to use in the future until the date the original account is paid, regardless of whether the other account or consumer is in good standing or not. 
d.  Charge for broken locks shall be $25.00. 
e.  After the water has initially been turned off by the City, if water is turned back on by the customer without sufficient payment and/or the City's authorization, progressive turn off methods and devices up to and including a turn off at the main may be implemented. These attempts to turn off water will result in additional fees as follows. 
1.  2nd-$50.00. 
2.  3rd-$125.00. 
3.  4th or more-$250.00 for each occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 213 § J, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-10; Ord. No. 80-28 § 2, 5-20-80; Ord. No. 2007-8, 9-18-2007) 
19-12.3   General Penalties; Additional Deposit.
    Any bill not paid within ten (10) days is considered delinquent. The City, after due notice, may shut off the service and a twenty-five ($25.00) dollar penalty shall be added to the bill. When a delinquent owner or consumer pays his bill and applies for water service, he will be required to deposit with the City an amount equal to three (3) months of his previous billing, plus paying the regular opening fee of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars. 
(1957 Code § 23-11; Ord. No. 80-28 § 3, 5-20-80; Ord. No. 2007-8, 9-18-2007) 
19-12.4   Surcharge on Delinquent Accounts.
    A late or surcharge shall automatically be imposed upon all delinquent customers of potable water in the amount of ten (10%) percent of the prior billing cycle's water charges or of any outstanding previous balance due at the time of each billing, whichever is lower, and the surcharge shall be added on at the time of billing and shall be due and owing to the City by the delinquent customer. 
(1957 Code § 23-11; Ord. No. 75-11 § 1, 6-17-75; Ord. No. 92-6 § 3, 5-5-92; Ord. No. 94-34 § 2, 10-4-94) 
19-12.5   Adoption of Rules and Regulations Concerning Deposits for New Residential Accounts; Accounts to Whom Service was Restored.
    The Public Utilities Commission shall adopt such reasonable rules and regulations as may be required in regard to establishment of the amount of new customer deposits for all new residential accounts of the water and sewer division, and if determined necessary by the Commission, accounts to whom service has been restored after termination due to a failure to promptly pay outstanding accounts, in accord with prudent fiscal policies. 
(1957 Code § 23-11.1; Ord. No. 69-31 § 3, 12-2-69) 
Cross reference- Public utilities department and commission, § 2-20 et seq. 
19-12.6   Residential Accounts to be Billed Monthly.
    All residential accounts of the Water and Sewer Division of the Public Utilities Department of the City of North Miami Beach shall be billed on a monthly basis, commencing with the first available billing cycle at which the Public Utilities Department can reasonably and feasibly implement such monthly billing cycle. 
(1957 Code § 23-11.2; Ord. No. 69-31 § 1, 12-2-69; Ord. No. 2018-9 , § 2, 9-13-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-9 , § 2, adopted Sept. 13, 2018, changed the title of § 19-12.6 from "Residential Accounts to be Billed Quarterly" to read as herein set out. 
19-12.7   Lien for Non-payment of Bill.
    The City has the right under this chapter to place a lien against any property where the owner or consumer fails to pay his water bill. There shall be an administrative fee of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars for the preparation and mailing of the lien notice on the property. If the water bill is still unpaid after ten (10) working days, an administrative fee of twenty ($20.00) dollars shall be assessed for preparation and mailing of the lien, in addition to any lien filing fees charged by the Clerk of the County Court. 
(Ord. No. 213 § B, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-12; Ord. No. 95-14 § 3, 9-19-95; Ord. No. 96-13, 10-1-96; Ord. No. 2007-8, 9-18-2007) 
19-13 - SALE OF LIENS FOR WATER SERVICE. 
a.  Liens; When Delinquent. Liens, when unpaid for more than thirty (30) days shall be considered delinquent and may be sold pursuant to Florida Statutes. All delinquent liens shall be offered for sale by the City Manager at the annual lien sale of the City next following the date of delinquency, and shall be subject to the same penalties, rights of collection, foreclosure, sale and forfeiture as provided for the sale of special assessment liens and may be handled in the same manner by the City. 
b.  Publication of Notice. The City Manager shall cause a notice of sale of delinquent liens to be published once each week for four (4) consecutive weeks in newspapers published in Miami-Dade County, Florida, or the City of North Miami Beach stating that all liens for nonpayment of lawfully imposed public utility bills or other local assessments will be offered for sale any time after May 1 of that year at the time specified in such notice. A complete list of such delinquent liens shall be available in the office of the City Clerk. The sale of these liens shall continue until such time as specified by Florida Statutes. 
c.  Sale. At 12:00 noon on the day designated in the notice for sale, the City Manager or his agent shall commence the sale of those liens which have been delinquent and such sale shall continue from day to day until the proceeds from the sales are sufficient to pay the fees assessed against the real property in question. 
d.  Payment by Purchaser. The purchaser of any lien certificate shall be required to make payment in cash or by certified check to the City of North Miami Beach within twenty-four (24) hours. The City Manager may cancel the bid of any purchaser of a lien certificate who fails to tender full payment to the City within twenty-four (24) hours. If any purchaser of a certificate of lien neglects or refuses to make full payment for such certificate, the City Manager may refuse to accept any other bid of such purchaser or his agent during the aforementioned sale. Any certificate of lien that is not paid for in full within twenty-four (24) hours after the close of the sale shall be deemed void and the lien shall be reinstated on the property. 
e.  Listing of Liens Sold. Within three (3) days after the sale of liens described herein, the City Manager shall direct that a list of all certificate of liens sold be certified and delivered to the Miami-Dade County Tax Collector for redemption purposes along with other forms required by the Miami-Dade County Tax Collector. A copy of the list shall be retained by the City Manager and another copy filed with the Clerk of the Circuit Court of Miami-Dade County, Florida. Each list shall contain the date of sale of each lien certificate, the number of each lien certificate, the value received and the interest bid for each lien certificate, the legal description of lands for which fees are owing, the name and address of the purchaser of each lien certificate, and an addendum to each list stating that the aforementioned sale was conducted according to law. 
f.  Award of Certificate of Lien; Required Deposit. The City Manager shall verify that only the person bidding the lowest interest rate within the maximum legal rate of eighteen (18%) percent be awarded a certificate of lien. Prior to or simultaneously with actual bidding, all bidders shall be required to make a deposit of ten (10%) percent in cash or by certified check of the lien amount for which they intend to bid. The successful bidder's deposit shall be nonrefundable and may be used at the discretion of the City of North Miami Beach to insure the purchase of all lien certificates placed for public sale. 
g.  Compliance. The City Manager shall verify that the successful bidder shall comply with all provisions of this section and all other legal requirements. The bidder shall be awarded a certificate of lien stating the amount of the bid, a description of the real property involved, and the rate of interest bid. 
h.  Redemption. The exclusive office for the redemption of lien certificates shall be the Miami-Dade County Tax Collector. 
(1957 Code § 23-12; Ord. No. 81-17 § 2, 5-19-81) 
19-14 - INSTALLATION OF NEW WATER SERVICE. 
19-14.1   Tapping Charges.
    On the application of the owner or consumer of water service on premises to which there has not been made previous service for water, tapping charges shall be made to cover the cost of the tap and installation of the service for water. Such tapping charges shall be made at the actual cost at the time of installation, as fixed by the Public Utilities Department of the City of North Miami Beach, to cover the cost of the tap and installation of the service to the property line of the lot to be supplied with water service and the cost of the meter; provided, however, such property line shall be construed to be the property line abutting the street or right-of-way upon which the City has mains already laid. 
(1957 Code § 23-13; Ord. No. 213 § B, 8-4-50; Res. No. R74-78 § 1, 11-5-74) 
19-14.2   Installation of Service Equipment, Tapping.
a.  The City shall lay the service pipe to the property line of the owner who has signed the contract for water service provided the property lines correspond with such lot lines as are dedicated and recorded in the subdivision plat. In other words, the City will not run service connections to lots or parts of lots that have been divided and for which no provisions and recording of easements or alleys have been made for water supply lines. 
b.  In case service supplying a house or building is found not to be large enough due to additions to buildings or an increase or change in the number of fixtures, the City will make the larger tap and install the service upon the payment of the tapping charge for the size of the new service. No credit will be given for the service already placed and found to be insufficient in size. The owner shall be required to place a gate valve on the service between the building and the meter box so that the supply may be turned off by the owner or the City in case of a break or repair being made to the building. 
c.  The City in every instance reserves the right, at its option, to designate and prescribe the size of the service connection, either upon original installation of a new connection or upon any renewal or replacement of any old connection. In any case, where size of the service is other than that applied for by the owner, or if previously existing, is so designated and prescribed by the City, the owner will be bound thereby. 
d.  The City reserves the right, at its option, where and when and in its discretion, the conditions may or might require it, at any time, to require any owner to install on his service connection, tank, check valve or valves, cock or gate valve, pressure regulator or other appliances, apparatus or equipment of such types or designs as are approved by the City and thereafter to require any change, alteration, substitution, or addition of and to any such tank, etc., as aforesaid, and failure upon the part of the owner to comply with such requirements of the City upon thirty (30) days' written notice to the owner, or within some agreed extension beyond such thirty (30) days, also in writing, shall authorize the City at its option, without further notice, to cancel the contract for such services and discontinue the same. 
(Ord. No. 213 § G, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-14) 
19-15 - CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL PROGRAM. 
19-15.1   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    Auxiliary supply shall mean any water source or system, other than the public potable water supply, that may be available in a building or premises. 
    Back pressure shall mean backflow caused by a pump, elevated tank, boiler, or other means that could create pressure within the system greater than the supply pressure. 
    Back siphonage shall mean a form of backflow due to a negative or subatmospheric pressure within a water system. 
    Backflow shall mean the flow, other than the intended direction of flow, of any foreign liquids, gases or substances, into the distribution system of a public water supply. 
    Backflow prevention device shall mean a device or a mechanical assembly to prohibit backflow into potable water system or back pressures or prevent back siphonage. The following types of backflow devices may be approved: 
a.  Air gap separation (AG) shall mean unobstructed vertical physical separation between the free-flowing discharge end of a potable water supply pipeline and the flood level rim of an open or non-pressure receiving vessel. An approved air gap separation shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe measured vertically above the top of the rim of the vessel. In no case shall an air gap separation be less than one (1) inch. 
b.  Double check detector assembly (DCDA) shall mean a specially designed assembly composed of a line-size approved double check valve assembly with a bypass containing a specific water meter and approved double check valve assembly. The meter shall register accurately for only very low rates of flow up to three (3) gallons per minute (gpm) and shall show a registration for all rates of flow. The DCDA is used only on fire systems. 
c.  Double check valve assembly (DC) shall mean an assembly composed of two (2) single, independently acting approved check valves, including tightly closing resilient seated shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly, and fitting with property located resilient seated test cocks suitable for testing the water tightness of each check valve. A check valve is a valve that is drip-tight in the normal direction of flow when the inlet pressure is one (1) psi and the outlet pressure is zero. The check valve shall permit no leakage in a direction reverse to the normal flow. The closure element (e.g., clapper) shall be internally weighted or otherwise internally loaded to promote rapid and positive closure. This assembly shall be used only to protect against a nonhealth hazard. 
d.  Pressure vacuum breaker (PVB) shall mean an assembly consisting of an independently operating internally loaded check valve and an independently operating loaded air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check valve, with properly located resilient-seated test cocks and tightly closing resilient-seated shutoff valves attached at each end. The PVB prevents backsiphonage, but is not effective, and should not be used, in backpressure conditions. 
e.  Reduced pressure detector assembly (RPDA) shall mean a specially designed assembly composed of a line-size approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly with a bypass containing a specific water meter and an approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. The meter shall register accurately for only very low rates of flow up to three (3) gpm and shall show a registration for all rates of flow. The RPDA is used only on fire systems. 
f.  Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer (RP) shall mean an assembly containing within its structure a minimum of two (2) independently acting approved check valves, together with an automatically operating pressure differential relief valve located between the two (2) check valves. The first check valve reduces the supply pressure by a predetermined amount so that during normal flow and at cessation of normal flow the pressure between the checks shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall operate to maintain the pressure between the checks less than the supply pressure. These units are equipped with tightly closing resilient seated shut-off valves located at each end of the assembly, and with properly located resilient seated test cocks. 
    Cross-connection shall mean any temporary or permanent physical arrangement whereby a public water supply is connected, directly or indirectly, with any other water supply system, sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture, or other device which contains, or may contain, contaminated water, sewage or other waste or liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water supply as a result of backflow. Bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or change-over devices, and other temporary or permanent devices through which or because of which, backflow could occur are considered to be cross-connections. 
    Public water supply shall mean any system or water supply intended for use or actually used for human consumption or other domestic uses including source, treatment, storage, transmission and distribution facilities, where water is furnished to any community, collection, or number of individuals, or is made available to the public for human consumption or domestic use, excluding water supplies serving individual single-family residences. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(A); Ord. No. 81-23 § 1, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.2   Gate Valves and Stop Cocks Prohibited.
    No cross-connections such as gate valves or stop cocks, whether or not controlled by automatic devices, shall be permitted in any new facilities or installations. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(B); Ord. No. 81-23 § 2, 7-21-81) 
19-15.3   Inspections; When Remedial Devices Required.
    The Department of Public Utilities of the City of North Miami Beach, in cooperation with the appropriate health officers, shall make periodic inspections of all premises served by the City's water supply system to check for the presence of cross-connections. Any cross-connections found shall be ordered removed, if possible, in the determination of the Department and the health official. If an immediate hazard to health is presented by the cross-connection, water service to the premises may be discontinued until the cross-connection has been removed. As an alternative to eliminating the cross-connection, a backflow prevention device shall be installed at the service connection or within any premises where, in the judgment of the Department of Public Utilities, the inclusion of such a device is necessary to protect the integrity of the water supply system. The following are examples of situations where such devices shall be required: 
a.  Premises having an auxiliary water supply, unless the quality of the auxiliary supply is in compliance with applicable Federal laws, and is acceptable to the Department; 
b.  Premises having internal cross-connections that are not correctable, or intricate plumbing arrangements which make it impractical to ascertain whether or not a cross-connection exists; 
c.  Premises where entry is restricted so that inspections for cross-connections cannot be made with sufficient frequency or on short notice to assure that cross-connections do not exist; 
d.  Premises on which any substance is handled under pressure so as to permit entry into the public water supply or where cross-connection could reasonably be expected to occur. This shall include the handling of processed waters and cooling waters; 
e.  Premises where materials of toxic or hazardous nature are handled so that if back siphonage should occur, a serious health hazard may result; 
f.  The following types of facilities fall into one (1) of the above categories where the listed backflow prevention devices are required to protect the public water supply in all situations: 
Facility Backflow

(1957 Code § 23-14.1(C); Ord. No. 81-23 § 3, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.4   Objectionable, but Not Hazardous Substances.
    In situations where substances involved may be objectionable but not hazardous to health as determined by the department and the health officers, a double check valve assembly, air gap separation or a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(F); Ord. No. 81-23 § 6, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.5   Location of Backflow Prevention Device.
    Backflow prevention devices installed shall be installed at the outlet side of the meter or at another location designated by the Department of Public Utilities. The device shall be located so as to be readily accessible for maintenance and testing and where no part of the device will be submerged. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(G); Ord. No. 81-23 § 7, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.6   Installation of Device at Customer's Expense.
    Backflow prevention devices shall be installed by the customer at the customer's expense or by the Department at the customer's request and expense should this arrangement be made by the customer and the Department. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(H); Ord. No. 81-23 § 8, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.7   Conditions for Approval of Device.
    Any protective device required in this section shall be approved by the Department of Public Utilities prior to installation. A double check valve assembly or a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device may be approved if the device has successfully passed performance tests of the University of Southern California Engineering Center or other testing laboratory satisfactory to the Department of Public Utilities. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(I); Ord. No. 81-23 § 9, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.8   Annual Inspection, Tests, Charges.
    Backflow prevention devices shall be inspected and tested annually by the Department of Public Utilities, or more often where successive inspections indicate repeated failure. The charge for each inspection or reinspection shall be twenty-five ($25.00) dollars for residential uses and, for commercial and industrial uses, shall be fifty ($50.00) dollars for the domestic line and one hundred ($100.00) dollars for the fire line. If required, the device shall be repaired, overhauled or replaced by the Department of Public Utilities contractors at the customer's expense whenever it is found the device is defective. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(J); Ord. No. 81-23 § 10, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.9   Grounds for Termination of Service.
    Failure of the customer to cooperate in the installation, maintenance, testing or inspection of required backflow prevention devices shall be grounds for termination of water service to the premises being served after notice has been given the customer by the Department. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(K); Ord. No. 81-23 § 11, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.10   Enforcement.
    It shall be the duty of the Director of the Department of Public Utilities of the City of North Miami Beach or his authorized designee to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(L); Ord. No. 81-23 § 12, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.11   Violation; Legal Remedies.
    Should any consumer use a water system in violation of this section, the City, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunctive action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful use or other violations, to restrain, correct or abate such violation, to prevent the occupancy of the building wherein the water system is being utilized or to prevent any illegal act, conduct, business or use in or about such premises. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(M); Ord. No. 81-23 § 13, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.12   Violation Deemed Misdemeanor; Penalties.
    The owner or occupant of a building or premises where a violation of this section has been committed or exists, or the lessee or tenant of the entire building or entire premises where such violation has been committed or exists, or the owner, lessee or tenant of any part of the building or premises in which such violation has been committed or exists, or any other person who commits, takes part in, or assists in any such violation, shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and liable to the penalty established in Chapter I, Section 1-8, by a fine not to exceed five hundred ($500.00) dollars per day or imprisonment for not more than sixty (60) days, or both, for each and every day that such violation continues. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(I); Ord. No. 81-23 § 14, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-15.13   Compliance; Applicability.
    The provisions of this section apply to all existing installations. Compliance shall be required within thirty (30) days of notification from the Department of Public Utilities unless the time is extended in writing by the Department. 
(1957 Code § 23-14.1(O); Ord. No. 81-23 § 15, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 2002-26 § 2, 1-7-2003) 
19-16 - TURN-ON AND SHUT-OFF; CURB COCK TO BE USED BY CITY. 
a.  The cock on any and all service connections shall not be used in any way by the owner, employee or agent in turning on or shutting off the water supply. All such turning on or shutting off by the owner shall be made with a separate stop cock, located or to be located on the house side of the service curb cock. All turning on or shutting off of the water supply at and with the curb cock shall be done exclusively by the City. 
b.  A violation of paragraph a. of this section upon the part of the owner, employee or agent shall subject the owner or consumer to a penalty of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars for the first offense, and upon the second offense, the City at its option may discontinue the service and shut off the water supply to the premises, so long as the owner or consumer continues to reside at the premises. 
c.  There shall be no separate charge for shutting off the water supply for any premises, but in every instance when such shut-off was originally made for nonpayment of any delinquent account or violation of any rule of the City, a twenty-five ($25.00) dollar shut-off charge shall be collected plus a twenty-five ($25.00) dollar turn-on charge. 
d.  All requests of the owner or consumer for shut-off or turn-on of the water supply shall be made to the City in writing and form shall be supplied for that purpose. 
e.  In case of accident, breakdown, shortage of water supply or any cause beyond its control or because of any act or omission on the part of the City, or its agents, or any of them, or in case of the making of repairs, renewals, or replacements, the City reserves the right to shut off the water supply from any one (1) or any number of premises, without notice, and shall in no manner be held responsible for any consequences of such shut-off. 
f.  The City will give notice in the manner deemed in its discretion to be most effective, of any shut-off of the water supply wherever and whenever the giving of such notice is practicable, but nothing in these rules and regulations shall be construed to require the giving of such notice under any circumstances. 
g.  The shutting off of the water supply from and the discontinuance of service to any premise or premises for any cause shall not entitle the owner to any abatement or deduction in or from the water service charges, nor to any refund on any such charges paid in advance, during or for the time of such shut-off unless such period of shut-off continues and extends into the next month following that in which such shut-off was made. 
h.  If any damage is done to any City property including, but not limited to meters, stop cocks, locks, mains, etc., the actual cost of repair shall be a charge against the account. 
i.  Whenever the City is required to shut off water service at the main due to the customer restoring service once discontinued, the owner or tenant shall be required to pay all costs and charges including labor and materials in both shutting off and turning on the water at the main prior to restoration of service. 
(1957 Code § 23-15; Ord. No. 213 § K, 8-4-50; Ord. No. 80-28 §§ 4-7, 5-19-80; Ord. No. 2007-8, 9-18-2007) 
19-17 - LEAKS AND WASTE. 
a.  It shall be the duty of every owner, his agent or tenant, to at all times exercise diligence to prevent the waste of water, and to this end shall immediately stop all leaks on his premises. 
b.  Persisting in any willful waste, or neglect to promptly stop water through leaks, or extravagant and unnecessary use of water supply by or on the part of any owner, his agent or tenant, shall be sufficient cause to authorize the City to discontinue its service and shut off the water supply from and to the premises in question, without notice. 
c.  Whenever the water supply to and for any premises has been shut off because of leaks or waste as in this section provided, the same shall not be turned on again until all causes for shut-off shall have been remedied or removed, and satisfactory assurance shall have been given by the owner, his agent or tenant, to the City, that the condition causing the shut-off will not again exist, and the sum of one ($1.00) dollar shall have been paid to the City to cover the cost of again turning on the water supply. 
(Ord. No. 213 § L, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-16) 
19-18 - SPRINKLING DURING FIRE. 
    All sprinkling during a fire in the vicinity of any premises of which the owner, his agent or tenant, has, or may reasonably be presumed to have, knowledge or notice of, is prohibited, unless such sprinkling is for protection against such fire. 
(Ord. No. 213 § M, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-17) 
19-19 - PUBLIC FIRE HYDRANTS, INSTALLATION AND USE. 
a.  Fire hydrants shall be installed by the City subsequent to agreements with local governing bodies served by the City system. 
b.  All fire hydrants or plugs shall be used for fire protection purposes exclusively. All use of fire hydrants or plugs for sprinkling, sewer flushing, filling, watering or other purposes, and any use of fire hydrants or plugs other than for strictly fire protection (meaning thereby extinguishment of fires or wetting down surrounding properties during a fire to prevent its spreading) is prohibited unless any such other use is permitted by the City and evidenced by a written permit signed by its superintendent, which permit shall be exhibited to any employees of the City. 
c.  Permits for use of water from fire hydrants or plugs for any purpose other than for fire protection shall not be granted by the City except in cases where such use is deemed by the City to be urgent and other means of obtaining water are not available, but all permits so granted shall be revocable at the pleasure or discretion of the City in every instance and without regard to reference to any terms or provisions in such permits to the contrary notwithstanding. 
(Ord. No. 213 § N, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-18) 
19-20 - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS. 
a.  Owner Responsible for All Acts. Each owner will be held fully responsible and liable by and to the City for all that is done or omitted on, in or about any premises by any agent or tenant or other person not in the employ of the City, who may gain access thereto, relevant to water service. 
b.  Tenant Deemed Agent. The tenant in or upon any premises of any owner shall at all times and for all purposes connected with or arising from the City water supply service to and for such premises, except the making of the original application for water supply service pipe and contract, be taken and construed to be the properly constituted agent of the owner. 
c.  Service of Notices. Any notices, as prescribed herein, shall be deemed to have been properly served if left upon the premises of the owner or if mailed to the owner, directed to, or left at his address as shown on records of the City. All notices of a general character affecting or likely to affect more than one (1) owner, if required by these rules to be given, shall be deemed to have been properly given or served if advertised at least once in one (1) of the daily newspapers. 
d.  Amendments to Rates and Rules. Each addition or modification, alteration or amendment to any of the rates or rules of the City shall be and become binding upon, and shall form a part of the contract with each owner, upon the expiration of thirty (30) days' notice thereof in writing, to each owner affected thereby unless and except any such addition, modification, alteration or amendment is by these rules and regulations provided to be and become otherwise effective and binding on such owner, or any or more thereof. 
e.  Rates and Rules Part of Contract. All of the foregoing rates and rules shall be considered and taken to be a part of the contract, so far as the same may be applicable to the class of service covered by and included in such contract, with every owner or consumer who shall make application for the water supply service of the City or whose premises are furnished with, or are connected to the system of the City for such service, and every such owner shall be considered as having, and be taken and construed to have expressed his consent to be, bound thereby whenever application for such water supply service is made, or so long as the premises of any such owner are furnished with, or are connected to, the system of the City for such service. 
(Ord. No. 213 § O, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-19) 
19-21 - PENALTIES. 
    Any person found guilty of a violation of any of the foregoing rules and regulations or who shall fail to observe any of the foregoing rules and regulations or who shall take and use water of the City without paying therefor in accordance with this chapter hereof, or who shall connect his premises with any water main of the City without the permission of the City shall be subject to prosecution as provided in Section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 213 § P, 8-4-50; 1957 Code § 23-20) 
19-22 - ADDITIONAL CHARGE FOR EXPANSION AND UPGRADING OF CITY'S WATER FACILITIES. 
a.  Each builder and developer of construction within the City of North Miami Beach and without the City of North Miami Beach, but within the service area of the Public Utilities Department of the City of North Miami Beach, and also within the area wherein the City is selling or servicing bulk water, or is required so to do, shall hereafter pay their fair share to the City of North Miami Beach of the cost, expense and capital contribution of the in-plant expansion and upgrading necessary to provide and service such increased demand with the amount of potable water required to be supplied daily for the construction and its new and additional consumers. 
b.  The amount of gallonage necessary and required by such new construction, additions, or modifications to existing constructions requiring additional water; and new and additional consumers shall be estimated, determined and fixed solely by the City of North Miami Beach's Public Utilities Department or such other Department or person as designated by the City Manager, who will apply, in computing such estimate, the South Florida Code where applicable, and such other recognized methods of estimating gallonage usage, and in accordance with modern, sanitary engineering practices. The City of North Miami Beach may require a certified statement by a licensed engineer or architect certifying to the amount of gallonage required by the new or modified construction. 
c.  Computation of amount due; letter of allocation and commitment: 
1.  Each future builder, developer and owner of new construction, simultaneously with the issuance of a permit and/or letter of commitment by the Public Utilities Department of the City, in addition to any and all other payments, shall be charged and pay to the City of North Miami Beach a sum to be computed on the basis of the estimated gallonage, as mentioned in paragraph b. hereof, as follows: 
For each gallon per day, the sum of five dollars and twenty-two cents ($5.22) per gallon. 
2.  Any and all bulk users who purchase potable water from the City shall, prior to any connection to any new development or building within its service area, seek permission and approval by way of a request for letter of allocation and commitment. Upon approval by the City, after payment to the City of the appropriate in-plant charge as stated in paragraph c.1. above, the bulk user may make the necessary connections from the new building and/or development to its system for potable water. 
3.  It is the obligation and responsibility of all bulk users and purchasers from the City's potable water system not to hook up any additional connections to new developments and/or buildings within its service area without first having obtained the necessary letter of approval for allocation by the City of North Miami Beach and proof of payment of the in-plant cost as mentioned in paragraph c.1. above. In the event the bulk users fail to comply with the foregoing provisions, it shall then be the personal responsibility and obligation of the bulk user to make the full payment to the City for the in-plant charge. 
d.  The charge or rate set forth in paragraph c. hereof may be changed by the adoption of City ordinances or resolutions from time to time at the sole discretion of the City Council, based upon technical and documentary information submitted to the Council by the consulting engineer of the City, or by other advisory personnel or professionals selected by the City Council. 
e.  The monies collected pursuant to this section shall be kept and placed in a separate interest-bearing account of the City, and shall be designated as an "In-plant Expansion and Upgrading Fund of Water System," until the opportunity arises for the use thereof toward payment of the cost and expense of the future water expansion and upgrading programs, as approved and directed hereafter by the City Council. 
f.  All in-plant fees charged in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be assessed in a uniform manner as set forth in paragraphs b. and c., and shall be collected in full by the City of North Miami Beach's Utilities Department prior to the approval of any plans and prior to the issuance of any permits or licenses. 
g.  In the event that such gallonage cannot be determined at the time the payment of the in-plant fee is due, an initial estimate of gallonage will be made based on the criteria set forth in paragraphs b. and c. herein. The initial estimate shall be designated as a minimum only. If an evaluation of the average daily gallonage used by such new or modified construction two (2) years after the completion of construction reveals that the actual gallonage usage exceeds the original estimate by ten (10%) percent, the in-plant fee will be adjusted to reflect the actual amount, and the difference between the cost for the estimated gallonage and the actual gallonage for the entire period of water use shall be assessed against the property. Payment of the adjusted amount, as well as interest and penalties, shall be due in full within thirty (30) days from the date the adjusted assessment is made. In the event that the initial estimate exceeds the actual gallonage, a refund shall be available without interest after application to and approval by the Mayor and City Council. This section shall apply only to specialty new construction, modifications or additions which, due to their unusual nature, render the City of North Miami Beach incapable of calculating an accurate in-plant fee prior to evaluating the actual use after completion of construction. 
h.  All adjusted assessments as set forth in paragraph g. above shall bear interest at the rate of one (1%) percent per month from the date of the payment of the in-plant fee. 
i.  A penalty in the amount of ten (10%) percent of the actual adjusted in-plant fee shall be assessed against the property for each deviation from the initial gallonage estimate as defined in paragraph g. above. Payment of the penalty shall be due within thirty (30) days from the date of the notice of the adjusted assessment as set forth in paragraph g. above. 
(1957 Code § 23-21; Ord. No. 74-18 §§ 1-5, 11-5-74; Ord. No. 74-24 §§ 1, 2, 1-7-75; Ord. No. 75-9 §§ 1-4, 5-6-75; Ord. No. 83-13 § 2, 8-16-83; Ord. No. 2005-11 § 2, 7-19-2005; Ord. No. 2006-20 § 2, 10-17-2006) 
19-23 - FIRE FLOW DEMAND CHARGE ON NEW BUILDINGS AND CONVERSIONS. 
a.  Established; Purpose. A fire flow demand charge is established to facilitate the expansion and upgrading of the water facilities for the fire flow system of the water service area of the City of North Miami Beach. 
b.  When Charge Payable; Water Shut-off for Nonpayment. The charge shall be paid to the Public Utilities Department of the City of North Miami Beach prior to the issuance of a building permit, or a certificate of occupancy in the case of a conversion, for the buildings addressed hereunder; or within thirty (30) days of demand by the Public Utilities Department. In the event payment is not received, the water to the subject property may be shut off immediately by the Public Utilities Department. 
c.  Rates; Multifamily Dwellings, Hotels, Schools, etc. The following schedule shall be the rate per gross square foot of the floor area regarding the structures within the water service area listed in paragraphs 1. and 2. below: 
Square Feet of Building, 
Conversions or Additions Rate per Square Foot

1.  All new buildings, conversions of or additions to existing buildings, for use as: 
(a)  Residential apartments. 
(b)  Condominiums. 
(c)  Cooperatives. 
(d)  Hotels. 
(e)  Motels. 
(f)  Time-share residences.

1.  New commercial or business buildings.

e.  Exceptions. Specifically exempted from the payment of a charge shall be the following structures: 
1.  Single-family residences. 
2.  Duplexes housing no more than two (2) families. 
f.  Computation of Gross Square Foot Area. The computation of the gross square foot area shall be made from the exterior dimensions, including all columns, stairways, hallways and vestibules. 
g.  Fund Established; Use of Proceeds Generally. All amounts collected shall be held by the Public Utilities Department in a fire flow demand fund account pursuant to all administrative procedures and City of North Miami Beach prescriptions, including bond issue requirements, and shall be expended for the installation, upsizing or improvement of any water line larger than seven (7) inches in diameter, including fire hydrants. 
h.  Allocation of Funds. The allocation of funds generated by this section shall be as follows: 
1.  For any Public Utilities Department capital improvement project which concerns water lines eight (8) inches to fifteen (15) inches in diameter, including fire hydrants, the project may receive up to one hundred (100%) percent of its funding from sums generated by this section. 
2.  For any Public Utilities Department capital improvement project which concerns water lines sixteen (16) inches or greater in diameter, including fire hydrants, the project may receive up to seventy-five (75%) percent of its funding from sums generated by this section. The remaining funding may come from revenue obtained under Section 19-22 of the Code of Ordinance of the City of North Miami Beach. 
i.  Review of Facilities by Fire Department. The Fire Department for Miami-Dade County may, at its option, review the facilities to be upgraded. 
(1957 Code § 23-22; Ord. No. 83-3A § 2, 3-15-83; Ord. No. 85-6 §§ 2, 3, 8-6-85; Ord. No. 92-6 § 3, 5-5-92; Ord. No. 2005-11 § 2, 7-19-05; Ord. No. 2006-20 § 2, 10-17-06) 
19-24 - EMERGENCY WATER CONSERVATION RATES. 
    During periods of mandated water restrictions by the South Florida Water Management District, an automatic adjustment to the rates shall be instituted. The rate adjustments are as follows: 
a.  During Phase I restrictions, a five (5%) percent surcharge will be added to the consumption portion of the bill for the following: each single-family customer for all water used in excess of three thousand (3,000) gallons per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each multi-family customer for all water used in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per unit per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each nonresidential customer for all water used in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per month per Equivalent Residential Connection, each wholesale customer for all water used. 
b.  During Phase II restrictions, a ten (10%) percent surcharge will be added to the consumption portion of the bill for the following: each single-family customer for all water used in excess of three thousand (3,000) gallons per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each multi-family customer for all water used in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per unit per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each nonresidential customer for all water used in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each wholesale customer for all water used. 
c.  During Phase III restrictions, a fifteen (15%) percent surcharge will be added to the consumption portion of the bill for the following: each single-family customer for all water used in excess of three thousand (3,000) gallons per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each multi-family customer for all water used in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per unit per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each nonresidential customer for all water used in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each wholesale customer for all water used. 
d.  During Phase IV restrictions, a twenty-five (25%) percent surcharge will be added to the consumption portion of the bill for the following: each single-family customer for all water used in excess of three thousand (3,000) gallons per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each multi-family customer for all water used in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per unit per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each nonresidential customer for all water used in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per month per Equivalent Residential Connection; each wholesale customer for all water used. 
(Ord. No. 2008-7 § 2, 4-15-08; Ord. No. 2009-21 § 2, 9-22-09) 
19-25-19-29 - RESERVED. 
Article III. - Sewers 
DIVISION I. - SEWER USE RULES AND REGULATIONS 

19-30 - ADOPTION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    The attached rules and regulations [3] relating to the use of the City of North Miami Beach Sewer System are hereby established, adopted, and promulgated, and shall be in full force and effect pursuant to section 3.11(b) of the rules and regulations, and the policies set forth in the rules and regulations are hereby ratified and confirmed and adopted as the policy of the City of North Miami Beach. 
(1957 Code § 23-41; Ord. No. 89-13 § 3, 10-17-89; Ord. No. 92-6 § 3, 5-5-92)

(f)  Replacing of grass with sod only, any special landscaping and trees to be replaced by owner.
