A subdivider or property owner in a subdivision may connect into an approved subdivision sewer without fee, for a period of five (5) years after the sewerage is constructed, providing that a previous subdivider has paid the entire connection charge and construction costs for the sewers in the subdivision. 
(1957 Code § 23-42; Ord. No. 89-13 § 4, 10-17-89; Ord. No. 92-6 § 3, 5-5-92; Ord. No. 92-8 § 2, 6-2-92; Ord. No. 92-24 § 2, 11-3-92; Ord. No. 93-12 § 2, 12-21-93; Ord. No. 94-34 § 4, 9-22-94; Ord. No. 95-14 § 4, 9-19-95; Ord. No. 96-13 § 2, 10-1-96; Ord. No. 97-9 § 2, 9-9-97; Ord. No. 98-10 § 2, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 99-6 § 2, 10-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-9 § 2, 9-25-01; Ord. No. 2002-25 § 2, 1-7-03; Ord. No. 2003-11 § 2, 10-7-03; Ord. No. 2004-15 § 2, 9-28-04; Ord. No. 2005-14 § 2, 9-22-05; Ord. No. 2006-19 § 2, 9-26-06; Ord. No. 2007-8, 9-18-2007; Ord. No. 2008-19 § 1, 9-23-08; Ord. No. 2009-21 § 2, 9-22-09; Ord. No. 2010-26 § 2, 9-28-10; Ord. No. 2011-15 § 2, 9-20-11; Ord. No. 2012-21, § 2, 9-20-12 ; Ord. No. 2013-18, § 3, 10-1-13 ; Ord. No. 2014-9 , § 2, 9-23-14; Ord. No. 2018-13 , § 2, 10-29-18) 
19-32 - BILLS-SURCHARGES ON DELINQUENT ACCOUNTS. 
    A penalty or surcharge shall automatically be imposed upon all delinquent customers of sewer service, in the amount of ten (10%) percent of the prior billing cycle's sewer charges or of any outstanding previous balance due at the time of each billing whichever is lower, and said surcharge shall be added on at the time of said billing and shall be due and owing to the City by the said delinquent customer. 
(Ord. No. 2007-8, 9-18-07) 
CHAPTER XX - STORMWATER 

20-1 - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT UTILITY PROGRAM. 
20-1.1   Intent.
    It is the intent of this chapter that the City of North Miami Beach hereby establishes stormwater management as a City utility in accordance with Section 403.0893, Florida Statutes, to operate under the City's Department of Public Works, and hereby establishes a program of user charges and connection fees for stormwater management service to be levied against all real property within the City to accomplish the functions of said utility. These functions include, but are not limited to administration, maintenance, planning, design, construction, regulation, surveying, inspection, and enforcement as they relate to stormwater management facilities of the City. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-1, 7-7-92) 
20-1.2   Definitions.
    City shall mean the City of North Miami Beach, Florida and its staff and elected officials. 
    Department shall mean the Public Works Department. 
    Drainage area shall mean the watershed (acreage) contributing surface water runoff to the City's stormwater management system. 
    Equivalent runoff unit (ERU) shall mean the basic unit for the computation of stormwater service charges. This unit is the statistically estimated average horizontal impervious area of residential developed property per single family dwelling unit. This estimated average is calculated by dividing the total impervious area of three (3) residential categories, to wit, single family, duplex, and mobile home, by the estimated total number of residential dwelling units. 
    Impervious area shall mean surface areas in a parcel of real property, which prevent or severely restrict infiltration of stormwater into the earth. 
    Manager shall mean the City Manager or designee. 
    Multifamily shall mean all apartment, condominium and congregate living facilities, of one (1) or more structures, having three (3) or more dwelling units within the same property. 
    Nonresidential/commercial shall include all property zoned or used for commercial, industrial, retail, business, governmental, residential office, or other nonresidential purposes and shall include all developed real property in the City not classified as single-family or multifamily as defined in this subsection. 
    Residential single-family shall mean all detached single-family homes, each half of a duplex property, or mobile home. 
    Receiving water shall mean those creeks, streams, rivers, lakes, canals, bays, and other bodies of water into which surface waters are directed, either naturally or in manmade ditches, pipes, or open systems. 
    Stormwater management plan shall mean a plan, as adopted by the City Council, for receiving, handling, and transporting storm and surface waters within the City. 
    Stormwater management system shall mean all natural and manmade elements used to convey stormwater from the first point of impact with the surface of the earth to a suitable receiving water or location internal or external to the boundaries of the City. The stormwater management system includes all pipes, channels, streams, ditches, wetlands, canals, bays, detention/retention basins, ponds, and other stormwater conveyance and treatment facilities. Regardless of whether or not the City shall have recorded rights-of-way or easements, it is presumed that the City has a prescriptive right of access to all stormwater management facilities for operation, maintenance, rehabilitation, or replacement. 
    Vacant shall mean a property that is presently unimproved, or has had all improvements totally demolished and removed, except for the placement of clean fill, which shall not be considered an improvement for the purposes of this definition. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-2, 7-7-92) 
20-1.3   Utility Established.
    There is hereby created and established in the City a Stormwater Management Utility in accordance with Section 403.0893, Florida Statutes. This Utility shall be responsible for the City's stormwater management system and shall have equal status with the other utility services provided by the City of North Miami Beach. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-3, 7-7-92) 
20-1.4   Directors of the Stormwater Management Utility.
    The Directors of the Stormwater Management Utility shall be the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-4, 7-7-92) 
20-1.5   Duties and Powers.
    The Stormwater Management Utility shall have all powers necessary for the exercise of its responsibility for the drainage from all properties within the City including, but not limited to, the following: 
a.  Preparation of plans for improvements and betterments to the stormwater management system. 
b.  Construction of improvements and betterments to the stormwater management system. 
c.  The promulgation of regulations for the use of the stormwater management system, including provisions for enforcement or said regulations. 
d.  Review and approval of all new development permits within the City for compliance with stormwater management regulations included in present City ordinances or ordinances later adopted. 
e.  Performance of routine maintenance and minor improvement of the stormwater management system. 
f.  Establishment of charges for connection and use of the stormwater management system. 
g.  Evaluation of water quality concerns for discharges to the stormwater management system. 
h.  Performance of all normal utility functions to include administration, construction, operation, maintenance, and enforcement of the City's stormwater management system including, but not limited to, the hiring of staff, the selection of special consultants, the entering into contracts for services and construction of facilities, and the handling of purchase, lease, sale or other rights to property for the stormwater management system. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-5, 7-7-92) 
20-1.6   Service Charges.
a.  Authority. The Stormwater Management Utility is empowered by this chapter to establish charges for the use and discharge to the City's stormwater management system. Such charges shall be based on the cost of providing stormwater management services to all properties within the City. The City Council may revise the schedule of charges for stormwater management services to cover funding requirements of utility operations. 
b.  Charges Assessed. Rates for stormwater management service shall be levied against all owners or occupants of all real property in the City which contribute stormwater runoff to and/or which benefit from the City's stormwater management system as a monthly fee in accordance with the following definitions: 
1.  Single-Family Property Services Charges: Each single-family property as defined shall be charged one (1) ERU per month. Service charges for each single-family dwelling unit shall be identical. 
2.  Multi-Family Property Service Charges: Each multi-family property as defined shall be charged 0.75 ERU (three-fourths [3/4] of one [1] ERU) per dwelling unit. Service charges for each multi-family dwelling unit shall be identical. 
3.  Nonresidential/Commercial Property Service Charges: The monthly service charge for all nonresidential and commercial properties shall be based on the number of equivalent runoff units (ERU) calculated for the property and the impervious areas thereon, but not less than one (1) ERU. Additionally there will be a twenty-five (25%) percent surcharge assessed to nonresidential and commercial properties for water quality impact such that the total monthly charge for each nonresidential and/or commercial property shall be determined as follows: 
Total Impervious Area x 1.25 
_______ = Total Era's 
Area of one (1) ERU (as defined) 
(a)  Owners of nonresidential/ commercial property that provide for complete retention of stormwater runoff on site in accordance with Florida Building Code, and Section 20-93 of the North Miami Beach Code, as amended, may appeal for a waiver from the water quality surcharge. 
The property owner must provide proof of on-site stormwater retention to the Director of Public Works or his designee. The following documentation shall be submitted by the property owner: 
(1)  Survey of subject property, adjacent roadways, and twenty (20) feet of all adjacent properties by a Florida registered professional land surveyor, showing elevation contours and stormwater management facilities, and all other physical improvements on the property; and 
(2)  Certification that stormwater management facilities shall be adequately maintained and cleaned, and kept functional at all times; and 
(3)  Other documentation or proof as deemed necessary by the Public Works Director. 
The City Manager may grant such exemptions upon verification of onsite stormwater retention by the Public Works Department. 
(b)  If at any time, and upon reinspection of the private facilities, it is the opinion of the Public Works Director that the facilities are not functioning so as to completely retain all of the property's stormwater runoff, he shall recommend to the City Manager that the water quality surcharge be applied to the property's monthly utility billings henceforth. 
4.  Vacant and Open Space. The monthly service charge for vacant and open space properties shall be based on the zoning classification and the size of the parcel as follows: 
(a)  Platted properties zoned for single-family residential development, of less than one-half (1/2) acre in size, shall be charged at the rate of one-half (0.5) ERU per month. 
(b)  All other properties of less than one (1) acre in size shall be charged at the rate of one (1) ERU per month. 
(c)  Properties one (1) acre in size or larger, but smaller than two (2) acres, shall be charged at the rate of two and one-half (2.5) ERU's per month; and 
(d)  Properties two (2) acres and larger in size, shall be charged at the rate of five (5) ERU's per month. 
c.  Application to All Properties. Service charges shall apply to all properties within the City, including those properties classified as nonprofit or tax-exempt for ad valorem tax purposes. 
d.  Exemptions. The following properties shall be exempt from the Stormwater Management Utility charge: 
1.  Public rights-of-way and alleyways, as platted or dedicated by deed. 
2.  Public drainage canals, wetlands, bays, lakes, and other bodies of water determined to be noncontributory; except for water bodies fitted with impervious surfaces or linings, and stormwater retention and detention basins. 
e.  Billing. The fees imposed by this chapter shall be billed in conjunction with the property owner's sanitation bill issued by the City of North Miami Beach. Such fees shall be due and payable at the same time and in the same manner and subject to the same penalties as other utility fees. 
    Any partial payment made towards a joint utility bill will be deemed to be a pro rata payment towards all utility services, regardless of the customer's designation or allocation of payment. 
    In the event a property shall not have utility service at the time of the adoption of this ordinance, but is deemed to be contributing runoff to the City's stormwater management system, a new account shall be developed and that property shall be billed separately for the stormwater management charges. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-6, 7-7-92) 
20-1.7   Stormwater Management Utility Fund.
a.  A Stormwater Management Utility Fund is hereby established into which all revenues from user fees, connection charges, grants, or other funding sources shall be deposited and from which all expenditures related to the City's stormwater management utility shall be paid. Accounting and reporting procedures shall be consistent with State law and generally accepted accounting principles and reported to the City Council by the City Manager or designee, annually. 
b.  Expenditures for activities that are not related to the City's Stormwater Management Utility shall not be permitted from the fund except for a prorated charge for general City government services as is in effect for other City utility funds. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-7, 7-7-92) 
20-1.8   Appeals.
a.  Any customer or property owner who feels that the stormwater management service charge for his property has been assigned or computed incorrectly may petition, in writing, to the City Manager or designee for a review of said charge. 
b.  If not satisfied with the determination of the City Manager or designee, the petitioner may request a hearing before the City Council, whose decision shall be final. Any credits authorized by the appeal process shall only be effective against billings subsequent to the date of authorization. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-8, 7-7-92) 
20-1.9   Delinquent Charges; Liens.
    A late or surcharge shall automatically be imposed upon any delinquent customers of the stormwater utility, in the amount of ten (10%) percent of the prior billing period's unpaid stormwater utility charges, and said surcharge shall be added on at the time of said billing and shall be due and owing to the City by the said delinquent customer. 
    The City shall have a lien for delinquent or unpaid stormwater management service charges. Enforcement and foreclosure of said lien(s) shall be as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-9, 7-7-92) 
20-2 - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT UTILITY SCHEDULE OF RATES. 
20-2.1   Size of the Equivalent Runoff Unit.
    The size of one (1) equivalent runoff unit (ERU) is determined to be one thousand eight hundred (1,800) square feet. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-10, 7-7-92) 
20-2.2   Monthly Utility Rate.
    An equivalent runoff unit (ERU) rate of four dollars and fifty ($4.50) cents per month per ERU is hereby established and shall be used to calculate the total monthly Stormwater Management Utility charge for all parcels of property located in the City of North Miami Beach, in accordance with the applicable formula established in subsection 20-1.6 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-11, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 96-6 § 25-11, 4-2-96; Ord. No. 98-11 § 25-11; Ord. No. 98-11, 10-6-98; Ord. No. 2005-15 § 25-11, 9-8-05; Ord. No. 2006-18 § 25-11, 9-26-06) 
20-2.3   Adjustments of Monthly Rate and ERU Size.
    City Council may review the Stormwater Utility charges at any time and may, by ordinance, increase or decrease the size of one (1) ERU or the monthly utility rate, or both, upon a determination that said increases or decreases are warranted. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-12, 7-7-92) 
20-3 - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT UTILITY ORGANIZATION. 
20-3.1   Stormwater Utility Division Created.
    There is hereby created a Stormwater Utility Division within the Department of Public Works of the City of North Miami Beach, which, in coordination with the City Finance Director, has the responsibility for planning, developing, and implementing stormwater management plans; financing, constructing, maintaining, rehabilitating, inspecting, and managing existing and new stormwater facilities; collecting fees and charges for the Utility Division; implementing and enforcing the provisions of this chapter; and other related duties as directed by the City Manager. The Utility Division shall be administered by the Director of Public Works, or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-13, 7-7-92) 
20-3.2   Determination of Impervious Area and Total Parcel Area.
    The Public Works Director shall be responsible for determining impervious area of developed property and total parcel area based on data obtained from the Miami-Dade County Property Appraiser. If such information is unavailable from the property appraiser, the property owner, tenant or developer may submit a certified survey and/or a foundation survey to assist the Director in determining impervious area and total parcel area. The Director may require additional information as necessary to make the determination. The amount of any fee may be revised by the Director based on any additions to the impervious area as approved through the building permit process. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-14, 7-7-92) 
20-3.3   Flooding, Liability.
    Floods from stormwater runoff may occasionally occur which exceed the capacity of storm drainage facilities constructed, operated, or maintained by funds made available under this chapter. This chapter shall not be construed or interpreted to mean that property subject to the fees and charges established herein will always (or at any time) be free from stormwater flooding or flood damage, or that stormwater systems capable of handling all storm events can be cost-effectively constructed, operated, or maintained. This chapter shall not create any liability on the part of, or cause of action against the City, or any official or employee thereof, for any flood damage that may result from such storms or the runoff therefrom. This chapter does not purport to reduce the need or eliminate the necessity for individual property owners to obtain flood insurance. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-15, 7-7-92) 
20-3.4   Private Facilities.
    The property owner shall be responsible for stormwater drainage facilities located on private property, where runoff will principally be collected and disposed of within that property in compliance with the Florida Building Code, Miami-Dade County Code and Florida Administrative Code. The owner shall clean and maintain the facility, as required, to ensure efficient and proper operation of the facility, and shall obtain prior written approval from the Director of Public Works or his designee for any proposed changes or alterations to any private stormwater drainage facilities that, in the City's sole discretion, may substantially or adversely affect stormwater drainage in the area of the property. The Director of Public Works shall provide for inspection of private facilities to ascertain that the stormwater facilities are functioning as designed and approved. The Utility Division shall require that the property owner perform remedial maintenance of facilities based upon the severity of stormwater problems and potential hazard to the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 92-12 § 25-16, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 2006-1 § 2) 
CHAPTER XXI - HEALTH 

21-1 - IN GENERAL. 
21-1.1   State Sanitary Code Adopted by Reference.
    The Sanitary Code of the State of Florida be and the same is hereby adopted as part of the basic law of the City, and incorporated herein by reference as if fully set out herein, except where the same is modified, deleted or amended by this Code of Ordinances or is in conflict herewith. 
(Ord. No. 531, 3-21-56; 1957 Code § 11-1) 
State Law reference- See F.S.A. (1966) chapters 381 through 387, 509, 513, 514. 
21-1.2   Procuring State Certificate, Required.
    All establishments selling, manufacturing, processing or handling foodstuffs, including food liquids of any kind, as well as any and all businesses, either establishments or mobile, are hereby required to first comply with the State health laws, and procure from the State health authorities a certificate or other requisite, acknowledging in writing that the State health regulations have been met; provided, such certificate or written acknowledgment shall be first presented to the granting authorities as a condition precedent to the issuance of an business tax receipt to do business within the circumscribed area of the City; provided further, such certificate or written acknowledgment shall be kept in the files of the City Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 530, 3-21-56; 1957 Code § 11-2) 
21-1.3   Sanitation Department Employees "On Call."
    All of the employees of the City Sanitary Department will forthwith be placed on the same "on call" basis as that of the employees of the Police and Fire Department; that is to say, that the employees of the Sanitation Department shall hold themselves in readiness for immediate service at all times, which includes holidays, under the same conditions of emergency which apply to the Police and Fire Departments of the City. 
(Ord. No. 497 § 1, 12-6-55; 1957 Code § 11-3) 
21-2 - SEWAGE DISPOSAL. 
21-2.1   Definitions.
    As used in this section: 
    Human excreta shall mean the bowel and kidney discharges of human beings. 
    Sanitary privy shall mean any privy which is so built, rebuilt, constructed or reconstructed, as to conform with plans and specifications promulgated and recommended by the State Board of Health. 
    Septic tank shall mean an underground cavity with watertight walls into which flows the effluent of sanitary water closets and from which the effluent does not come to the surface of the ground. 
    Sanitary water closet shall mean any flush toilet properly connected with the City sewer or a septic tank of approved construction. 
(Ord. No. 47, Art. II §§ 1-4, 2-27-34; 1957 Code § 11-4) 
21-2.2   Sanitary Method of Disposing of Human Excreta Required.
    Every residence and building in which human beings reside, are employed or congregated, shall be required to have a sanitary method of human excreta disposal, namely: have a sanitary water closet connected with the City sewer, an approved type of septic tank or a sanitary privy. 
(Ord. No. 47, Art. I § 2, 2-27-34; 1957 Code § 11-5) 
Editor's note- Authority to provide for sanitary disposal of sewage, Charter § 21 (16), (36). 
21-2.3   Approved Methods of Disposal.
    It shall be unlawful to dispose of any human excreta within the corporate limits of the City except in a sanitary water closet or a sanitary privy. 
(Ord. No. 47, Art. I § 2, 2-27-34; 1957 Code § 11-6) 
21-2.4   Leased or Rental Property.
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or leasing any premises in the City to permit the disposal of any human excreta on any property leased or rented by any such person or the agent of any such person, except in a sanitary water toilet or a sanitary privy, and it shall be unlawful to permit the disposal of any material in a sanitary privy other than human excreta and paper. 
(Ord. No. 47, Art. I § 3, 2-27-34; 1957 Code § 11-7) 
21-2.5   Septic Tanks; Approval by State.
    No septic tank other than those approved by the State Board of Health shall be constructed within the corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. 47, Art. I § 4, 2-27-34; 1957 Code § 11-8) 
21-2.6   Privies Declared Nuisances.
    All privies within the corporate limits not constructed or maintained in conformity with plans and instructions of the State Board of Health, or located where prohibited, shall be and are hereby declared nuisances dangerous and injurious to the public health, and shall be condemned and forthwith abated in accordance with the law of the City. 
(Ord. No. 47, Art. I § 6, 2-27-34; 1957 Code § 11-9) 
21-2.7   Alterations in Privies.
    The City shall have the further right to make or have made such alterations and constructions of those privies which are nuisances and make them sanitary, and all costs pertaining to such work shall be charged against the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 47, Art. I § 7, 2-27-34; 1957 Code § 11-10) 
21-2.8   Owners Abutting Sewer Line; Required to Connect.
    Where in any street or section of street is constructed a public sewer for the purpose of carrying off the sewage, the owner or owners of property abutting on, or adjacent to such sewer so constructed, shall connect the house and building on such property with such public sewer in accordance with the Miami-Dade County Code. 
(Ord. No. 47, Art. I § 8, 2-27-34; 1957 Code § 11-11) 
21-3 - AIR POLLUTION[1] 
21-3.1   Prohibition Against Incinerator Burning.
a.  Incinerator burning of combustible refuse of any type is prohibited within the City of North Miami Beach without first obtaining a permit from the City Council. The prohibition against incinerator burning includes any article, machine, equipment, contrivance, structure or part of structure used to dispose of combustible refuse by burning. 
b.  In considering whether or not to issue a permit for the construction of an incineration device, the City Council shall consider the following, among other factors: 
1.  The location of the proposed facility; 
2.  The proximity of the facility to residential areas; 
3.  The type of facility being proposed; 
4.  The proposed hours of operation of the facility; 
5.  The intended use of the facility; 
6.  The reason for the request for construction of the facility; 
7.  Any possible environmental concerns; 
8.  All other factors that may be reasonable and necessary to consider before permitting the structure. 
c.  The City Council may issue a permit with reasonable conditions attached thereto. 
(1957 Code § 11-12; Ord. No. 82-17 § 2, 5-4-82) 
21-3.2   Dense Smoke; Conditions When Emission Permitted; Abatement.
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or in charge of any tar, kettle, steam machine or contrivance, or of any open fire, smokestack, or chimney of any building or premises to allow the emission of dense smoke except for one (1) hour at the time when the fire-box is being cleaned out or a new fire being built therein, during which period of or periods aggregating six (6) minutes in any one (1) hour, the emission of smoke of a shade or density greater than number three (3) of the Ringlemann Chart as published by the United States Bureau of Mines, is prohibited. Such emission of smoke is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and may be summarily abated by the City Clerk in charge, or by anyone whom he may duly authorize for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 207 § 8, 6-6-50; 1957 Code § 11-19) 
21-3.3   Soot from Smokestacks.
    No person shall cause or allow the escape from any smokestack or chimney into the open air of such quantities of ash dust, soot, cinders, acid or other fumes, dirt or other material, or noxious gases in such place or manner as to cause injury, detriment, nuisance, or annoyance to any person or to the public or to endanger the comfort, repose, health or safety of any such person or the public, or in such a manner as to cause or have a natural tendency to cause injury or damage to business or property. 
    All persons participating in any violation of this provision either as owners, proprietors, lessees, agents, tenants, managers, superintendents, engineers, firemen, janitors or otherwise shall be severally liable therefor. 
(Ord. No. 207 § 9, 6-6-50; 1957 Code § 11-20)
